fields.headline: Investors flee to dollar haven
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The US dollar, government bonds and gold were in high demand last night as international investors sought refuge after one of the most tumultuous days in years on the global financial markets.
fields.body:
The US dollar, government bonds and gold were in high demand last night as international investors sought refuge after one of the most tumultuous days in years on the global financial markets.

Sterling and the Swiss franc were also sought after in a flight to quality which saw dealers mark down the value of any assets seen as remotely risky. Developing countries from the Phillipines to Poland saw their currencies unceremoniously dumped.

With the US dollar apparently impervious to the precipitous drop in share prices on Wall Street, the euro dropped to less than 86.5 cents against the US currency, below the level at which the G7 stepped in to deter speculative attacks last month.

The pound rose to a five-month high against the single currency, with one euro costing just under 59p.

Sterling's trade-weighted index rose to 109.6, its highest since May, when it hit 14-year peaks.

Bond markets saw a marked divergence between strong demand for government stock -both in the US and Europe -and weakness in the corporate bond market, where investors were demanding higher returns to compensate for a perceived increase in risk.

Gold - historically the safest of havens in times of crisis -rose by more than $3 an ounce to $276.10, but is still far below its peak of $800 reached during the oil crisis of the 1970s.

fields.headline: Is this a trombone I see before me?
fields.standfirst:
Northern Sinfonia/Lindberg
Newcastle City Hall
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Northern Sinfonia/Lindberg
Newcastle City Hall
Rating: ****
fields.body:
This was the madcap Swedish trombonist Christian Lindberg's first ever conducting engagement. The wonder was that he hadn't brought his motorbike. As a solo trombone virtuoso Lindberg is number one in a field of one. Although a recent poll placed him in the all-time top 10 of brass players, alongside Miles Davis and Louis Armstrong, the established classical repertoire for solo trombone remains select. Lindberg has come to specialise in purpose-built concerti, with Berio, Takemitsu and Nyman among the many figures inspired to write for his extraordinary talent. Lindberg's most trusted collaborator, however, is a fellow Swede, Jan Sandstrom, who began the process in 1989 with the Motorbike Concerto in which Linberg sits astride a revved-up Harley Davidson and unleashes his instrument at full throttle.

Impressed, the Northern Sinfonia asked Lindberg to come back and conduct. Aware of his limitations, Lindberg refused. The orchestra persisted, and eventually the trombonist turned to Sandstrom for help.

Sandstrom's response was to come up with a piece containing all the mistakes Lindberg could possibly make, based on Shakespeare's Macbeth.

The 30-minute piece, which is entitled A Scottish Play, is indeed a mess. This is orchestrated mayhem in the truest sense: Lindberg alternately empties his lungs into his instrument with frenzied virtuosity then barks out scraps of the bard's verse, while the orchestra alternately lurches into life and stammers to a halt around him.

Only a performer of Lindberg's indestructibility could get away with this kind of thing - and he does, magnificently. He also performs a "proper" romantic trombone concerto by Mendelssohn's associate, Ferdinand David. Anyone who doubts that the trombone has the eloquence to function as a solo instrument need only listen to the sheer poetry that floats out of Lindberg's horn.

 Further performance tonight at the Sands Centre, Carlisle. Box office: 0500 591 996.

fields.headline: Your not-so-secret history
fields.standfirst: What you thought of as confidential doctor's appointments can be used against you if you let a solicitor get hold of those medical notes, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: What you thought of as confidential doctor's appointments can be used against you if you let a solicitor get hold of those medical notes, an employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
Seeing lots of other people's medical notes makes one somewhat doctor-shy. You know that in the terrible eventuality that you ever get involved in litigation about a whiplash injury or similar, some lawyer somewhere is going to be flipping idly through your notes, musing about your verrucas, your urinary tract infections, that thing on your nose you just thought you'd ask your GP about. All your physical failings and fits of hypochondria laid out bleakly in black and white.

I'm not sure what Julie, my client this week, thought her GP was writing in her notes. We had the first instalment of Julie's case about six months ago. Julie was a junior solicitor who said she had been bullied by her boss to the point where she had a nervous breakdown and had to leave work. When I first saw Julie she seemed to present graphic physical evidence of whatever she had been through - her eyelids were red, her neck covered in silver and pink scale that she scrubbed at with shaking hands. She talked very fast, but she made sense.

Julie hasn't felt able to apply for another job and it's hard to see how in her condition she would get one. So in the interval between instalments of her case, her solicitor and I suggested to Julie that we get a medical report to explain her condition to the tribunal. Julie was happy with that.

So here we are: Julie, her solicitor, the psychiatrist and I, sat round a table a week before her case resumes, looking in silence at fat photocopied bundles of Julie's medical records.

I don't want to know all of the things I now know about Julie. Julie is thirty. There are entries going back more than fourteen years about her eating disorders, her abortions, her suicide attempts. These are the least of our worries. The notes that are the most disturbing from the point of view of Julie's case go back about three years. They say things like, "Still abusing cocaine and amphetamines. Not sleeping. Paranoia++."

Julie shakes her head: "I didn't know he was writing all this stuff down. I thought it was confidential."

Me: "It is. It was. But we told your ex-employer we were going to rely on evidence of your medical condition. You agreed they should see this material."

Julie's nails are raising a papery storm of scales from her neck: "Well does it matter that much? Why does it matter?"

Julie's solicitor doesn't want to spell it out. The psychiatrist is busying himself with a rich tea biscuit. I try to look at Julie's eyes and not her ravaged neck: "Because there is a straight conflict of evidence between you and your boss on the bullying issue. Because they are going to cross-examine you on your medical notes and say that you had a drug problem that made you paranoid, that there was no bullying."

It is obvious to me from Julie's face that she knew this, that she just needed to hear it, that she doesn't want to sit in a tribunal and be exposed in this way, that she won't continue with her case.

But as she leaves the room, she says to me very quietly: "You know, just because you're screwed up doesn't mean people haven't done things to hurt you."

webTitle: Warning from history points to crash

fields.headline: Warning from history points to crash
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Suddenly the drama threatens to turn into a full blown crisis. The television screens are full of Israeli helicopters hitting targets in the Gaza strip. Gunboats patrol menacingly offshore.
fields.body:
Suddenly the drama threatens to turn into a full blown crisis. The television screens are full of Israeli helicopters hitting targets in the Gaza strip. Gunboats patrol menacingly offshore.

The response of the world's financial markets has been swift. Equity markets, led by Wall Street, are in a spin, bond and currency markets look even more fragile than earlier in the week. The oil price has jumped to $35 a barrel and already there is panicky talk in the market that - if the worst comes to the worst - it could hit $100. "Flight to quality" has become the predictable mantra.

But hang on. Haven't we been here before? Oil crises are nothing new. Policy makers have learned how to cope; they know which levers to pull to keep the global economy on course.

Well, up to a point. We have certainly been here before - three times, since the Yom Kippur war of 1973 brought the long boom to a halt. The reason it did so was that a five-fold increase in the cost of energy added to already strong inflationary pressure. By adding to the costs of almost everything it hit incomes and profits, dashing consumer and corporate confidence. When central banks raised interest rates to combat higher inflation all the conditions were in place for the dreaded stagflation.

Subsequent oil shocks - in 1979-80 and 1990-91 - ultimately led to slower growth and higher unemployment. The current increase, if sustained, could have the same effect, particularly since the strong growth in the global economy means there is little spare capacity for the Opec oil cartel to raise production. The real doomsday scenario would be for Saudi Arabia - the world's biggest oil producers and the most dovish of the Opec members - to became embroiled in a wider middle east conflict.

What are the risks? The optimistic view is that dearer energy leads to the pricking of the US stock market bubble, thereby obviating the need for further increases in US interest rates. As a result the US economy slows gently from its recent breakneck speed and experiences a soft landing. For that to happen, peace efforts in the middle east would have to bear fruit relatively quickly.

A slightly darker view is that the tension is protracted, leading to a prolonged period of higher oil prices and continuing uncertainties in the financial markets.

The blackest outlook of all would be one where the conflict dragged in other countries, drove a wedge between the Saudis and the US and led not just to a fall in share prices but to a systemic crisis in the entire financial sector.

Regulators have already had a warning of what could happen. During the Russian debt crisis two years ago they were forced to rescue a high profile hedge fund - Long Term Capital Management - to prevent market meltdown.

Signs of distress are already evident. The spread between AAA-rated US corporate bonds and treasury paper - always a measure of investor nervousness - has widened and is close to the levels during the LTCM crisis.

If it does look like there is the possibility of real distress in the financial sector. US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan may be tempted to cut interest rates, as he has in the past, to prevent a 1930s style slump.

But he will not be able to do that if workers facing lower real incomes because of higher inflation demand higher wages. Central banks have already warned that they would respond to such an eventuality by raising interest rates rather than risk a return of the inflationary problems of the past. If the long-run response were dearer not cheaper money the global economy would not have a hard landing but a crash.

fields.headline: The Marriage of Figaro
fields.standfirst:
Britten Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Britten Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Although based in rural Cheshire, Clonter Opera has brought its production of Mozart's Marriage of Figaro to London's Britten Theatre, an intimate venue in the heart of the Royal College of Music. These performances represent a return to home ground for several of the principals who once studied here. In this performance, they used the theatre's warm acoustic to ensure that much of Amanda Holden's witty translation came over clearly and crisply. The orchestra comprised only 10 players; with single players on all the parts, the string players were performing as soloists lines intended for a blended body of musicians. In places the result was slightly ragged, but the orchestra played spiritedly, despite the slow tempos set by conductor Michael Rosewell.

Even so, the cast responded well to Rosewell, and there were good performances, including James Cleverton's Figaro and Michael Dewis's Count. Sally McHugh, as the Countess, rarely relaxed vocally or physically, but Marie Arnet was a polished and engaging Susanna.

There was strength, too, in the smaller roles, from tenor Robert Murray, in the dual role of Basilio and Don Curzio, and especially from Jonathan Lemalu, whose pit-stop costume changes allowed him to sing both Bartolo and Antonio. As the latter, his bumpkin-gardener accent travelled all over southern England; but as the former he grabbed the attention. The problems with this production were largely in its direction by Geoffrey Saunders: he tried too hard to provide an alternative staging. Having Basilio engineer the discovery of the hidden pageboy Cherubino, rather than have the Count pull the dustsheet away, unwittingly to reveal the boy, blunted the edge of a sharp visual joke.

fields.headline: Cardboard cut-outs at the Coliseum
fields.standfirst:
The Turk in Italy
London Coliseum
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Turk in Italy
London Coliseum
Rating: **
fields.body:
Let's begin on the bright side. The latest show in English National Opera's Italian season features some crisp and idiomatic conducting from David Parry, and a clutch of very decent vocal performances. Judith Howarth dominates the show with her neatly purled-coloratura and elegant phrasing, Thomas Allen (returning to the Coliseum after 12 years) demonstrates all his stage craft and there is fine support from Jeremy White, Donald Maxwell, Victoria Simmonds and Toby Spence. But their talents are squandered in this version of The Turk in Italy, which confronts the challenge of this most complex and elusive of Rossini's comic plots by turning the work into something quite different, in a way that often irritates.

The original scenario concerns a poet with creative block, Prosdocimo, who finds a subject for the play he must write by orchestrating the tangled relationships of the elderly Geronio and his younger wife, Fiorilla. She is already embroiled with the young Narciso when she falls for the Turk, Selim, who is also attracted to the nubile Zaide.

It all ends happily, of course, with Geronio and Fiorilla reconciled, but not before events have threatened to get out of the poet's control. In David Fielding's staging, Naples is transformed into Rome's Cinecitta studios at the height of Italian new wave cinema in 1961. Prosdocimo (Allen) becomes a film director, got up to look exactly like Marcello Mastroianni in Fellini's 8, who is stuck on a blockbuster movie, Fiorilla (Howarth) is his leading lady and Geronio (Maxwell) the producer, while Narciso (Spence) is a preening matinee idol and Selim (White) a Turkish film star imported to spice things up. In the end, Prosdocimo makes his movie and wins his Oscar.

To accommodate this conceit, the translator, Kit Hesketh Harvey, has had to play fast and loose with the text, in a way that goes for cheap laughs and self-conscious updatings. Meanwhile, Fielding's production, some of which looks nice enough in sets by Stefanos Lazaridis, squeezes credibility out of the characters.

This is not a show about real people, or even real people's pretensions. It seems concerned only with cartoon characters doing silly things; they give us no reason to care about them, so that the musical polish of the performances and the moments of genuine seriousness in Rossini's score count for nothing.

 Until November 18. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

webTitle: Deutsche spells out its plans for diversification

fields.headline: Deutsche spells out its plans for diversification
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Michael Philipp, the new head of asset management at Deutsche Bank, last night outlined a plan to diversify the business as part of an attempt to double assets under management within five years.
fields.body:
Michael Philipp, the new head of asset management at Deutsche Bank, last night outlined a plan to diversify the business as part of an attempt to double assets under management within five years.

In the first of three global "town hall" meetings with staff around the world, Mr Philipp emphasised the need to offer more alternative investment products such as venture capital and hedge funds and to expand in the American and Asian retail markets.

Deutsche, which bought Morgan Grenfell in the UK six years ago, already manages about£410bn of assets, making it one of the largest fund managers in the world. A report commissioned from McKinsey, the management consultants, earlier this year suggested that growth in the asset management business could lead to a trebling of net income and a doubling of assets within five years.

Mr Philipp, who was appointed to the asset management job in June, is one of two former Wall Street bankers appointed to the managing board of the bank this summer. In an interview with the Guardian, he said that while the asset management business was already extremely profitable, "we need to diversify by product and geography to have a really good business". The group has a strong retail presence in Germany and Italy and a good institutional business in the UK. Its US business largely consists of lower margin products.

Mr Philipp has already restructured the asset management division into similar reporting lines as those put in place in investment banking. A seven-strong management commitee has been set up along global/regional and product/sales lines.

The new structure will be explained to staff in London and Frankfurt next week. Headhunters have circled the UK division since Mr Philipp's appointment.

Mr Philipp helped negotiate the bank's acquisition of Natwest's derivatives business and its takeover of Bankers Trust two years ago and few believe that his dealmaking will go to waste in asset management.

He denied, however, that Deutsche needed to make a large acquisition. "Joint ventures and partnerships are going to be much more important going forward, everybody realises big deals don't always make sense," he said.

Industry analysts believe this could also give the group a breathing space to consolidate a fragmented asset management businsess.

fields.headline: Hi-tech twitch
fields.standfirst:
It is the dollar that has to be watched
Net news
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hard landing or soft? The value of new technology stocks twitched sharply this week; it was more like a spasm in the price of oil, as dealers hit the panic button after the events appraised above. On the hi-tech front, share movements may signal the start of much-needed realignment in the relationship between equities and commercial prospects.
fields.body:
Hard landing or soft? The value of new technology stocks twitched sharply this week; it was more like a spasm in the price of oil, as dealers hit the panic button after the events appraised above. On the hi-tech front, share movements may signal the start of much-needed realignment in the relationship between equities and commercial prospects. After spectacular movements on Wednesday, things calmed down yesterday, despite gloomy warnings from Motorola that worldwide growth in demand for mobile phones is now slowing.

Some people bathe in schadenfreude on such occasions. The possible liquidation of Boxman, set up three years ago to sell music and videos over the net, no doubt pleased those offended by the explosive growth in the perceived value of dot.com companies despite their lack of a track record in real (and often hotly competitive) markets. Boxman is unlikely to be the last collapse. According to a study last month, another 19 big start-ups are going to run out of cash before the end of the year. It is an irony that those who relish the pain of the Boos and the Boxmans are often most appreciative of how the "new economy" appears to have altered some fundamentals for the bet ter. Sushil Wadwhani's view, expressed yesterday, that the economy can be run at higher levels of demand without generating inflation relies on a positive appraisal of the internet's effects on competition. If he can persuade his colleagues on the Bank of England's interest setting committee and they stay their hand in the face of recent inflation figures, well and good. But one inference is that internet start-up companies are playing a sterling role in the process.

Broad-brush correction is much needed. American stocks are over- valued. Dot-commery needs the air let out. But of course everything depends on how readjustment is made. Wall Street valuations will affect the dollar, the hinge of the benign economic circumstances in which the American election is being fought. On the high dollar also depends the huge inflow of short and long-term capital into the United States, funding an extraordinary balance of payments deficit which in turn keeps the world economy ticking over nicely. Growth and employment in the euro zone win faint praise when compared to the US. But as Sir Samuel Brittan observes (we hope not too presciently), the American economy is "more precariously balanced".

fields.headline: Llama Farmers
fields.standfirst:
Manchester University
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Manchester University
Rating: **
fields.body:
Having previously supported the likes of Green Day and the Foo Fighters, the Llama Farmers found themselves in the unenviable position of going on stage before the Crocketts. Perhaps fearing an infection of mediocrity, the Llamas gave the impression of wanting to get it over with as quickly as possible and, as a result, they substituted an urgent thrash of guitars for their kooky pop songs.

Disappointingly, there was no room in their 30-minute set for the hippy dreaminess of their last single, Same Song, or for Movie. Instead, they settled for a big noise of discordant, duelling guitars over a vocal so low in the mix that, for the most part, frontman Bernie Simpson sounded as if he was singing from beneath several layers of blankets. And wet ones at that.

Still, they produced enough punkish energy to speed their way through the singles from last year's debut album, Dead Letter Chorus. There was the stop-start heaviness of Big Wheels, the wall-of-sound wail of Get the Keys and Go, and the Teenage-Fan-Club-melody-meets-the-Pixies bass of Always Echoes. Lacking definition, it tended to indie goulash for hungry pop-kids to wash down with their beer.

A graduate of the Damon Albarn school of boyish charm, Simpson did his best to look nonchalant, while his sister, Jenni, on bass and inaudible backing vocals, looked uncomfortable or perhaps just plain bored.

When the band played material from their soon to be released El Troppo album, nothing much changed. The title track was all scratchy riffs and big, echoey vocals fit for most indie backbeats, whereas Ear the C returned to the layers of guitars that have wrapped many a short-lived student anthem.

But the Llamas can offer much more than this, and it was left to the melodious breaks and sleep-walking rhythms of Snow White to reveal them at their fairy-tale best. Which only goes to show that you don't have to go all out and blast it if you can write a half-decent song.

fields.headline: War jitters lead to sell-off
fields.standfirst:
Stock shock Middle east violence drives shares down and fuel costs up
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Wall Street suffered a savage blow to its fragile confidence yesterday when fears of an all-out war in the middle east triggered panic selling of blue chip and technology stocks.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Wall Street suffered a savage blow to its fragile confidence yesterday when fears of an all-out war in the middle east triggered panic selling of blue chip and technology stocks.

In a market already alarmed by a growing number of profit warnings, the Dow Jones was down 350 points by lunchtime in New York and on the brink of falling below 10,000 for the first time since March.

Technology shares continued to fall, with the Nasdaq index dipping below its lowest point of the year with a fall of more than 70 points to 3020 at lunchtime.

The sell-off was caused by news of a terrorist attack on a US navy destroyer and an Israeli assault on Yasser Arafat's West Bank headquarters.

Violence in the middle east forced a rise of more than $3 in the oil price, increasing the risks of a hard landing for the world's biggest economy.

US share prices fell so sharply that they triggered trading curbs designed to slow markets in times of turmoil.

Following Wall Street's lead, the Euro Stoxx 50 index of euro zone blue chips tumbled 1% after being sharply higher earlier in the day, although it later pared losses and eventually registered small gains.

Investors in the London market also suffered a see-saw ride, with a gain of almost 100 points on the FTSE 100 index quickly erased by a fall of 143 to a five-month low of 6068.3.

The FTSE 100 later recovered to close up 14.3 points at 6131.9 but was vulnerable to further bad news, dealers said.

"It's teetering on the edge, the market desperately needs some good news and at the moment I don't know where it's going to find it," said one senior equity salesman.

Dealers said that only gains in defensive bank stocks and oil companies managed to keep the London market in positive territory.

At worst, dealers fear a full-blown war in the middle east would lead to a rerun of the 1973-74 oil crisis, which was followed by a global recession.

But some analysts sought to calm the mood by saying that the downturn in equity prices represented a healthy correction after a long period of excessive valuations.

"The world is not coming to an end," said Alan Skrainka, chief markets strategist at the investment house Edwards Jones.

G7 Group, the Washington-based firm of analysts, said investors hoping for a cut in US interest rates to ease the gloom in the markets were likely to be disappointed.

"Fed chairman Alan Greenspan is probably pretty comfortable with the market environment," the firm said. "After all, this past spring the Fed was looking for an orderly reversal of the Nasdaq bubble. And, despite the doom and gloom surrounding a possible market implosion, the bubble is deflating with relatively little collateral damage to the rest of the economy."

A profits warning by the US DIY retailer Home Depot reinforced fears that higher oil prices and the weak euro would lead to widespread earnings disappointment at the start of the quarterly results season. Financial services companies continued to be hit hard after a difficult week amid fears of trading losses.

fields.headline: Greta Scacchi upstaged by co-star
fields.standfirst:
The Guardsman
Albery Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Guardsman
Albery Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Ferenc Molnar's The Guardsman, a Budapest boulevard comedy written in 1911, now has the feeling of an extended anecdote. Dealing with the eroticism of disguise within marriage, it takes two-and-a-half hours to make its point. The problem is that Pinter's The Lover tackles the same theme, with far greater emotional complexity, in the space of 50 minutes.

To be fair, Molnar gives his story a faint piquancy by making his protagonists warring actors. After six months of marriage, the narcissistic Nandor feels the bloom has gone off his relationship with the intriguing Ilona. So, pretending to head off to the provinces, he returns in the guise of a dashing guardsman to seduce his wife. The more he looks like succeeding, the more he is driven into frenzied jealousy of his invented alter ego.

Audiences today are quick on the uptake: we guess the outcome a good hour before it arrives. Molnar was also, I suspect, trapped by the conventions of his time: were the disguised hero actually to sleep with his wife, as well as stretching probability it would lead to searing, morning-after recriminations. In the end, however, Molnar keeps everything on the level of a charade by ensuring that Nandor enjoys little more than stolen kisses and the prospect of an adulterous assignation; contrast Pinter, where consensual sex drives the husband into a nervous breakdown.

Played with the lightest of touches, the play survives precariously. But, although Frank Marcus's translation possesses strokes of wit, Janet Suzman's production has a romping heaviness. For a start Charles Cusick Smith's set, however archaeologically accurate in its reproduction of the geometric designs of the Wiener Werkstatt movement, is ludicrously cluttered: for once, you see the point of Coward's injunction not to bump into the furniture.

While Greta Scacchi is sinuously decorative and studiously posy as Ilona, she lacks the starry incandescence Maggie Smith and Diana Rigg brought to the role. The whole joke of the play is that Ilona is a greasepaint creature who has rather reluctantly, like Congreve's Millamant, dwindled into a wife. Michael Pennington is much funnier as Nandor, donning a wonderfully fake Viennese accent to go with his plumes and epaulettes and fuming with Othello-like rage.

But the two leads seem to come from different generations and, although there is decent support from Nickolas Grace as a suave critic and Georgina Hale as Ilona's lower-class protector, you miss Molnar's teasing ambivalence. You go into the theatre expecting chilled Tokay and end up with warm cider.

 Until November 25. Box office: 020-7369 1740.

fields.headline: Banks and tobacco in favour
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rising oil and bank shares helped cushion the slide in the London stock market yesterday as investors began to seek havens.
fields.body:
Rising oil and bank shares helped cushion the slide in the London stock market yesterday as investors began to seek havens.

The leap in crude oil prices gave oil companies a lift with Shell ending at 611p, up 13.5p, while BP Amoco finished at 646.5p, up 8.5p.

The biggest falls were in sectors vulnerable to the price of oil, such as transport, electricity and cars.

But analysts pointed out that some of the moves were still related to company news. Telecoms, for instance, ended broadly higher because of a rally which began before the extent of the crisis in the middle east emerged.

Typically defensive stocks found favour with nervous investors who pushed British American Tobacco towards the top of the leader board.

Banking stocks also ended the day in positive territory, fuelled in part by the decision by investors to start buying the shares again after a number of days of heavy losses. This sector injected a 15 point uplift to the FTSE 100 index, which eventually ended at 6,131, just 0.2% higher.

British Airways, highly dependent on the price of fuel, fell heavily but Khuram Chaudhry, pan-European stocks analyst at invest- ment bank Merrill Lynch, pointed out that the slide was probably exacerbated by the company's announcements about pulling out of unprofitable routes and other planned restructuring.

webTitle: TV sport chief leaves home over romance

fields.headline: TV sport chief leaves home over romance
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC said yesterday that it stood by its head of sport, Peter Salmon, who has left his family for actor Sarah Lancashire.
fields.body:
The BBC said yesterday that it stood by its head of sport, Peter Salmon, who has left his family for actor Sarah Lancashire.

Mr Salmon, the former controller of BBC1, has left his partner of 20 years and moved into a flat near their home in Oxford, in order to see his three children regularly.

The BBC said it was a personal matter for Mr Salmon, and stressed there was no suggestion of any impropriety. As controller of BBC1, Mr Salmon had no direct role in casting, a spokesman said. Ms Lancashire, a former Coronation Street star, has recently signed an exclusive deal with ITV. Mr Salmon, 44, recently moved out of the home he shared with Penny Watt and their three school-age children.

He is said to be "devoted" to his children, and will continue to see them. "He did not take the decision to move out lightly," said one friend. "He has done quite a few big jobs, and Penny has pursued her own career, and I think they just grew apart."

Ms Lancashire, 36, who has two children from a previous relationship, and lives in Cheshire, left Coronation Street in 1996. She secured a lucrative "golden handcuffs" deal with ITV this summer, ranking her alongside top TV stars such as David Jason.

fields.headline: Hysteria
fields.standfirst:
Minerva Theatre, Chichester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Minerva Theatre, Chichester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Terry Johnson's career has gone from the sublime to the ridiculous. Hysteria, a wildly original analytical farce about Sigmund Freud and infantile seduction that puts the analyst in the psychiatrist's chair, was one of the great Royal Court plays of the last decade. This century his major contribution to theatre has been to direct Jerry Hall in The Graduate.

What this revival of Hysteria shows is that it is possible to have fun in the theatre and at the same time be intellectally stimulating and emotionally touching. You can even do it with naked women. In Hysteria they keep coming out of the closet of the dying Freud's morphine-fuelled mind.

At least one does: Jessica, the daughter of one of Freud's female "hysterics", Rebecca S, whom he had treated and cured when he discovered that her mental illness was caused by having been orally raped by her father. But a year later, he abandoned his so-called seduction theory, arguing instead that the stories of abuse he had been told by so many women were not memories but fantasies.

In Johnson's mixture of fact and fiction, Freud's recantation has tragic consequences for both Rebecca and her daughter. But why did he retract? Was Freud attempting to save a career that looked as if it was about to be wrecked on the fury and indignation of Vienna's upright citizens, who didn't like being told that they had been routinely raping their daughters? Or did he have other motives, rather closer to home?

Johnson brilliantly mixes fact with fiction and there are good performances all round, but particularly by Guy Henry as Salvador Dali. However, Loveday Ingram's production never quite solves the design demands of the play or realises fully its potential for farce.

But this is a brilliant firework of a play, which reminds that even a hackneyed dramatic form such as farce can delve into our dream lives, and be intellectually teasing; and most importantly that therapy can only be as honest as its practitioners.

 Until October 28. Box office: 01214 3781312.

webTitle: Traders' panic sends oil prices skyward

fields.headline: Traders' panic sends oil prices skyward
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Panic stricken traders drove world oil prices to 10- year highs yesterday as the intensifying crisis in the middle east raised fears that a squeeze on global energy supplies could drive crude prices even higher.
fields.body:
Panic stricken traders drove world oil prices to 10- year highs yesterday as the intensifying crisis in the middle east raised fears that a squeeze on global energy supplies could drive crude prices even higher.

Brent crude broke through $35 a barrel for the first time since 1990, rising $3.51 to $35.30 before easing in late trading. US light crudes were $2.10 stronger at $35.35.

US heating oil prices broke 10-year records yesterday, hitting $1.11 a barrel, the highest level since 1979. Middle east tensions added to concerns that America may run out of heating oil over the winter.

The US department of energy reported yesterday that national heating oil stocks fell 1.3m barrels last week to 46.6m barrels, more than a third lower then a year ago.

One analyst warned that, with most big oil exporters already pumping at capac ity, any disruption to production could drive prices above $100 a barrel.

As news flashed up on dealing screens that Israeli helicopter gunships had fired at targets near Palestinian president Yasser Arafat's headquarters, one trader reported that panic buying had set in.

Traders fear a region that holds the bulk of the world's petroleum reserves could cut supply to the west at a time when booming world demand has already resulted in some of the highest energy prices since the invasion of Kuwait.

"If there was a serious threat to supplies you would be talking about oil at $100 a barrel," said Lawrence Eagles, a commodities analyst with GNL. "It's not like the Gulf War, which took out Iraq, but Saudi Arabia had 5m barrels a day of spare capacity. This time everybody is pumping oil flat out. If this went horribly wrong, the sky is the limit for oil prices."

"If there was a serious threat to supplies you would be talking about oil at $100 a barrel," said Lawrence Eagles, a commodities analyst with GNL. "It's not like the Gulf War, which took out Iraq, but Saudi Arabia had 5m barrels a day of spare capacity. This time everybody is pumping oil flat out. If this went horribly wrong, the sky is the limit for oil prices." webTitle: Why Wenger will stick to his Gunners

fields.headline: Why Wenger will stick to his Gunners
fields.trailText: With comments that apparently make further debate futile, Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger has already outlined why he would not take up the role of an international coach.
fields.body:
Banned from the touchline for 12 games and fined £100,000, Arsène Wenger yesterday had even the dubious consolation of the England coach's job ripped from his considerations by his club chairman.

"The FA can forget any thoughts they may have had about asking him to be the next England manager," the Arsenal chairman Peter Hill-Wood fumed. "The punishment is way over the top."

But a quick rummage in the collected quotes of the cerebral - but, says the FA, intimidating - Frenchman makes revealing reading. Back in 1998, after he had guided Arsenal to the Double, Wenger spelled out why he thought "you have to be a little bit of a masochist" to be a national coach.

He said: "What is the pleasure of being an international manager? You never see the players, and when you do have them you absolutely have to win.

"International football is behind club football because a club like Barcelona can buy the world's best players and so have a better team than Spain.

"Juventus's team is made of 11 internationals. They work every day together so they are bound to be stronger than an international team."

The simple truth of the matter, he judged, was: "If an international manager has a good generation of players, he does well. If he has a bad generation, he does not. Historically, when teams do well it is always because you have a super generation. In France, when Platini and other players emerged, we won the European Championship."

webTitle: Out of luck England hit rock bottom

fields.headline: Out of luck England hit rock bottom
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report

French referee no stranger to controversy

Wilkinson out of his depth
fields.trailText: David Lacey Bottom of the group after last night's poor passing, sloppy control, lack of invention, and errant refereeing - as poor starts go, this has to be the pits.
fields.body:
The chances of England qualifying for the 2002 World Cup in the Far East are still no more than a dim light on the dawn horizon. They are now two points behind Albania and Greece (Albania beat Greece 2-0 last night) at the bottom of their group. As poor starts go, this has to be the pits.

Yet at least England are on the scoreboard with a point obtained from last night's determined if inelegant performance in holding Finland to 0-0 here in the Olympic stadium. They are off the mark with football's equivalent of a scrambled leg-bye.

England survived because the Finns could not finish. At the same time Howard Wilkinson's irregulars came so close to snatching victory in a final act of the grandest larceny that they would almost have deserved to win through the sheer cheek of it.

With three minutes remaining Ray Parlour burst out of his shell of anonymity to dart and swerve his way through a Finnish defence which previously had proved about as negotiable as the Baltic in mid-winter. One moment he was faced by five opponents, the next he was past them all.

In goal Antti Niemi could only hope that Parlour suddenly remembered he was not Dennis Bergkamp. Whether he did or not, the Arsenal midfielder let fly from 15 yards but hit the underside of the bar. Television replays suggested the ball bounced down behind the goalline. The French linesman was well positioned to see the incident but declined to give the goal.

England would have been lucky victors but this would have been just the sort of luck they needed after Saturday's 1-0 defeat by Germany, Kevin Keegan's resignation and its moribund aftermath, with players dropping out of the squad like plague victims.

The makeshift team fielded by Wilkinson looked just that. England's caretaker coach was never going to see the quality of performance he craved and in the end, having boldly gone with three strikers, he was grateful to the defending of Martin Keown and Gareth Southgate that his plans did not go completely awry.

Of the three up front only Emile Heskey posed any kind of threat to Sami Hyypia and a solid Finnish defence. Teddy Sheringham and Andrew Cole failed to reproduce their successful partnership for Manchester United; Sheringham's passing was off and Cole's control could not have been worse had he been playing with a rugby ball. Why Wilkinson chose not to bring on Michael Owen, only Wilko knows.

Last night's result would have been satisfactory for England had they beaten Germany. As it is, by avoiding defeat, they have given themselves a marginally less fraught interlude before resuming the task of qualifying for 2002 with Finland's visit to Anfield on March 24.

Though the Finns were clearly delighted there must have been disappointment at not having exploited to the full those periods when the craft and guile of Jari Litmanen was predominant. At the start of the second half the combination of Litmanen's skills and the speed of Mikael Forssell, on loan to Crystal Palace, looked certain to bring them a goal. But England survived and when, later on, Forssell's touch let him down after a pass from the excellent Mika Nurmela had sent him clear, they must have suspected that the worst was over.

Initially England put their trust in a right feint and a left hook. That is to say Parlour was little more than a token attacking force on the right, and movements tended to concentrate on releasing Heskey, with his pace, power and aggression, on the left. It was not a bad plan. Heskey had several chances to break away, forcing corners and free-kicks which put Finland under sporadic pressure. After 24 minutes, from Dennis Wise's free-kick, Heskey nodded the ball down towards goal with Niemi out of position, but Hyypia cleared off the line.

Niemi had risked getting himself sent off in the sixth minute when he brought down Sheringham after the England striker had pounced on a fraught pass back from Petri Helin. Fortunately for the Hearts goalkeeper Helin had raced back to the goalmouth to cover him, otherwise Niemi would surely have seen a red card rather than the yellow.

There was nothing wrong in England's determination but again the midfield looked as if it had been recruited from the nearest bus queue and introduced to one another shortly before kick-off. Paul Scholes and Wise consistently found themselves turning into Simo Valakari or Jarkko Wiss. Valakari plays for Derby County, the Premiership's bottom club, and Wiss is an irregular for Stockport County.

Several times Litmanen came close to creating a goal before half-time, notably in the 35th minute when he sent Nurmela through for a low cross which Jonatan Johansson, goalside of Southgate, just failed to reach.

Finland dominated much of the second half and, had Parlour scored and England won, justice would hardly have been served. But in their present situation England would have settled last night for a bent judge and a nobbled jury.

 Albania opened their World Cup qualifying account and exacerbated England's woes as goals by Alban Bushi and Ervin Fakaj guided them to a 2-0 victory over Greece in Tirana last night. It was only Albania's second ever victory against Greece.

The Albanians were more aggressive at the start and Greece, missing five players through injury, found the home defence well-organised.

However, they wasted good scoring opportunities in the opening minutes, putting three headers over the bar.

More than 15,000 Albanian fans went wild when Fatmir Vata fed Bushi to give his team the lead in the 48th minute. Seconds before the final whistle Fakaj, headed in the second.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Wilkinson out of his depth
fields.standfirst: Caretaker coach threatens to return England to dark ages
fields.trailText: Stand-in Howard Wilkinson's woolly thinking runs the risk of returning England to the dark ages. Heaven help us should he become a permanent fixture, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
Howard Wilkinson had said that the first thought that crossed his mind when he was asked to become England's caretaker manager last weekend, apart, of course, from "yes, please", was that he had to bring back Teddy Sheringham as a central part of the masterplan for his country.

Sheringham duly responded to his call and all week on the training pitch he was a central plank in every piece of the team's organisational work. Yet after only 69 minutes in the Olympic stadium last night the electronic substitutions board lit up with the number 10 and Sheringham's brief comeback to international football was over. And Wilkinson was back to the drawing board, a familiar position for all England's coaches, though not normally after 69 minutes of their first game.

At first Sheringham seemed unwilling to believe his fate, pointing to his chest to confirm that it was not a case of mistaken identity and that he was indeed being told to leave the stage. Wilkinson, after admitting that Sheringham was not best pleased, said: "I did it very, very reluctantly but I didn't think we were getting the ball to our front two and Teddy wasn't getting the service he thrives on."

Nothing could have better summed up the woolly thinking of Wilkinson, who sent out a team so lacking in midfield skills and balance that Kevin Keegan might have picked it. And it was obvious to everyone who witnessed England's dreadful performance that, if he throws his hat into the ring for the coach's job, the Football Association's chief executive Adam Crozier should toss it straight out again.

Wilkinson, who is one of the six men who will have Crozier's ear as he attempts to find Keegan's replacement, was noncommittal about his candidature afterwards, saying that all parties had agreed not to comment until they returned to England.

A Wilkinson appointment, however, would be an affront to those who want to see the English game moved forward. Judging from his team selection and their performance last night, he would return it to the dark ages.

Even when it was obvious that Andy Cole and Emile Heskey were struggling up front, Wilkinson refused to send on Michael Owen, bizarrely claiming that he did not do so because he knew Heskey was suffering from a back problem. Wilkinson presumably meant that he did not want to replace Cole with Owen and then lose Heskey. But surely it would have made sense to replace the latter with Owen.

As England laboured through admittedly atrocious conditions, a swirling wind and a pitch that looked as though it had recently hosted the Horse of the Year show, Wilkinson's main concern was not the inadequacy of his players but those of a Finnish ball boy. Twice, he left his touchline seat to berate the unfortunate youngster for not returning the ball to play more quickly, though England's players did little enough with it when they got it.

Wilkinson had also said before the match that of all the thousands of excuses that the players might grasp following a poor performance, none would be acceptable. Then, in the minutes after the game, he scattered excuses like verbal confetti, blaming everything from a Finnish summer which made the pitch too hard, the wind, the Finnish style of play, the angst over Keegan's departure and the referee's failure to send off Finland's goalkeeper Antti Niemi for a professional foul on Sheringham and to spot that Ray Parlour's shot had crossed the goalline.

Wilkinson could not be sure whether he was pleased or not, first suggesting that a draw was two points lost and then saying: "If you put it in a club context, if you take over as manager of a side at the bottom of the league which hadn't won a game, you would be quite happy with a draw away."

Few club managers would have been happy with the standard of England's play. The only thing that might have given the night an optimistic finish was if the aptly named Wilkinson had followed Keegan's splendid example and fallen on his sword.

fields.headline: Kinsella sparks Irish power play
fields.standfirst: Kinsella 25, Dunne 50
fields.trailText: The Republic of Ireland maintained momentum and bolstered their hopes of qualifying from a difficult group courtesy of goals from Mark Kinsella and Roy Keane.
fields.body:
After a pre-match power failure the Republic of Ireland lit up Lansdowne Road last night with another performance brimming with their new-found sense of adventure.

Estonia may not make the most daunting of opposition but the Irish, inspired by Kevin Kilbane's best performance for his country plus the prodigious work-rate of Mark Kinsella and Roy Keane at his snarling best, were more than impressive all the same.

Holding Portugal and Holland to away draws had bolstered Irish hopes of qualifying from this tough group or, at the very least, remaining in touch with the two Euro 2000 semi-finalists until they visit Dublin next year.

Having elevated themselves to new heights, the question last night was whether the Irish could keep the momentum going against one of the Continent's weaker nations or fall flat on their faces.

It was not the brightest of starts. As both teams warmed up and the first spectators lapped up England's failure to beat Finland, the lights went out. In almost complete darkness the players perversely attempted to carry on before finally giving up and skulking back down the tunnel. Even in the dark it was just about possible to make out the red faces.

Normal service was resumed within 15 minutes and the first half quickly settled into a predictable pattern of incessant Irish pressure with Estonia looking for scraps on the counter-attack.

One breakaway came too close for comfort with the Irish goalkeeper Alan Kelly called upon to keep out Indrek Zelinski's shot but within seconds the Irish went ahead on 25 minutes courtesy of Mark Kinsella's first goal for his country.

There did not seem much on when Ian Harte lofted a hopeful punt into the penalty area but Niall Quinn's lay-off invited the shot from Kinsella and his low right-foot drive had the power and accuracy to beat Estonia's Derby goalkeeper Mart Poom.

If the home manager Mick McCarthy harboured any lingering fears that his team were due a poor show, they were being swiftly dispelled. The likes of Quinn, Kinsella and Roy Keane could never be accused of complacency and, at times, the quality of their neat and composed football threatened to swamp their opponents.

Estonia have blossomed in recent years but here they wilted under the pressure and the scoreline was given a more realistic look five minutes into a one-sided second half.

Harte whipped in a corner from the left and the ball was hooked on by Quinn for Richard Dunne - or Honey Monster, as he is known by his team mates - to smash in a stinging shot at the far post.

There could and should have been more - but nobody was complaining here last night.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2):Kelly; Carr, Dunne, Breen, Harte; McAteer (Duff, h-t), Kinsella, Roy Keane, Kilbane (Foley, 88min); Quinn, Robbie Keane (Finnan, 88).

Estonia (4-4-2): Poom; Allas, Stepanov, Lamslau, Saviauk; Viikmae (Haaviste, 69min), Anniste, Reim, Terekhov; Oper, Zelinski (Ustritski, 69).

Referee: T Hauge (Norway).

fields.headline: Brown banished as Scots rebound
fields.standfirst: Boksic 15 | Gallacher 24
fields.trailText: Kevin Gallacher earned Scotland a valuable point last night after Alen Boksic had earlier given a somewhat schizophrenic Croatia the lead.
fields.body:
Scotland stole a precious World Cup point in the Maksimir stadium last night and might even have filched a victory had a Don Hutchison shot in the 70th minute not fizzed wide of a post.

It was a bleak night, though, in other ways for Craig Brown. In comical fashion, the Scottish coach was sent to the stand by Gilles Veissière, the French referee, after an untypical outburst. A chastened Brown headed for the cheap seats where he spent the second half chatting to local pressmen.

The game had a frenetic edge but for the Scotland camp this was still a gloomy occasion. The dreadful news earlier in the day of the death of the country's first minister, Donald Dewar, created a pall and even a suggestion that the game should have been called off. The Scottish players wore black armbands and observed a minute's silence, while the 2,000-strong Tartan Army for once hardly raised a chorus.

With Alen Boksic and Robert Prosinecki showing their class, the game was lively enough, though Croatia are clearly a fitful lot. The way they breezed into the lead was an intoxicating sight, but they were equally as shoddy when they allowed the Scots back into the match.

Boksic struck a beautiful goal during an opening period in which the Scots were turned dizzy. Zvonimir Soldo's raking pass arrowed through the Scottish defence, spinning Matt Elliott through 360 degrees and leaving Boksic to bear through on goal. The striker's control and finish were perfection: killing the pace of the pass, nudging the ball to his right foot and belting it past Neil Sullivan. The Croats had already peppered the Scots' goal with efforts before, somewhat miraculously, the visitors contrived an equaliser. Colin Hendry appealed for a penalty after being hauled down just outside the area and, within the same 24th minute, Colin Cameron's low cross was met by Kevin Gallacher, who stabbed it home from seven yards. Nine goals in 51 appearances for Gallacher - not the stuff of a predator but it was timely all the same.

The match proceeded via the sublime and the ridiculous. Prosinecki remains wonderfully gifted, drifting here and there and scattering his passes around. In the 59th minute he blasted in a shot, apparently without swinging a leg, which smashed against Sullivan's post.

Then followed Brown's ignominy. The man widely held to be the most courteous manager in Europe was sent to the stand by the stroppy Veissière, following the coach's angry reaction to a foul given against Paul Dickov. The Manchester City striker had been in the process of being strangled from behind by Robert Kovac, lending Brown's fury a certain justification.

Croatia (3-5-2): Pavlovic; R Kovac, Stimac, Simic; Saric, N Kovac, Soldo (Biscan, h-t), Prosinecki, Jarni (Zivkovic, h-t); Balaban, Boksic (Vugrinec, 76).

Scotland (3-5-2): Sullivan; Hendry, Elliott, Weir; Boyd, Hutchsion, Burley, Cameron, Naysmith; Johnston (Dickov, h-t; Holt, 90), Gallacher.

Referee : G Veissiere (France).

A chastened Brown headed for the cheap seats where he spent the second half chatting to local pressmen. The game had a frenetic edge but for the Scotland camp this was still a gloomy occasion. The dreadful news earlier in the day of the death of the country's first minister, Donald Dewar, created a pall and even a suggestion that the game should have been called off. The Scottish players wore black armbands and observed a minute's silence, while the 2,000-strong Tartan Army for once hardly raised a chorus. With Alen Boksic and Robert Prosinecki showing their class, the game was lively enough, though Croatia are clearly a fitful lot. The way they breezed into the lead was an intoxicating sight, but they were equally as shoddy when they allowed the Scots back into the match. Boksic struck a beautiful goal during an opening period in which the Scots were turned dizzy. Zvonimir Soldo's raking pass arrowed through the Scottish defence, spinning Matt Elliott through 360 degrees and leaving Boksic to bear through on goal. The striker's control and finish were perfection: killing the pace of the pass, nudging the ball to his right foot and belting it past Neil Sullivan. The Croats had already peppered the Scots' goal with efforts before, somewhat miraculously, the visitors contrived an equaliser. Colin Hendry appealed for a penalty after being hauled down just outside the area and, within the same 24th minute, Colin Cameron's low cross was met by Kevin Gallacher, who stabbed it home from seven yards. Nine goals in 51 appearances for Gallacher - not the stuff of a predator but it was timely all the same. The match proceeded via the sublime and the ridiculous. Prosinecki remains wonderfully gifted, drifting here and there and scattering his passes around. In the 59th minute he blasted in a shot, apparently without swinging a leg, which smashed against Sullivan's post. Then followed Brown's ignominy. The man widely held to be the most courteous manager in Europe was sent to the stand by the stroppy Veissière, following the coach's angry reaction to a foul given against Paul Dickov. The Manchester City striker had been in the process of being strangled from behind by Robert Kovac, lending Brown's fury a certain justification. Scotland (3-5-2): Sullivan; Hendry, Elliott, Weir; Boyd, Hutchsion, Burley, Cameron, Naysmith; Johnston (Dickov, h-t; Holt, 90), Gallacher. fields.headline: Battling Wales cling to lifeline
fields.trailText: Wales ignored the smoke bombs and fanatical local support to gain a valuable point and end Poland's 100% record at the Legia Stadium in Warsaw.
fields.body:
The smoke bombs billowed around the Legia Stadium and the fanatical Tannoy announcer roared for his countrymen throughout, but Wales produced a magnificent performance to gain a valuable point here last night.

If they had lost, then Mark Hughes' side would have been virtually out of contention in their World Cup qualifying group but, with the support of around 200 fans, defended with sufficient heart and strength to end Poland's 100% record.

Andy Melville, Chris Coleman and Robert Page were outstanding at the back while in midfield the captain Gary Speed, alongside John Robinson and Robbie Savage, ran themselves into the ground. Ryan Giggs was a constant threat with his clever, controlled running.

Wales, who started with the same XI that drew with Norway on Saturday, unashamedly set themselves for a cagey, defensive game, looking to slow the match down and keep possession by spinning the ball around between their defenders as much as possible.

In the first half the ploy worked, Poland, despite dominating possession, running up against the brick wall of the Welsh defence. Indeed Wales could have been ahead after just 30 seconds. Mark Delaney's ball down the left put John Hartson clear, but he was unable to make the most of the chance.

A minute later Giggs' crossfield run set up Nathan Blake, who cut in from the right to drill a low shot that the Polish keeper Jerzy Dudek held low.

But Poland slowly gained a measure of control in midfield, and their first effort came on nine minutes when Bartosz Karwan's pass put Radoslaw Gilewicz in on the right, but he mishit his shot from 12 yards. Radoslaw Kaluzny missed Poland's best chance of the half when his header from eight yards dropped wide.

After 50 minutes Hartson's flick-on presented Speed with a shooting chance, but his drive flew high over. Hartson was booked two minutes later and from the resulting free-kick Paul Jones had to be alert.

The first attempt, taken quickly, sailed into the keeper's hands, but the referee called the Poles back and allowed them a second go, this time a 25-yarder from Michal Zewlakov dipped inches over the top.

Poland should have scored when Andrzei Juskowiak drove over from Piotr Swierczewski's cross, and it was the Wolfsburg forward's last involvement, as he was hauled off, along with Jacek Krzynowek as the Poles began to get desperate.

Wales took off Hartson and bolstered the midfield with Matthew Jones and hung on grimly, as Poland slunk away after the final whistle, knowing that their own hopes of a massive lead had gone up in smoke.

Poland: Dudek: Klos, Zielinski, Zewlakow, Waldoch, Krzynowek (Rzasa, 70min), Swierczewski, Karwan, Juskowiak (Emmanuel Olisadebe, 75), Kaluzny, Gilewicz (Kryszalowicz, 56).

Wales: P Jones; Delaney, Page, Melville, Coleman, Savage, Robinson, Hartson (M Jones, 76), Blake, Speed, Giggs.

Referee: L Batista (Portugal).

webTitle: Ehiogu close to sealing Boro move

fields.headline: Ehiogu close to sealing Boro move
fields.trailText: The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson is set to splash out £8m on Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu.
fields.body:
The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson is expected to revert to his tried and trusted policy of throwing money at a problem by investing £8m on the Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu.

After several weeks of negotiation, the centre-back is poised to become the most expensive player in the Teesside club's history, superseding Fabrizio Ravanelli who cost £7m when he moved to the north-east in 1996.

Ehiogu, 27, has decided that if he is to realise his dream of winning full international honours he must sever his ties with Villa, nine years after he arrived from West Bromwich Albion for a nominal fee.

He is expected to begin discussing personal terms in the next 24 hours and, barring any 11th-hour problems, is likely to make his debut in Monday night's Tees-Tyne derby at the Riverside stadium.

West Brom, who had been entitled to 50% of any fee for Ehiogu, will receive about £2m from the deal. They reached a settlement with Villa to accept £1.25m and 10% of any fee after Villa threatened to refuse to sell him.

Robson will use the £5.5m collected from the sale of Christian Ziege to Liverpool to fund the deal, and his chairman Steve Gibson is believed ready to sanction at least two more deals before Christmas.

David Beckham saw a specialist yesterday about the knee ligament damage that forced him out of England's game in Finland but the Manchester United midfielder has been told there is no need for an operation and hopes to face Leicester City on Saturday.

Portsmouth's manager Tony Pulis last night lost his job 24 hours after receiving "the full support" of his chairman Milan Mandaric. Pulis, who has spent almost £4m since taking charge 10 months ago, has overseen only three wins in 15 matches this season.

"I am not enjoying myself coming all the way from my home in Florida to places like Stockport and seeing us lucky to draw," Mandaric said.

The striker Steve Claridge and coach Dave Kemp are favourites to take charge while Mandaric searches for a permanent successor.

Forfar's Dave Bowman has been given a seven-match ban after he received four red cards during his side's 5-3 defeat by Berwick Rangers on Saturday. The midfielder was sent off for two cautions and subsequently reported for foul and abusive language on three separate occasions.

fields.headline: Man-to-man marking
fields.standfirst: How the players rated
fields.trailText: How the players rated on the night.
fields.body:
David Seaman 7/10

Confident display after his Wembley blunder. Crucial intervention on 73 minutes rushing off his line to deny Finland's best attack, and few problems throughout.

Phil Neville 6/10

Adequate but no more. Switched flanks in second half after Barry's substitution. Largely ineffective as an attacking force.

Martin Keown 6/10

Solid and dependable when it mattered in defence. Showed commitment to suggest that a long-term captaincy appointment might be no bad thing.

Gareth Southgate 7/10

After ludicrous midfield selection against Germany, happy to be back in defence with some telling contributions when moving forward to join attack at set pieces.

Gareth Barry 5/10

Hugely disappointing. Missed a tremendous opportunity to oust Le Saux as the No1 left-back selection. Rightly substituted when the time came to look for more options.

Dennis Wise 5/10

Useful first half, linking intelligently with Sheringham, but looked lost when the Man United targetman was taken off in the second half.

Ray Parlour 5/10

Largely ineffective throughout until the moment when his long-range shot, after a powerful run, hit the crossbar, bounced down over the line and was ruled as no goal. Oh for 1966.

Paul Scholes 5/10

Hugely disappointing. Much energy and commitment but little constructive without his pal Beckham alongside him.

Emile Heskey 6/10

Decent first half when opportunities arose to attack down the left flank, but little in way of scoring opportunities and utterly anonymous after the interval.

Andrew Cole 6/10

Struggled manfully with little support from those behind him, particularly after Sheringham's substitution, and ended his 11th England appearance without a goal. When is it Kevin Phillips's turn?

Teddy Sheringham 7/10

Made effortless transition back to international standard after 16 months. Despite his substitution England's best attacking force by some distance; a shame Howard Wilkinson failed to see it.

Substitutes

Steve McManaman 6/10

For a man who is getting no first-team football with Real Madrid, a decent contribution which suggested it should have come earlier.

Wes Brown 6/10

No problem slotting into the right-back berth after Barry's second-half substitution.

webTitle: French referee at centre of storm is no stranger to controversy

fields.headline: French referee at centre of storm is no stranger to controversy
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Alain Sars, the referee who last night failed to award Ray Parlour a crucial 86th-minute goal, is no stranger to controversy, as Roy Collins reports.
fields.body:
Alain Sars, the referee who last night failed to award Ray Parlour a crucial 86th-minute goal or send off the Finnish goalkeeper for bringing down Teddy Sheringham outside his area and handling the ball, is no stranger to controversy.

In April he was in charge of one of the most explosive matches in French history, when a brawl in the tunnel and the sending-off of three players marred Marseille's 4-2 win over Monaco.

Sars is no more popular among the fans of St Etienne and Toulouse. During a match in August he did not spot the use of a hand by St Etienne's Brazilian Aloisio, and was described as "scandalous" by St Etienne's coach when he failed to protect the striker from the retaliatory hacks of the Toulouse players.

The man likely to become as infamous as that 1966 Russian linesman was also criticised by Stockholm last season when he allowed Barcelona to score an 86th-minute equaliser in their Champions League match while the Swedish team were in the process of making a substitution and had only 10 players on the pitch.

Parlour said last night that seeing the video proof that his shot did cross the Finnish line had only added to England's frustration. "The ball had got stuck under my foot at first and I really had to dig it out and the wind took it even higher," he said.

"As it came down off the bar, I was sure it crossed the line and I was very disappointed it wasn't given. It would have been my first goal for England."

More vitally, of course, it would have given England three qualifying points after their dismal start against Germany on Saturday. But Parlour warned: "Don't write us off yet. This was a disappointing result but the conditions were terrible.

"The pitch was awful and the wind made it very difficult. But after all the problems the lads gave it their best, and there is still a long way to go."

Howard Wilkinson, England's caretaker coach, felt the team were robbed by Sars' failure to send off the goalkeeper Antti Niemi after five minutes. He said: "My first thought was that it was a penalty and my second that it was a definite red card. But we didn't get either.

"It has been a difficult week for everyone but there is not the confidence, belief or faith that there should be among the players. That won't come until we achieve some long-term planning and give the team a chance to perform."

This seemed a coded message that Wilkinson intends to throw his hat into the ring for the England manager's job, though he refused to confirm that.

The Finland manager Antti Muurinen, meanwhile, was silent on the possible sending-off of his goalkeeper. But he said of the Parlour effort: "You managed to get a goal like that in the 1966 World Cup final. So perhaps that is enough for you guys."

webTitle: NHS insider to oversee changes after trawl of private sector

fields.headline: NHS insider to oversee changes after trawl of private sector
fields.standfirst: London NHS boss gets NHS top job
fields.trailText: A sigh of relief spread across the NHS when the government appointed an internal candidate to head the service, instead of bringing in a captain of industry, as Tony Blair originally intended.
fields.byline: John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
A sigh of relief spread across the NHS yesterday when the government appointed an internal candidate to head the service, instead of bringing in a captain of industry, as Tony Blair originally intended.

Nigel Crisp, regional NHS director for London, will take over as NHS chief executive and permanent secretary at the Department of Health on November 1.

The job was billed as the most powerful and challenging public sector appointment in Europe, with a £50bn budget and 1m staff. It will combine the roles of head of NHS management and civil service mandarin responsible for co-ordinating policy advice on health and social care.

The prime minister ordered an open competition for the post, and headhunters trawled the private sector for candidates. Alan Milburn, health secretary, said the government would pay whatever was necessary to attract the best - if need be, a lot more than the £140,000 paid to Sir Richard Wilson, cabinet secretary.

Senior health service managers speculated yesterday that Mr Milburn abandoned an attempt to recruit the head of a hotel chain or other consumer oriented company after realising the dangers of excessive managerial upheaval in the early stages of implementing the government's NHS changes. But sources close to Mr Milburn said he was not involved in a selection process conducted by independent civil service commissioners, with advice from Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians.

Mr Crisp, 48, was appointed London regional director of the NHS executive in 1999 and oversaw the merger of the two regions that had operated in the capital. His handling of pressures on the health service last winter and quick building of relationships with Ken Livingstone, the incoming mayor, attracted favourable attention.

Mr Milburn said: "Nigel Crisp will be a superb manager for the NHS and the Department of Health, having worked in both the public and private sectors and in urban and rural areas. He can bring to this job frontline experience of making change happen."

Mr Crisp said: "For far too long the NHS has just been surviving ... Now we are at a point of turning a corner. We have got a clear direction, we have got national standards, we have got investment - we have to turn that into improvement for patients."

He intended to have a far higher public profile than his predecessors and to talk more to staff, patients and the media.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, said: "This appointment proves that the most able NHS managers stand comparison with the best top private and public sector management."

Mr Crisp, a Cambridge graduate, spent five years as a community worker in Liverpool before working in industry and the voluntary sector. He joined the NHS in 1986 as general manager at the East Berkshire mental handicap unit.

He became the first chief executive of the Oxford Radcliffe hospital NHS trust and in 1997 was made South Thames regional director for the NHS executive.
