webTitle: Another shot at 'the shot heard around the world'

fields.headline: Another shot at 'the shot heard around the world'
fields.standfirst: New York is beside itself in anticipation of the subway series, the keenly desired and never-before seen meeting of the city's two baseball teams in the World Series. Michael Ellison steps up to the plate for a look at the hype, the rivalry and the navel-gazing
fields.trailText: New York is beside itself in anticipation of the subway series, the keenly desired and never-before seen meeting of the city's two baseball teams in the World Series. Michael Ellison steps up to the plate for a look at the hype, the rivalry and the navel-gazing
fields.body:
New Yorkers are paying rapt attention to the closest race in years: it leads every television news bulletin; the newspapers vie to outdo each other with special pullout sections; straphangers on the subway uncurl their lips and actually talk to strangers about it.

No, they are not consumed with anxiety about the identity of the next occupant of the White House. Even CNN, which loves nothing more than to worry a story to death over a prolonged period, could bring itself to do no better than this recommendation before the second presidential debate: "Gore pledges to get facts straight, refrain from sighing."

Nor is Hillary Clinton's bid to represent the state of New York in the Senate the force transcending daily lives that often do not extend beyond the humdrum, even in "the capital of the world." She's been campaigning for nearly 16 months now and the grudging realisation that she's going to make it has taken hold.

Rather, the city is beside itself in anticipation of yet another event that would confirm it - at least in the minds of its inhabitants - as a place unmatched in the country, certainly, and the world.

This is the subway series, the keenly desired and never-before seen meeting of New York's two baseball teams in the World Series, the best-of-seven that climaxes a season that started last April. It's called the subway series because all the games can be reached without resort to any mode of transport other than an underground train.

Never mind that it is requires negotiating a tortuous route to make your way between Yankee Stadium in The Bronx and Shea Stadium in Queens, the point is that it's an all-New York affair, with no interlopers from elsewhere in the United States.

The Yankees and the Mets are each just one step away from making it happen and, if they do, there will have been nothing like it since the Yankees met the lamented Brooklyn Dodgers in 1956. So affected by the experience were the Dodgers' owners that they moved the franchise to Los Angeles in 1958.

None of this might seem to matter very much, and indeed it does not anywhere but in the city. In commercial terms alone it would be a disaster for television as sets across the nation would be switched off as New York turned in upon itself.

What those viewers would be missing is a soap opera far more engaging than what they might watch instead of the games. The Yankees are the Manchester United of baseball, the most-loved and hated club in the game, the richest - this year their playing staff's combined salary is $112m - and the most successful. They have won the World Series in three of the last four years.

The Mets are not exactly hard-up, except in the coin of achievement. New York's perennial also-rans, their image that of the blue-collar underdog, they have not won the series since 1986. The Mets - otherwise known as the Amazin' Mets - have as their ace pitcher Al Leiter, who looks like he might have come to mow the lawn.

Bobby Jones, whose pitching got them this far, was sent to ply his trade in the ignominy of the minor leagues as recently as last June; and yet another pitcher, the reliever Turk Wendell wears a necklace made of the teeth of animals he has killed. They have a little glamour, too, in Mike Piazza, by common consent the best hitting catcher the game has ever seen, who earns $12m a year, cultivates complicated facial hair and has a Playboy centrefold for a girlfriend. Bobby Valentine, the manager, rules with all the emotional stability of a supermodel with a broken toenail and told a group of business students in an off-the-record lecture - it was on the internet a few minutes later - that the club had lumbered him with a surfeit of overpaid under-performers.

But this is nothing compared to the Yankees. Their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, is a convicted felon; manager Joe Torre presents to the world a look so grim that he would surely commit suicide were he not too depressed to make the trip to the top of the Empire State Building.

David Justice was once married to the actress Halle Berry; Jose Canseco, so heavily built that he might be able to take on the entire membership of the Teamsters' Union single-handedly, used to go out with Madonna; Derek Jeter, the Yankees' golden boy, was Mariah Carey's boyfriend.

Jeter, who has a black father and a white mother and therefore epitomises how New York would like to be seen, might be considered a star analogous to David Beckham, except for the fact that he is quite intelligent and appears to have no talent for petulance.

The Yankees' ace pitcher, Roger Clemens, has become so distracted that he refers to himself by his tabloid sobriquet, The Rocket, though this will not prevent him from earning $15m next year. The Cuban defector Orlando "El Duque" Hernandez barely speaks any English and no one really knows what age he is (the best guess is: older than he admits).

But the Yankee award for unintentional entertainment is held by second baseman Chuck Knoblauch, a golden glove holder - meaning he is very good in the field - before he reached New York. Now, despite his name, he could not throw the ball straight if you paid him about $8m a year, which they do.

Knoblauch's finest moment came in the summer when he swooped on a ball and hurled it yards wide of its intended target, into the crowd and the face of the aged mother of a Fox Sports commentator. This occasioned an impenetrable piece on the front page of the New York Times, comparing him - for some reason - to Tolstoy.

No one has done this yet to Al Gore or George W Bush, irrespective of their assaults on likeability or the English language. But just as Bush has been trained to say "fuzzy math" any time Gore talks about something that is beyond the Texas governor, the ageing Yankees have been playing fuzzy baseball since the beginning of last month.

Chances are that the Mets will implode or the Yankees will expire - or both - depriving New York of that much-prized subway series until it all starts up again next year.

fields.headline: Postcode lottery hits heart patient
fields.standfirst: Care lottery is a matter of life and death
fields.trailText: A man who will die without laser heart surgery has been told that his health authority will not pay for the treatment, revealing a new dimension to the postcode lottery in the NHS in which healthcare depends on where patients live.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
A man who will die without laser heart surgery has been told that his health authority will not pay for the treatment, revealing a new dimension to the postcode lottery in the NHS in which healthcare depends on where patients live.

Philip Salthouse, 58, from Preston, Lancashire, has suffered several heart attacks and had a coronary bypass operation that failed.

He now spends his life being constantly transferred between hospital and his bed at home. He is on heavy doses of morphine for his pain.

The only hope for him, according to his GP, Christopher Rossall, is a laser procedure - new to the UK but widespread in the United States - which could open up the blocked arteries of his heart.

"It would make a vast difference," said Dr Rossall. "It would give him a 30% improvement in exercise and reduction in pain. Laser treatment is done routinely in London, but our health authority won't pay for it."

Mr Salthouse's wife, Kathleen, has pursued every avenue to secure the treatment for her husband since a consultant told them about it last year.

When they approached St Thomas's hospital in London, one of two places where the technique is being used, they were advised that Mr Salthouse was eminently suitable for the procedure.

He was offered a bed at St Thomas's, but on July 3 the couple received a letter from the hospital saying that the consultant had been in correspondance with the acting director of public health at the North West Lancashire health authority, Anthony Suddell.

"I regret to say that he is not able to authorise funding for your procedure at St Thomas's hospital," the letter said.

Mrs Salthouse wrote to Nigel Evans, Conservative MP for Ribble Valley, who took up the case with the junior health minister, Lord Hunt.

"I can assure you that Mr Salthouse is not being denied treatment because of lack of funding but simply because there are no other clinical options available," Lord Hunt replied.

That, in Mrs Salthouse's view, is not the case. "We know that they have been doing this procedure in London for over a year," she said. "On the internet there is loads of information about it."

While the health authority would not discuss individual cases, it denied that patients would be refused life saving surgery on grounds of cost. "We regard this as an experimental treatment," said Dr Suddell.

A trial on the effectiveness and safety of the laser surgery technique, percutaneous myocardial revascularisation, had just finished at Papworth hospital in Cambridgeshire - Mr Salthouse was too late to get a place on it - but the results were not yet published, he said.

"As soon as it is published we will look at it carefully and determine how the results of that publication affect our policy. It may be if it proves an effective treatment that we will want to commission it, or maybe it will need further research."

The authority said it considered each case on its merits.

"We sometimes find ourselves in a situation - and it is a difficult situation - where elsewhere the treatment has started without the evidence of effectiveness being available."

Meanwhile, Mr Salthouse knows that time is slipping by. "It's upsetting," he said. "It's getting me down.

"I'm getting worse. We can't get out, and I can't go for walks with the grandchildren. I have got no quality of life or anything."

webTitle: Portuguese humble Dutch at the double

fields.headline: Portuguese humble Dutch at the double
fields.standfirst: Conceicao 10, Pauleta 43
fields.trailText: Portugal top Group Two after they outplayed Holland to win 2-0 in Rotterdam.
fields.body:
Pedro Resendes, better known as Pauleta, contributed a goal and an assist as a dominant Portugal outplayed Holland to win 2-0 here last night.

The win takes the Portuguese, who were held to a 1-1 draw at home by the Republic of Ireland on Saturday, to the top of the group with seven points from three games while the Dutch drop to fourth on four points.

Sergio Conceicao seized on Pauleta's measured through- ball deep into the Dutch penalty area in the 10th minute, took two touches to control it and beat Edwin van der Sar with a clinical left-foot finish. The chance arose after several Dutch players hesitated on hearing a whistle from the crowd.

Pauleta hit the second himself on 44 minutes, picking up Michael Reiziger's give-away square pass and nonchalantly evading challenges from Frank de Boer and Philip Cocu before burying the ball just inside the right post.

The Dutch enjoyed their customary domination of possession in the first half but only Patrick Kluivert looked sharp enough to threaten, turning once on the edge of the box to test Quim and sending a near-post header just wide from Reiziger's cross.

Holland : Van der Sar; Melchiot, F de Boer, Cocu, Reiziger, Van Bommel, Overmars, Davids, Kluivert, Seedorf, Bouma.

Portugal : Quim; Jorge Costa, Dimas, Secretario, Couto, Vidigal, Luis Figo, Bino, Pauleta, Rui Costa, Conceicao.

webTitle: Smith calls for ceasefire in lottery bid warfare

fields.headline: Smith calls for ceasefire in lottery bid warfare
fields.trailText: The embattled culture secretary, Chris Smith, called on the companies bidding to run the national lottery to end their increasingly bitter public wrangling.
fields.body:
The embattled culture secretary, Chris Smith, yesterday called on the companies bidding to run the national lottery to end their increasingly bitter public wrangling.

Mr Smith, who has received calls for his resignation over the mishandling of the bid process, said it was time to call a ceasefire and engage in constructive dialogue with the national lottery commission, which will award the next licence.

The culture secretary admitted the decision by the commission in August to pursue exclusive negotiations with Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery, which he had endorsed, was "flawed". But he bemoaned the "warfare" that has subsequently broken out between the current lottery operator Camelot, the People's Lottery and the commission. He said the protagonists had been using "megaphone diplomacy" to get their way.

Speaking on Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Smith, who appointed the commission, denied that the process had descended into "a mess". He said his own performance should be judged once the process had reached its conclusion.

Mr Smith underlined his support of the commission and said a new chair would be appointed before the end of the week.

"I can of course understand Camelot was upset by the original flawed decision that was taken," he said.

"What they now have to accept is that the commission was setting out to be fair and that the commission now has a job to do. I look to [the commission] to do an impartial job and they will do that, I'll make sure of it.

"All parties involved in this must now get down to the serious business of looking at the applications rather than engaging in warfare across the airwaves and in public print." Mr Smith said he was determined to ensure a smooth handover in October next year.

The People's Lottery chief executive, Simon Burridge, described the comments as "a welcome note of sanity in the increasingly mad proceedings".

However, a Camelot spokeswoman suggested that the threat of further legal action, which could yet delay the process, had not been lifted. She said: "We are pleased that Chris Smith is seeking to ensure impartiality but at the moment we are still not convinced the commission will act fairly."

Camelot has just under two weeks left to submit its final, amended bid for the next seven year licence, which is due to run from October 2001. The People's Lottery has already put in its revised bid.

Mr Smith also said he had no role in the decision by the commission chairwoman, Dame Helena Shovelton, to resign last week. The decision to pursue talks with the People's Lottery despite reservations over both bids was overturned by a high court judge, who dubbed it "conspicuously unfair".

A spokesman for the commission welcomed Mr Smith's comments. "We want to proceed impartially and swiftly. It's a matter of getting down to business," he said.

fields.headline: Lurching towards war
fields.standfirst: This morning's renewed hopes in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in the Middle East have all but been destroyed in the light of today's events. Derek Brown looks back on a day where talk of peace has been replaced by deeds of war
fields.trailText: This morning's renewed hopes in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in the Middle East have all but been destroyed in the light of today's events. Derek Brown looks back on a day where talk of peace has been replaced by deeds of war
fields.body:
The Middle East is lurching towards war. Today's ghastly events in Ramallah, where three captured Israeli soldiers were butchered by a lynch mob, and the subsequent massive retaliatory attacks on Palestinian targets, have plunged the region into its deepest gloom since the darkest days of the intifada.

Thirteen years ago, when the Palestinian uprising erupted, Israeli forces were in full control of the occupied territories. Now, most of the Gaza strip and large chunks of the West Bank are controlled by Yasser Arafat's motley forces.

It is no match, as the world has seen this afternoon. On the one hand, a few hundred Kalashnikov rifles; on the other, the region's most formidable military machine. And yet that is not the end of the matter. The assault helicopters which smashed Arafat's headquarters in Gaza and in Ramallah were spelling out Israel's constant message to its neighbours: harm us, and you will pay dearly.

The direst danger now is that Israel may attempt to re-impose its military occupation of the Palestinian territories. That would outrage Arab opinion throughout the region, and could even spark a wider conflagration.

Israeli public opinion is also inflamed. The lynch mob which killed the three soldiers in Ramallah scraped the rawest nerve in Israel's national psyche. The brutal murders will inevitably raise mortal fears for the Israeli soldiers now being held captive by Hizbullah guerrillas in south Lebanon.

There is no shortage of shrill calls for the Israeli army once more to cross the Lebanese border. War is no longer an abstract threat. Both Israelis and Palestinians are saying it is already a fact. Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, Israel's deputy prime minister, has said that the peace process "is now dead". Saeb Erakat, a senior Palestinian negotiator, has given an extraordinary interview to BBC Radio Five Live, passionately appealing for international intervention to halt the Israeli retaliation.

He will not get his wish. The international community is not going to get directly involved. And yet the world will not sit idly by. It cannot, with fears of a general regional conflagration already sending oil prices soaring, and causing chaos on stock markets around the world.

The best and most immediate hope for restoring sanity is US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, who is in the region struggling to prevent the final disintegration of the peace process. Already, she has appealed to Israel to stop its military onslaught, using unusually direct language. There is as yet no sign that Israel is listening, let alone complying.

This is a conflict in which both sides passionately believe they are the victims. The Palestinians talk of Israel's brutal military machine, and complain about the USA's unquestioning support for the Jewish state. The Israelis talk of being a tiny threatened enclave in a hostile region.

Both are right, of course. That is why there is such an urgent need for deeds of war to be replaced by talk of peace.

webTitle: Granada joins Boots for £18m health and beauty venture

fields.headline: Granada joins Boots for £18m health and beauty venture
fields.trailText: 6pm update: Granada Media has linked up with retailer Boots in a joint venture to develop TV, internet and broadband services dedicated to health and beauty.
fields.body:
Granada Media has linked up with retailer Boots in a joint venture to develop TV, internet and broadband services dedicated to health and beauty.

The venture will launch an interactive digital TV channel and website offering health and beauty-related information and products in February next year. The two partners are expecting to invest £18m in setting up the new health and beauty content and e-commerce platform in the current financial year.

The Granada/Boots joint venture will be headed by joint managing directors Richard Holmes and Paula Carter. Ms Carter will be responsible for the TV channel and developing broadband and interactive technologies; while Mr Holmes will focus on the health and beauty market and customer relationship management.

The company already employs 60 people in Nottingham and Granada is planning to establish a specialist broadband content production centre in Leeds.

People watching the TV channel will be able to order information, services and products. The service will be accessible via TV, PC or laptop, and later on mobile and palmtop devices. As broadband develops, the TV channel and website are expected to be increasingly integrated and the interactive element of the service expanded.

The new venture will be 60%-owned by Boots, with Granada holding the remaining 40%. The two companies estimate that the UK market for health and beauty products and services, excluding the National Health Service, is worth £11bn per year.

Granada Media's chief executive, Steve Morrison, said: "Granada, together with Boots, the country's most trusted health and beauty brand, will build an authoritative, independent health and beauty TV channel, internet and broadband business for this country. I am delighted that it is now becoming technologically possible to provide every citizen in the country with their own personalised health service."

fields.trailText: CLUBS ON CELLULOID - UPDATED
fields.body:
CLUBS ON CELLULOID - UPDATED

"In This is Spinal Tap, the bassist Derek Smalls can be seen to be wearing an early 80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Have there been other incidences of silver screen glory for the lower league clubs?" asks James McKie.

Last week Philip Hassell pointed out that, "in Trainspotting, Renton and Spud are rabid Hibs fans - chanting 'Oh to, oh to be, oh to be a ... Hibee'." But Doug Green suggests their singing of that song may have been cynical.

"As I recall, the guys in the movie were rabid Hearts fans and hated Hibs. I swear there was an episode where Renton, after an intoxicant-influenced night in a club, shagged a girl who turned out to be 14, and felt momentarily bad. He then found out that her father was a Hibs supporter and suddenly felt really good about the incident," he says.

However - as many of you have pointed out - Doug is just plain wrong. "They were rabid Hibs fans, which isn't suprising if you consider that Irvine Welsh is also a Hibee," says Jan Brynjolffssen. "In the book quite a bit of time is spent discussing football (or fitba), most of it concentrating on a New Year's Day derby when Hibernian beat Hearts 7-0. And when Renton feels OK about having shagged a 14-year-old girl, it's because her parents were Heart of Midlothian fans."

And, sorry Doug, there's more evidence too. "I'm not sure about the episodes in the movie, but there's a great sex scene in the book where Renton's pleasure is, eh, enhanced by being able to see the score 'St Johnstone 1 Hibernian 3' coming up on the vidiprinter while in the act," says John McManus.

Meanwhile, Tom Paternoster points out: "Further evidence of him and his mates' Hibs affiliation is when Spud is asked by someone (possibly Tommy) if he's been to many games lately, and he rambles a little then asks if 'jukebox' Durie is still playing for them. However, this is entirely academic (as well as pedantic) since Hibs don't exactly qualify as a lower league team."

SOCIALIST FOOTBALLERS (PART 2)

"Two members of Tottenham's great FA Cup and Uefa winning side of the early Eighties were confirmed socialists, contributing articles to Living Marxism and other journals," wrote one Knowledge Unlimited reader whose correspondence we sadly mislaid. "Said players were Republic of Ireland internationals Tony Galvin and Chris Houghton." Last week we suggested several others, including Brian McClair, Bill Shankly, Alex Ferguson, Diego Maradona, Jorge Valdano, Fernando Redondo and Pep Guardiola. But we wanted to know if there were any other reds (or fascists) out there.

There are quite a few, as it turns out. "The famous and hairy Paul Breitner, who was on the winning German team in the 1974 World Cup, went pretty far in even supporting Baader Meinhof and Rote Arme Fraktion," writes Ulf Severdup, who reminds us that Egil Olsen is also a true Marxist.

Ivan Zamorano is a leftist, according to Noel Ivey, as is Rosenborg manager Nils Arne Eggen, says Bent Sofus Tranøy. And Lilian Thuram is considered a real intellectual, and subscribes to Le Monde Diplomatique, "so he might be one too," suggests Doug Green.

The South African 2006 World Cup bid leader, Danny Jordaan, was also a bit of a leftie in his day, says Jonathan Faull, a local government policy researcher in South Africa.

Closer to home, Pat Nevin is on the left, reckons Dan Johnson. And another left-leaning Scot is Gordon McQueen, who in the 1970s appeared in the Daily Mirror to justify his support for socialism, according to James Lupton.

On the right front, Daniel Massaro, the Italian World Cup striker in the 94 World Cup, is a strong, public supporter of the Lega Nord, says Arild Andersen. And Doug Green is "pretty certain that Giovanni Trappatoni is a supporter of the very conservative Forza Italia political party."

TOUGH-TACKLING TOFFS (PART 3)

"Does anyone know of any footballers that went to public school? I know Frank Lampard Jnr was one (he went to Brentwood). But are there any others?" wonders Joel Davison.

So far we've had Stewart Robson and Quinton Fortune, among others. But Jonathan Faull reckons Graeme Le Saux also attended public school. "It was a point made after his Russian spat with David Batty during a European campaign with Blackburn," he says.

WHY DIDN'T BOB GET THE ENGLAND JOB?

"Was Bob Paisley ever considered for the England manager's job?" asks Killian Morgan. "And if not, why not?"

"I don't know about the England job, but Bob Paisley applied for the Republic of Ireland job after he stood down as Liverpool manager," says Aidan Twomey. "After a lot of politics within the FAI, the greatest manager in the history of English football was, astonishingly, rejected in favour of Jack Charlton.

"Mind you, big Jack turned out to be a national hero, so it turned out alright in the end. But if Charlton did that, Paisley could have won us the World Cup."

Mark Aspinall has a different viewpoint. "Never mind why Paisley wasn't asked to become England manager," he says. "The key question is: why wasn't he knighted? After all, he did win leagues and European Cups with Liverpool, making them the first English team to dominate Europe for a number of years." "Nor was Clough knighted for acheiving two consecutive European Cups on a more modest budget with Forest," he continues. "Or Tony Barton for winning the European Cup with Villa, beating a certain German club against all the odds in the final. Yet both Matt Busby and Alex Ferguson were knighted - probably because they were the manager of a certain northern club beloved by the media and other home counties residents."

If a member of either the current Labour government or the Tory regime of the early 80s knows why this is, we'd love to know.

SLIMY SHIRTS

"After watching a couple of Arsenal games this season myself and my flatmates have noticed that several of the players appear to have a patch of slime on the chest of their shirts. Does anyone have any idea what this is?" ask Paul Bird and Will Morrison.

"It is some form of vapour rub, which is put on the top of the chest so that the vapour will rise and ensure that the players nose stays clear while playing," points out Carl White.

CLUBS WITH NUMBERS

Are there any others with numbers in their names?" asks William Smith.

Last week we ploughed through what almost every team in the German Bundesliga. And now it's Denmark's turn. "In the Danish second division, there is a team called 'B93' which is short for 'Boldklub 1893', the year that the 'ballclub' (football club) was formed" says Pádraig Kelleher. "And Sunday football teams also commonly use numbers - their year of conception - in their team names."

CAN YOU HELP?

"We've all heard the football cliché 'get stuck in' enough times. What is the derivation of this expression?" asks Steven Randall.

"What convention (if any) decides how we refer to foreign clubs? For instance, why Bayern Munich, and not Bayern Munchen or Bavaria Munich?" asks Keir Gale.

"Does anyone know the basis of the rivalry between River Plate and Boca Juniors of Argentina? Is it true that the clubs are supposed to be for the rich and for the poor of Buenos Aires respectively?" asks Matt Walker.

"What would have happened if the 1966 World Cup Final had ended in a draw? I'm sure that there would not have been provision for a penalty shoot-out, so would it have been a replay? I heard that European ties were decided by a toss of a coin at this time - so is it conceivable that Bobby Moore may have had to call correctly to have won the World Cup for England?" asks Alain Verdun.

Send your emails to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: England fans draw a double blank

fields.headline: England fans draw a double blank
fields.trailText: Pay-per-view coverage of England's World Cup qualifier against Finland apparently collapsed last night, prompting furious fans to jam the helpline of broadcaster u>directsports.
fields.body:
Pay-per-view coverage of England's World Cup qualifier against Finland apparently collapsed last night, prompting furious fans to jam the helpline of broadcaster u>directsports.

Footage from the game, which cost fans up to £10 to pre-order, halted after 15 minutes, according to those trying to watch it. The company's helpline became permanently engaged and its website crashed by 5.30pm.

In a statement, the broadcaster blamed any problems on customers. "The only viewing problems which have been reported are those involving customers who left it until the last minute to register for the match or failed to register at all. The vast majority of cus tomers who called before coverage started have experienced no problems at all."

England's fortunes on the pitch failed to improve following Saturday's 1-0 home defeat by Germany. They were held to a goalless draw by Finland, who last week lost 1-0 to Greece. With one point from two games, England's task of reaching the 2002 World Cup finals appeared increasingly daunting for whoever succeeds Kevin Keegan.

England might have snatched a win three minutes from the end of a poor match when a shot by Arsenal's Ray Parlour hit the bar and appeared to bounce over the goal line. Unlike the 1966 World Cup final at Wembley, there was no Russian linesman for England to turn to.

webTitle: Trouble at home as daddy's girl grows up

fields.headline: Trouble at home as daddy's girl grows up
fields.trailText: Zamira is in big trouble. With her father for cutting her hair and plucking her eyebrows, and with me for parading this "rebellion" in a steady stream of photographs home.
fields.body:
Zamira is in big trouble. With her father for cutting her hair and plucking her eyebrows, and with me for parading this "rebellion" in a steady stream of photographs home.

To be honest I didn't think she would last two months abroad, never mind two years. But although it was touch and go during the first year, she has made it. So much so that she wants to stay for a third. She sprang this request on her unsuspecting parents during a weekly three-minute call home. Her father, terrified of what the photos show she has become, was not too keen on the idea.

I was summoned to listen to and lend weight to a list of objections that he then proceeded to recite in a 10-point letter to Zamira. I had somehow become responsible for the fate of his offspring, having foolishly agreed two years ago to act as escort, courier and go-between. Besides which, it was my country that was polluting her, and he needed someone to rail against.

Top of the list was the hair, followed closely by the eyebrows. He fortunately never got to see the mini-skirt and shorts that I tactfully amputated at mid-thigh before passing the photos on, more for my preservation than for hers. He was sure, he said in his letter, that the photo was playing some kind of trick, and that she probably hadn't disobeyed him by neglecting to ask his permission to carry out such radical alterations to her appearance, but in the unlikely event that she had - how dare she?

His reaction to her cutting 45cm off her waist-length hair was predictable. Hair was given by God to be long, and should never be cut. Like his beard, I retorted - he is clean-shaven. Fortunately he saw the joke, but couldn't bring himself to laugh about the eyebrows. A girl only plucks them on the eve of her wedding, together with all other vestiges of body hair in honour of the first night. Had she forgotten the effect that someone seeing a photo of her compromised like this could have on her marriage prospects in the village?

The problem is, Zamira has forgotten. She has forgotten a lot, and it is surprising how blind she has become to the gulf between the world she has left and the one she has now embraced. She has forgotten how much she has changed and how little they have. She has learned to handle money and freedom. Her father, like all good fathers here, still takes his responsibilities seriously to control his daughter wherever she is, whatever she may be doing and whoever she is doing it with, until of course the day he transfers that duty into the hands of another man, chosen by him to assume responsibility for her continued upbringing and discipline. Until that day, as far as he is concerned, all her decisions are still his.

He hoped she remembered his final words to her to stay pure. Did she remember he had allowed her to go, provided she only made friends with girls and kept away from boys? Was that a boy in the group photo she had sent once? Who was he, and why had she not spoken of him to her father? Had she also remembered that she was to take an Uzbek husband on her return? The time had come for her to accept her responsibilities and to start producing children to care for them all in their old age. At 25 she was becoming less and less desirable as a wife, and if she was not careful he would become the laughing stock of their village. As far as he was concerned, two extra years of English would be ample for the job he had lined up for her. Besides, he could see no point in study for study's sake.

The first year in England was hell for Zamira. She felt like an outsider, squeezed into people's diarised lives and terribly lonely without the communality of village existence. She was terrified to express an opinion openly in class, particularly if it differed from that of the lecturer, after years of rote learning recitation and beatings as a child in school. She described the anguish of buying her first pair of shoes in England without her father's permission or opinion, and still finds purchases of any kind an immense trial.

She was embarrassed to eat openly for the first few months, squirrelling food away to eat in secret later. She volunteered for cooking duty at her college, knowing that she could pick at the food without anyone seeing. Girls in her village don't eat in front of strangers, and never admit to being hungry. The English were obsessed with personal hygiene, she thought, coming from a village where people rarely wash more than their face and hands more than once every week or two. She found the other students' insistence that she shower every day offensive.

But Zamira has moved on. She loves her life and is immersed in the quest for knowledge for knowledge's sake. She devours books, no longer by candlelight at midnight after everyone has gone to bed and after the household chores are done.

I have the onerous job on her father's behalf of trying to persuade her to return. Even were I so inclined, she can make her own decisions now, and she has decided to stay. But I have told her she must tell her father - herself.

Map

fields.trailText: Israeli helicopter gunships have responded swiftly to the earlier mob killing of three Israeli soldiers, firing six rockets at the Palestinian police station where the men died.
fields.body:
Israeli helicopter gunships have responded swiftly to the earlier mob killing of three Israeli soldiers, firing six rockets at the Palestinian police station where the men died.

The attack, in the West Bank town of Ramallah, pushed the region closer to war as UN secretary general Kofi Annan and other diplomats attempted to calm violence that has left more than 90 people, mainly Palestinians, dead in the past two weeks.

"This is a declaration of war - a crazy war," Saeb Erekat, a senior Palestinian official, said of some of the worst Israeli-Palestinian violence since the 1967 Mideast war. Mr Erekat called on the Israeli's to "stop the madness".

The gunships also reportedly hit Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's headquarters. There are no confirmed reports of Mr Arafat's whereabouts but he met this afternoon with the head of the CIA, George Tenet.

The soldiers were killed when a crowd stormed a Palestinian police station where they were being held.

The Israeli deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, said Israel had no choice but to retaliate, adding that "it's never too late" to resume talks at some stage. Israeli sources said the attacks represented "limited action" rather than all-out war.

The reservist soldiers apparently took a wrong turning and inadvertently ended up in Ramallah, a flashpoint for recent violence. They were detained with a colleague before being attacked, military sources said. There was no immediate information about the fate of the other soldier.

The Israeili prime minister, Ehud Barak, has called an emergency cabinet meeting. There are unconfirmed reports he informed Mr Arafat of the gunship attack before it began.

Mr Tenet had been hoping to chair trilateral security talks under a committee established two years ago, diplomatic sources said. But reports indicate that, so far, he has only spoken directly with Mr Arafat.

Mr Barak said earlier in the week that he would consider allowing contacts between the sides on merit, even if violence persisted. Mr Anan cut short a trip to Lebanon to return this afternoon to Israel.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, today urged the Israelis and Palestinians to prevent the latest outbreak of violence in the Middle East "spiralling out of control".

Mr Blair spoke to the US president, Bill Clinton, this morning, and has also been in contact with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who is still in the region.

High-level diplomacy has coincided with a decrease in the overall level of the violence, but prospects for a quick resumption of talks on a comprehensive peace settlement appeared extremely dim.

Israel's communications minister Binyamin Ben-Eliezer today accused Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat of wanting to escalate the crisis. "Arafat's clear desire is for war, that is what he wants," he told Israeli radio.

"There is no peace process today. The peace process is dead."

Fierce gunbattles in the West Bank towns of Bethlehem and Hebron lasted into the early hours of today. Israel radio said the Israeli army had fired from helicopter gunships at Palestinian gunmen outside Bethlehem. An Israeli soldier shot in the stomach was evacuated near Hebron in four hours of overnight fighting. A mosque was torched before dawn in Howara village, near the West Bank town of Nablus, and residents said they believed Jewish settlers were responsible.

Jewish settlers have expressed outrage at the recent Palestinian ransacking of the Joseph's Tomb compound, a small Israeli seminary tucked in the middle of Nablus, an overwhelming Palestinian area.

An American-born rabbi who taught at the seminary was shot dead last week and buried yesterday. Palestinian stone throwers and gunmen attacked settlers travelling to the funeral, and Israeli troops responded with fire from machine guns mounted on tanks.

Three Palestinians were killed in clashes yesterday, and Sami Abu Jazar, a 12-year-old boy who was shot in the head earlier in the week, died of his wounds, Palestinian officials said. His funeral will be held later today in the Gaza Strip.

The Palestinians have accused the Israelis of using excessive force, but Major General Moshe Yaalon, the Israeli army's deputy chief of staff, said the military was prepared to step up its operations if the Palestinians do not rein in rioters.

"We don't have any choice," he said. "If we see that this escalation does not stop, we will have to use much more severe means."

Meanwhile, Mr Annan delayed a trip to Beirut, Lebanon - where he had hoped to help negotiate the release of three kidnapped Israeli soldiers - in favour of additional meetings with Mr Barak and Mr Arafat.

In what may be an optimistic sign, Israel came out in favour of a Middle East summit quickly to calm the situation and resume peace talks. He had previously said he would attend a summit only if Mr Arafat took decisive steps to end the violence.

US President Bill Clinton has been trying to bring Mr Barak and Mr Arafat together for a US-hosted summit in the region in the next few days.

webTitle: Be proud to be British, Straw tells left

fields.headline: Be proud to be British, Straw tells left
fields.standfirst:
Do not leave patriotism to far right, urges home secretary
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, yesterday blamed the lack of patriotism of the political left for allowing the modern British identity to be seen as "narrow, exclusionary and conservative".
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, yesterday blamed the lack of patriotism of the political left for allowing the modern British identity to be seen as "narrow, exclusionary and conservative".

Mr Straw declared himself proud to be British and insisted that he did not accept the arguments of some on the liberal left or the nationalist right that the idea of Britain as a cohesive nation was dead. The existence of people happy to be known as "black British or Chinese British" demonstrated that "Britishness" had a future.

The modern challenge now, said Mr Straw, was to meld the enormous range of races, accents and attitudes in the country into a single shared identity. "This is made even more difficult by the way those on the left turned their backs on the concept of patriotism and left the field to those on the far right," the home secretary said.

He was speaking at the launch of the controversial report of the commission on the future of multi-ethnic Britain, which has put a question mark against the future use of the term "British" because it has racial connotations of "white colonialism". It calls for a formal declaration that Britain is a multicultural society, and it has been accused of wanting to rewrite British history.

Mr Straw said that while he welcomed some of the recommendations of the Runny mede Trust sponsored commission, which was chaired by the Labour peer and political scientist Lord Parekh, he parted company with the report over its view of Britishness. "Unlike the Runnymede Trust, I firmly believe there is a future for Britain and a future for Britishness."

Mr Straw said George Orwell's observation 50 years ago that in leftwing circles it was felt that there was something slightly disgraceful in being an Englishman still applied to day. "Orwell wrote that 'it is unquestionably true that almost any English intellectual would feel more ashamed of standing to attention during God Save the King than of stealing from the poor box'.

"Given the tendency of some of the left to wash their hands of the whole notion of nationhood, it is perhaps not surprising that some people's perception of Englishness and Britishness became a narrow, exclusionary, conservative one. That's a view of British ness that I don't recognise. We all benefit, economically and socially, from our diversity and difference. We should be celebrating that, not bemoaning it."

Lord Parekh insisted that his commission wanted to reform and redefine what it means to be British. "We do not denigrate British history. There is a very important role for a common national culture and a common civic nationality," he said. "But we are requesting that this common culture needs to be discussed and renegotiated. It does not imply that it is not a coherent idea."

Lord Parekh said that too often minority ethnic groups were seen at best as "welcome tenants" and not as common owners of the country.

"The British national identity should be so defined that we all feel comfortable with it and we all feel proud to be British," he said.

The wide-ranging report is the biggest review of British identity and racial equality since Labour came to power three years ago. Its recommendations include scrapping the asylum voucher and dispersal system and setting up a human rights commission.

 The Future of Multi-ethnic Britain, The Parekh Report, Profile Books, £10.99

fields.headline: The inclusiveness of 'Britain' cannot be challenged
fields.standfirst:
Lord Parekh's commission is wrong about labels, but right about race
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Thirty years ago, the argument of the British right was that coloured immigration, as they called it, was going to destroy the British way of life. Enoch Powell prophesied that whole areas of the country would soon be unrecognisable, as the proportion of non-white faces grew by compound accumulation.
fields.body:
Thirty years ago, the argument of the British right was that coloured immigration, as they called it, was going to destroy the British way of life. Enoch Powell prophesied that whole areas of the country would soon be unrecognisable, as the proportion of non-white faces grew by compound accumulation. In 1978, as Conservative leader and candidate for prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, promised to stop the "swamping" of the country by an "influx" of people who did not ethnically belong here. The critique of the right was that far too many non-Brits were being let in, and would give birth to far too many offspring who would change Britain for ever.

It was an inflammatory argument, which had a pervasive effect on the way race was dealt with by politicians of all parties. However, it has now apparently changed. The right's response to the new report by the Commission on the Future of Multi-ethnic Britain starts from the opposite premise. The commission's proposal that historic concepts of Britishness deserve rethinking in 2000 meets a tirade of anger based on the claim that there are not enough blacks and Asians here to justify any such exercise.

Whites, it is said, are the majority: about 53m out of 57m. So any recognition that this is a multi-ethnic society, let alone that Britishness needs to encompass wider definitions than hitherto, is an affront to the white majority: "sub-Marxist gibberish" (Daily Telegraph), "an insult to history and our intelligence" (Daily Mail). The same people who once said you were being swamped, and generated decades of journalism playing to such images, now say that nothing has changed after all and that anyone who suggests otherwise must come from the Josef Goebbels academy of political correctness.

Besides being startlingly contradictory, each of these positions lacks a certain basis in fact. The Powellite prophecy did not come true. By this time, had he been correct, there would be about 5m more non-white British than in fact there are. Such a large error should caution us against the propensity of the right to allow paranoid hallucination to invade objectivity in these matters. And so it proves with their reaction to Lord Parekh's commission. They seem to regard the fact that there are now nearly 4m British who are not white, as well as millions more who are not Anglo-Saxon, as so unimportant, and yet so strangely menacing, that it is better left unaddressed by intellectual inquiry.

The commission was foolish to leave itself open to the charge that it wants to abolish "Britain". Its report does not say that, but makes insinuations about the meaning of Britain and British history that could only be provocative. They seem silly anyway. Far from "Britain" needing to be replaced by something else, it strikes me as a label that gains new life from the very non-white communities that Lord Parekh says have made it anachronistic. Properly understood, Britain provides a catch-all identity for every segment of this multi-ethnic country. Though its political origins may be undone by the separation of Scotland from England, its descriptive inclusiveness can hardly be challenged.

But it does need to be inclusive. That is all the Parekh commission is really saying. Defenders of Britain's racial record insist that there is no doubt about such inclusiveness. Parekh surveys the field and raises questions that suggest otherwise. And in doing so it makes its own proposal for an historic evolution. Whereas the right is fixated by the past, the left urges a new kind of focus on the future.

At the time Enoch Powell spoke, the emphasis of public policy was on racial integration. It was against the Wilson government's legislative efforts in that field that Powell proffered his poisonous vision of the rivers of urban Britain foaming with blood. The governing ethos tended to favour the idea of assimilation of immigrant minorities into the host community, unimpeded by racial penalties. As home secretary, Roy Jenkins made a famous speech broadening the objective to include diversity and tolerance. But essentially the goal was to make available to all who entered this country access to British rights and standards, not to mention jobs and housing: to permit everyone to conform to a rather narrow, if admirable and well-defended, model of Britishness.

Many immigrants and their British-born children did so. Some could be heard denouncing Lord Parekh yesterday. But many others found that the model did not fit their lives. It is much easier for German migrants to become fully American than for, say, Pakistani Muslims to fit into a British legal regime that cannot cope with religious differences. The integrationist model has its limits. It has little to say about social, as distinct from legal, exclusion or the interlinking of social deprivation with racial prejudice which must surely preoccupy any keen observer of the state of Britain today.

The Parekh commission, by characterising Britain as a community of communities, offers a broader model than mere assimilation. It has scouted out the land the Daily Telegraph never visits, and hoisted some storm cones. It wants Britain to celebrate her variety, and understand how differences as well as conformity need to be accommodated in schools, in the police, in politics, in culture, in the whole range of public life. It makes some substantial proposals, as such surveys must, which are of variable quality but deserve serious discussion.

The hysteria with which the report has been greeted does not bode well for such discussion. But it throws a revealing light on these frightened spokesmen for the old canons of Britishness. They can barely contain their rage at the notion of the national identity, along with its hierarchy of historic icons, perhaps needing to be updated. They evidently do not understand what it means to feel excluded: don't feel the individual pain, don't reflect on the social consequences. Their anguished frenzy makes a contrast with the measured, confident and adult tone of the commission, which is a far cry from the ethnic whingeing of 20 years ago. Who, one wonders, are the real inheritors of British tolerance and cool common sense here?

The most potent recent display of our island nationalism took place at Wembley last Saturday. This is what Englishness - which is synonymous, for the Telegraph and Mail, with Britishness - has sunk to. Ten thousand voices roared anti-German war taunts, and drowned out the other side's national anthem. Richard Williams reported "a mood of such depravity as to make one wonder exactly what, in far wider terms, the English think they are doing with themselves".

I wasn't there, and can't prove it. But would anyone bet that more than 1% of that yobbish multitude was of Asian or Caribbean origin? Finding the only way to proclaim their Britishness by screaming obscenities at Germans? They may not always support England at cricket. But they seem to know better than many Anglo-Saxons what should be meant by being British.

fields.trailText: RADIO TIMES
fields.body:
RADIO TIMES

How much do you love u>direct sports, the capital-letter-less capitalists who snaffled up the live rights to last night's World Cup match between Finland and England and then asked everyone to pay to watch it? Very much? Well, you must love staring at boxes with the words "Finland v England £7.99 please insert your smartcard" in them, then. Unlike the Fiver, for example, who, upon being presented with such a box for the duration of the whole game, was forced to smash the television into sharp Jari Litmanen-shaped pieces. Before saying sorry to Granny Fiver, whose telly we had been watching.

It turns out that the Fiver was only one of many customers experiencing "technical difficulties" such as frozen or blank screens. According to u>direct, anyone who subscribed to the "event" through the Sky "platform" would have had "few" problems. But any poor sod who chipped into the u>coffers using some other digital provider was destined to suffer. Additionally, if you were rude enough to only pay through the nose just before the game began, and not several days in advance, then you may as well have flushed your money straight down the Swanee.

Unsurprisingly, the whole affair was deemed to be a corking success by the folks at u>. "We did have one or two problems with isolated customers, mainly those who phoned very late and left it to the last minute to register," complained u>ngrateful managing director Roger Hall. "I don't want to pass the buck," he passed the buck, "but in the same way that u>direct wouldn't have been responsible for something going wrong on the BBC last night, nor would we be responsible for something going wrong on another broadcast platform."

Why Hall should be at pains to shift the blame onto "another broadcast platform" is beyond us, especially when an ONdigital spokesperson insisted he was "not aware" of any problems at all with his company's service. The Fiver is currently very confused, but once we've read the statements from both companies again - no apology from either, you'll notice - we're sure we'll discover that missing the whole match was our own silly fault.

STEVE TOASTS COAST POST

Anything Southampton can do, bitter south coast rivals Portsmouth can do too. Apart from retaining top-flight status, that is, but now is not the time to start a row. Anyway, the First Division club have taken their neighbours lead in appointing a brand new manager while moving the present one aside for personal reasons. "Dave Jones and Glenn Hoddle? We'll give you Dave Jones and Glenn Hoddle!" you can almost imagine Pompey fans screaming at the folk they light-heartedly refer to as scummers.

The similarities between the two situations are uncanny: Dell boss Jones was ousted from his post so he could defend himself in the courts, while Pompey boss Tony Pulis has been granted leave of absence on full pay to "concentrate on his forthcoming court case with Gillingham FC"; the reason for Jones's dismissal was widely regarded as an excuse to jettison him for performances on the pitch - chairman Milan Mandaric has relieved Pulis of his duties after a run of two wins in 11 league games; and just as Saints called up a world-class footballing genius to take over, so Pompey have appointed Steve Claridge.

"It's a dream come true!" bubbled the Portsmouth-born striker. "It's something I've always dreamed about since I was a kid and I love this club," he continued, drinking in the heady atmosphere. But although 34-year-old Claridge was giddy with delight, he was well aware of how sobering the task ahead will be. "It's great," he toasted, "but I've got to make it work. I'm under no illusions about how hard it will be." We wish you well, Steve - after all, Pompey have taken one hell of a gamble on you.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"My job is available" - Norway coach Nils Johan Semb offers to resign following his side's 1-0 home defeat by Ukraine. Ecoutez et repetez, Monsieur Wilkinson.

'ERE'S A BLEEDIN' JACKANORY, INNIT?

With Stanley Victor Collymore's sulkathon set to run and run - unlike his body, which is putting on weight at such a rate that even Leicester East MP Keith Vaz would be impressed - you would think Peter Taylor would be desperate to offload him. But perhaps Leicester's cockney manager is being too 'bright and breezy' (easy) about dealing with his 'Allan Border' (out-of-order) striker. Because when Southend boss David Webb tried to 'shovel and pick' (nick) Collymore, it was Taylor who warned him off!

"Peter rang me last week to wish me good luck with Southend and I took the opportunity to ask him about Stan," revealed Webb, using a disappointing lack of London slang. "But he told me Stan wanted to move abroad and I wouldn't want him because of his problems." Now usually that would be the end of the matter, but Webb seems strangely keen to get his man - albeit with one or two provisos.

"I thought it would be nice to get him back at Roots Hall for the fans if Leicester would be willing to pay his wages," said the Shrimpers boss, sheepishly forgetting to mention that Stan 'earns' £13,000 a week. "He's still available for transfer as I got a circular from Leicester the other day, and you never know what might happen," he chirped with a wanton disregard for the amount of baggage Stan carries with him. "The seeds have been sown now," he added, blissfully unaware that jellied eels, a pier and Third-Division football are unlikely to satisfy Collymore's ego - let alone his stomach.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle are poised to sign Honduran defender Milton Jocon Reyes, according to Teamtalk. Reyes, who has won 29 international caps and also interests Coventry, said: "My club have informed me they are expecting a formal offer to be made for me on Thursday. If that offer does not take shape, I will wait for another option."

Derby manager Jim Smith is lining up a bid for Blackburn's out-of-favour Christian Dailly.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Former world featherweight boxing champion Naseem Hamed is considering forming a consortium to buy into struggling Sheffield Wednesday. "Our reasons for doing it are because we are from Sheffield and there is a parochial link," said his brother Riath. "There is no quick fix. Obviously nobody is looking at this as a quick profit-making scheme. We would have a long-term strategy plan to turn the club round and put it on the road to recovery."

David Beckham has been fined almost £4,000 by Uefa after showing "clear dissent" towards referee Markus Merk during Manchester United's Big Cup defeat at PSV Eindhoven.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Frank Leboeuf have been given two-match bans for using foul and abusive language to the referee after Chelsea's 2-0 Euro-Vase defeat at St Gallen.

Leicester manager Peter Taylor has been named Carling manager of the month for September. Tim Flowers won the player of the month award.

Scotland manager Craig Brown will face a Fifa disciplinary committee next week after being sent off against Croatia last night.

Danish goalkeeper Lars Winde has joined West Ham on a one week trial.

Reading manager Alan Pardew and assistant Martin Allen have signed new contracts which will keep them at the club until 2003.

Claudio Gentile has been named as coach of Italy Under-21s.

Other news now, and, according to some survey or other, people are doing 40% more driving than they used to in the 1980s, or something!

fields.bodyText: RADIO TIMES How much do you love u>direct sports, the capital-letter-less capitalists who snaffled up the live rights to last night's World Cup match between Finland and England and then asked everyone to pay to watch it? Very much? Well, you must love staring at boxes with the words "Finland v England £7.99 please insert your smartcard" in them, then. Unlike the Fiver, for example, who, upon being presented with such a box for the duration of the whole game, was forced to smash the television into sharp Jari Litmanen-shaped pieces. Before saying sorry to Granny Fiver, whose telly we had been watching. It turns out that the Fiver was only one of many customers experiencing "technical difficulties" such as frozen or blank screens. According to u>direct, anyone who subscribed to the "event" through the Sky "platform" would have had "few" problems. But any poor sod who chipped into the u>coffers using some other digital provider was destined to suffer. Additionally, if you were rude enough to only pay through the nose just before the game began, and not several days in advance, then you may as well have flushed your money straight down the Swanee. Unsurprisingly, the whole affair was deemed to be a corking success by the folks at u>. "We did have one or two problems with isolated customers, mainly those who phoned very late and left it to the last minute to register," complained u>ngrateful managing director Roger Hall. "I don't want to pass the buck," he passed the buck, "but in the same way that u>direct wouldn't have been responsible for something going wrong on the BBC last night, nor would we be responsible for something going wrong on another broadcast platform." Why Hall should be at pains to shift the blame onto "another broadcast platform" is beyond us, especially when an ONdigital spokesperson insisted he was "not aware" of any problems at all with his company's service. The Fiver is currently very confused, but once we've read the statements from both companies again - no apology from either, you'll notice - we're sure we'll discover that missing the whole match was our own silly fault. STEVE TOASTS COAST POST Anything Southampton can do, bitter south coast rivals Portsmouth can do too. Apart from retaining top-flight status, that is, but now is not the time to start a row. Anyway, the First Division club have taken their neighbours lead in appointing a brand new manager while moving the present one aside for personal reasons. "Dave Jones and Glenn Hoddle? We'll give you Dave Jones and Glenn Hoddle!" you can almost imagine Pompey fans screaming at the folk they light-heartedly refer to as scummers. The similarities between the two situations are uncanny: Dell boss Jones was ousted from his post so he could defend himself in the courts, while Pompey boss Tony Pulis has been granted leave of absence on full pay to "concentrate on his forthcoming court case with Gillingham FC"; the reason for Jones's dismissal was widely regarded as an excuse to jettison him for performances on the pitch - chairman Milan Mandaric has relieved Pulis of his duties after a run of two wins in 11 league games; and just as Saints called up a world-class footballing genius to take over, so Pompey have appointed Steve Claridge. "It's a dream come true!" bubbled the Portsmouth-born striker. "It's something I've always dreamed about since I was a kid and I love this club," he continued, drinking in the heady atmosphere. But although 34-year-old Claridge was giddy with delight, he was well aware of how sobering the task ahead will be. "It's great," he toasted, "but I've got to make it work. I'm under no illusions about how hard it will be." We wish you well, Steve - after all, Pompey have taken one hell of a gamble on you. fields.headline: Sea 'lawn' clue to climate change
fields.trailText: Scientists who borrowed a leaf from the gardening manuals have confirmed that the oceans can bloom with trillions of tiny plants - if someone sprinkles a little mineral fertiliser first.
fields.body:
Scientists who borrowed a leaf from the gardening manuals have confirmed that the oceans can bloom with trillions of tiny plants - if someone sprinkles a little mineral fertiliser first.

More importantly, the phytoplankton - the tiny green plants - can soak up huge quantities of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, provided they have enough iron in the oceanic equivalent of topsoil.

An international team of scientists reports in Nature today that they tipped more than three tons of dissolved iron into a 50 square kilometre patch of sea off Antarctica. Over the next two weeks they measured the levels of dissolved carbon dioxide in the surface waters and noted that it had fallen by 10% as the algae began to bloom. They calculated that 1,000 tons of carbon had been taken up by the plants.

When the scientists checked satellite images six weeks later, their original 50km square "lawn" had been stretched by ocean currents to a ribbon more than 150km long.

All plants need water, and carbon and nitrogen from the air, to grow. But they also need tiny quantities of other nutrients to make this growth possible. In 1990, an American oceanographer called John Martin argued that the reason the oceans weren't teeming with plant life was a shortage of iron.

In 1993, Andrew Watson of the University of East Anglia began a series of tests. The latest voyage of the "Soiree" team - Soiree stands for southern ocean iron release experiment - confirmed that the hypothesis was as true for near freezing oceans as for tropical ones.

But, Prof Watson warned, the experiment did not offer a solution to the problem of global warming.

Ever since the first alarms about the greenhouse effect there have been hopes of a "technical fix". But, he said, the process could only take carbon dioxide from the atmosphere at a certain rate. The value of the experiment lay in what it could reveal about the history of the earth during the last 400,000 years.

"The changes we saw after adding the iron may well explain past changes in the earth's carbon dioxide levels during and at the end of the ice ages. It is evident that this is a driver for climate change. We know that there was a far higher flux of iron in the atmospheric dust to the oceans in glacial times. Our study indicates this was responsible for about half of the big change in atmospheric carbon dioxide that occurred then," he said.

webTitle: UK telcos gear up for Italian phone  auction

fields.headline: UK telcos gear up for Italian phone  auction
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: The third major European phone licence auction will kick off in Italy next week, with two UK telecoms companies in the frame, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The third major European phone licence auction will kick off in Italy next week, with two UK telecoms companies in the frame.

Italian prime minister Giuliano Amato confirmed that the auction for five third generation mobile phone licences will begin on October 19. Analysts expect the process to raise between £9.5bn and £19bn.

Vodafone, the UK mobile phone group, is bidding for a licence through its Omnitel subsidiary while BT is a major shareholder in rival bidder Blu.

The licences will last for 15 years from the beginning of January 2002. Both bids are expected to be successful.

webTitle: Sky, Channel 4 and Arena bid for horseracing

fields.headline: Sky, Channel 4 and Arena saddle up for racing bid
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: BSkyB and Channel 4 have teamed up with racecourse owner Arena Leisure to outbid Carlton for rights to UK horseracing, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BSkyB and Channel 4 have teamed up with racecourse owner Arena Leisure in an attempt to outbid Carlton Communications for the global media rights to UK horseracing.

The three partners are forming a joint venture, NewCo, that is expected to make a formal offer to the 59 UK racecourses within two weeks. The bid is likely to cover worldwide TV, internet and interactive rights for events including Royal Ascot and the Grand National.

Arena Leisure - which owns six British racecourses - earlier this month saw its previous £320m bid topped by Carlton, which offered £400m. Arena is also reported to be in talks with the BBC - which currently shares terrestrial coverage of UK horse racing with Channel 4 - about selling on some of the rights.

Earlier this year, Channel 4 and NTL withdrew a joint bid for UK horseracing rights after failing to agree a deal with the racecourse owners.

Ian Penrose, Arena finance director, said: "Our partnership with Channel 4 and BSkyB combines all the necessary broadcasting, technology, interactive gaming and racing experience, expertise and contacts to develop UK racing as a truly global media and gaming product.

"We are confident that the UK racecourses will appreciate this partnership is best placed to maximise enhanced revenue streams to racing," he added.

fields.headline: BBC holds on to snooker
fields.trailText: 4pm: The BBC has signed a deal enabling it to keep snooker matches on terrestrial television until 2006. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC has signed a deal enabling it to keep snooker matches on terrestrial television until 2006.

As part of the deal with the World Snooker Association, the BBC has agreed to bump up coverage of the four major snooker competitions: the Grand Prix, Benson & Hedges Masters, Liverpool Victoria UK Championship and Embassy World Championship.

BBC Sport's acting director Richard Sambrook said "Snooker is still one of the hot television sports, with a devoted following counted in millions. We are delighted to continue with the present cream of the snooker calendar."

The BBC has lost a number of high-profile sports contracts over the past few years due to competition from ITV and cable and satellite providers, and it is likely to make much of this success.

fields.headline: How much can you pay for
fields.trailText: ... a stamp
fields.body:
... a stamp

In practical terms, this item is utterly useless. Half a Serbian stamp. A mere snip at £11,000. But stamp collectors listen up, this one's a gem.

In 1866 Serbia, 20 para was the amount of cash that changed hands for the equivalent of a second class stamp. But, alas, this was a turbulent time in the Balkans. Peace was sporadic, and, due to a shortage of para, emergency franking was declared. And so, Prince Michael on the 40 para deep blue, had his head ripped in half. This stamp is the prized possession of Dragan Udovicic, proprietor of Euro-Yu Stamp Collecting. There is however, one problem. The stamp is lonely, it has lost its other half. According to Udovicic, it exists somewhere. The two half-40 paras are believed to be the last in existence. If you are keen, but your budget doesn't stretch to 11 grand then don't despair. Prices at Euro Yu start at £10. Stamps are all pre-1945 and strictly continental.

Euro-Yu Stamp Collecting: 0207 495 0242, website: euro-yu@msn.com.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cocktails
fields.body:
Cocktails

A wonderful invention. But very expensive in bars. So, as the nights draw in, kick off your shoes, shake those spirits and settle down in the comfort of your own own home to sip a delicious creation.

First up is www.chowbaby.com. Whether you usually stick to a G&T or are a cocktail connoisseur, this is the site for you. Browse their cocktail index by cocktail title or ingredient, the latter being the perfect way to use up that random spirit given to you by your great aunt last Christmas. This American site isn't graphically amazing, but the index is straightforward.

At www.drinkboy.com the site master offers you to take an "adventure in cocktails". The site includes cocktail menus and articles on drinking. For example, tequila "is a distilled spirit made from the blue agave variety of the maguey plant". The level of information is great for cocktail buffs, and an opportunity to become cock tail-savvy for the rest of us. So now you've got the ingredients sussed, time to get serious on the equipment side.

www.drinkstuff.com is a mine of information. Click to cocktails, select cocktail equipment and enjoy scrolling down a list of "necessary"utensils. The shopper's menu is complete with very good graphic images. Selection includes a clear party cocktail shaker (£5.50) and a sombrero salt rimmer (£3.75).

For something a bit special try www.cocktailshaker.com. The classic shaker company uses original designs; sterling silver prices start around £1,600

webTitle: BSkyB told to give rivals 'clean feed' of premium channels

fields.headline: BSkyB told to give rivals 'clean feed' of premium channels
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: BSkyB has been told it must guarantee a "clean feed" of its premium pay-TV channels - stripped of interactive elements - to rival digital TV distributors. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BSkyB has been told by consumer affairs minister Kim Howells that it must guarantee a "clean feed" of its premium pay-TV channels - stripped of interactive elements - to rival digital TV distributors.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Trade & Industry said that Mr Howells had accepted recommendations by the director general of fair trading that by increasing its stake in interactive platform Open... from 32% to 80%, its interest in the company had changed from "material" to "controlling", and that this raised "competition concerns".

Currently, viewers of BSkyB interactive services such as Sky News and Sky Sports Active on rival distribution networks are faced with dialogues and audio feeds telling them about the interactive services available to them on BSkyB platforms. Under the directive, BSkyB must remove all references to these services.

If the undertaking is not agreed, BSkyB's bid to increase its stake in Open...will be referred to the Competition Commission.

BSkyB was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: ARM acts to break mobile dependency

fields.headline: ARM acts to break mobile dependency
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The growth that has transformed ARM Holdings into a top performer in the British technology sector shows little sign of slowing, the company's chief executive said yesterday after reporting unexpectedly good third-quarter figures.
fields.body:
The growth that has transformed ARM Holdings into a top performer in the British technology sector shows little sign of slowing, the company's chief executive said yesterday after reporting unexpectedly good third-quarter figures.

ARM-powered chips are already in 85% of the world's mobile telephones but revenues from products such as digital modems and set-top boxes are reducing its dependence on that sector and boosting overall sales, according to Arm's founder and chief executive, Robin Saxby.

"Momentum is stronger than ever and the trends in all sectors are good," he said.

Figures for the three months to September 30 show revenues 68% higher than the previous year at £36.4m.

Pre-tax profit doubled to £8.8m. The latest available figures on unit shipments are for the second quarter and show they have more than tripled to 107m.

Analysts had been expecting revenues of around £23m and profits of £7m, and several raised their price targets for the shares later in the day.

That helped ARM shares outperform a weak hi-tech market, with the price at the close 16p lower at 670p.

Some analysts have questioned whether ARM can maintain its rate of growth and whether it is vulnerable to any slowing in the market for mobile phone handsets. Chicago-based Motorola, one of the biggest handset manufacturers in the world, added to those fears yesterday by warning that profits would be lower than expected because the American group had overestimated the size of the handset market.

Mr Saxby said ARM's dependence on mobile telephone handsets was "much smaller than people think".

"Mobile-related sales account for 60% of our royalty sales, but royalties are only 28% of our overall revenues," he said, and royalties linked to sales of products such as smart cards, ABS braking systems in cars and consumer electronics were becoming increasingly important.

ARM-powered chips are already in 85% of the world's mobile telephones but revenues from products such as digital modems and set-top boxes are reducing its dependence on that sector and boosting overall sales, according to Arm's founder and chief executive, Robin Saxby. That helped ARM shares outperform a weak hi-tech market, with the price at the close 16p lower at 670p.
