fields.headline: Is Hurley's Hollywood life over?
fields.trailText: Liz Hurley's stop-start film career may have come to a premature end. The New York Post reports that the actress is facing expulsion from the Screen Actor's Guild, which would make working in the film industry all but impossible
fields.body:
Liz Hurley's stop-start film career may have come to a premature end, as the US braces itself for her appearance as the devil in her new comedy Bedazzled.

The New York Post reports that the actress is facing expulsion from the Screen Actor's Guild, which would make working in the film industry all but impossible. The 35-year-old Hurley attracted fierce criticism when she crossed a picket lines earlier this year to film an ad for Estee Lauder during the recent five-month long commercial actors' strike (see our news story.

Hurley apologised for her actions, claiming that as a non-resident of the US, she was unaware of the situation. "Had she known it was strike work she never would have done it," said her agent Tracey Jacobs. "She is very supportive of her union."

Union representatives however say that she will be expelled or heavily fined for crossing the line. Fellow actor Tim Robbins seemed especially incensed by the model-cum-actress's behaviour, promising an inquisitorial reception. "We're bringing [Hurley] to trial. .. She won't get away with this," he said at a New York rally last week.

The IMDb lists only one new project for the actress: Double Whammy, directed by Living In Oblivion's Tom DiCillo, co-starring Steve Buscemi and due to appear next year. Meanwhile, the US release of Bedazzled, the remake of Peter Cook's 1967 film, is due out in the US on October 20 and in the UK on November 10.

webTitle: ABC shines in US autumn ratings battle

fields.headline: ABC shines in US autumn ratings battle
fields.trailText: 10.45am US ratings: On Tuesday night it was ABC's turn to shine in the US autumn ratings battle, with the help of Geena Davis's new sitcom. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
On Tuesday night it was ABC's turn to shine in the cut-throat US autumn ratings battle, with a little help from the debut of Thelma & Louise star Geena Davis's new sitcom.

The star vehicle, imaginatively titled the Geena Davis Show and featuring Ms Davis as a glamorous career woman who falls for Thirtysomething actor Peter Horton's divorced single dad, won its 9.30pm slot and averaged a 12.9 rating/19 share.

New ABC medical drama Gideon's Crossing, which reunites Homicide creator Paul Attanasio and star Andre Braugher, also opened strongly at 10pm, with 11.8/19.

James Cameron's futuristic drama Dark Angel followed up its stellar launch last week with a promising second episode on Tuesday night, averaging 8.7/13 from 9-10pm on Fox.

CBS drama Judging Amy also returned strongly for its second season, winning the 10pm slot with 12.3/20.

Tuesday night reinforced the new season trend of the US networks' traditional fare of drama and sitcom making a comeback in the ratings, after a year when reality shows, led by Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and Survivor, have dominated.

webTitle: Discovery blasts off on 100th space shuttle flight

fields.headline: Discovery blasts off on 100th space shuttle flight
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Discovery thundered into orbit on Nasa's 100th shuttle flight, carrying seven astronauts on a crucial construction trip to the international space station.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Discovery thundered into orbit on Nasa's 100th shuttle flight, carrying seven astronauts on a crucial construction trip to the international space station.

"We're going to take a big step here. Let's go!" commander Brian Duffy called out Wednesday evening. Discovery rose from its seaside pad at 23:17pm GMT, just after sunset, on Nasa's fourth launch attempt. The shuttle had been grounded since last Thursday because of trouble with bolts, a valve, a pin and the weather.

The shuttle pierced thin, wispy clouds as it raced out over the Atlantic, its exhaust trail tinged peach, orange and red by the setting sun and surpassing the nearly full moon in brightness.

Throughout Wednesday afternoon, the sky was overcast and a waterspout was spotted a few miles from the launch pad. But the weather improved dramatically by evening, and shuttle managers gave the nod.

"All good things are worth waiting for, and I think you and your crew have waited long enough for this one," launch director Mike Leinbach told the astronauts. "Good luck on this extremely important mission to the international space station - and have fun."

Workers had to hustle to remove the small metal pin that was left on an oxygen line running between Discovery and its external fuel tank. The pin resulted in an embarrassing and costly delay for Nasa on Tuesday.

Following liftoff, Nasa Administrator Daniel Goldin singled out the sharp-eyed engineer, Jorge Rivera, who spotted the pin. "I took a look at the camera angles... it's unbelievable how you did it," Goldin said.

The space station was soaring 240 miles above the Bay of Bengal when Discovery finally soared. The chase will end with a docking on Friday.

Discovery contains two new segments for the international space station. The crew's job is to attach the girderlike truss and docking port; four spacewalks will be needed to make all the connections, beginning Sunday.

The 11-day mission has been on hold for two years, as have subsequent assembly flights, because of Russia's difficulties in launching the space station's crew quarters. The module was finally placed in orbit in July and was outfitted by a visiting space shuttle crew in September.

The truss and docking port aboard Discovery must be installed on the space station before the first permanent crew can move in. Nasa astronaut Bill Shepherd and his two-cosmonaut crew are scheduled to lift off from Kazakstan on October 30.

This will be Nasa's fifth visit to the space station. But it's the first actual construction mission since the first pieces of the complex were launched in 1998.

fields.headline: New Media Age round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date October 12.
fields.trailText: October 12: Abbey National could take legal action against MoneySupermarket and Netmortgage unless they remove its products from their services.
fields.body:
New Media Age's splash is the news that Abbey National could take legal action against mortgage comparison services MoneySupermarket and Netmortgage unless they remove Abbey products from their services. Simon Nixon, chief executive officer of MoneySupermarket, said he will see Abbey in court and is refusing to remove its products.

A headline says the Advertising Standards Authority is unveiling a kitemark, although the story talks about the Committee of Advertising Practice launching the scheme. Shoddy subbing.

Andrew Warner, marketing manager at Emap Online, is joining MSN's planned car website, Carview, as marketing director.

Priceline.com is denying that the problems it is experiencing in the US will affect its launch in Europe later this year.

The Consumer Association has said that unmetered access packages are a "recipe for confusion".

Yahoo! is launching a broadband service in France.

Website of the week is Babyworld.co.uk: "Not your run-of-the-mill parenting site." It received a whopping 95/100.

webTitle: British Deaf Association in controversial poster drive

fields.headline: British Deaf Association in controversial poster drive
fields.trailText: 10am: Britain's deaf community is giving a one-fingered salute to the government in a controversial poster campaign, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Britain's deaf community is giving a one-fingered salute to the government in a controversial poster campaign designed to get British sign language officially recognised in Westminster.

The British Deaf Association will today launch a poster drive featuring the rude hand gesture beside the line, "Westminster's attitude to recognising British sign language." The copy underneath explains that in British sign language the gesture means "idle".

Jeff McWhinney, chief executive of the BDA, said: "The BDA has had to resort to shock tactics with this campaign to get politicians to sit up and take notice. The BDA is extremely concerned about the resistance of government to extending the same linguistic rights to deaf people as those enjoyed by the hearing population."

The BDA is calling on the government to recognise British sign language under the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages. Countries that sign up to the charter are required to improve the access of minority language users to public services such as health, education and the justice system. They are also expected to promote the learning and study of minority languages.

webTitle: Barclays in Nomura portal joint venture

fields.headline: Barclays in Nomura portal joint venture
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Barclays has teamed up with Nomura to launch a joint venture shopping portal, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Banking group Barclays has teamed up with Japanese investment giant Nomura Securities to launch a joint venture shopping portal later this year.

The portal, backed by investment of £30m, will be Barclaycard-branded and aims to have 500,000 regular users by the end of 2001.

Initially, it will offer more than 1m products, including computers, gifts, travel, health, beauty, music and clothing goods, provided by 50 third-party suppliers. The service eventually aims to sign up more than 350 retailers and 5m products and expand across Europe.

Barclaycard said the portal was one of the first in a series of planned initiatives aimed at expanding its customer base.

Bob Potts, chief executive of Barclaycard, said: "Building our credentials as a major player in internet-related commerce will be a significant factor in the growth of Barclaycard over the next five to 10 years."

Barclaycard has more than 11m cards in circulation, and over 8m customers.

fields.headline: Digitas picks up PepsiCo brands
fields.trailText: 8am: PepsiCo has appointed the e-commerce consultancy, Digitas, to develop digital marketing strategies for its brands, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
PepsiCo has appointed the e-commerce consultancy, Digitas, to develop digital marketing strategies for its brands.

Digitas, which has offices in London and the US, will work across a number of PepsiCo brands including Pepsi and Tropicana. The company counts American Express, Woolworths and BT Cellnet among its clients.

David Kenny, chairman and chief executive of Digitas, said: "Every PepsiCo business is ranked either number one or number two in the world. The success of their brands is the result of superior differentiation as well as superior quality. Our goal is to assist Pepsi in leveraging their powerful brands and competitive strategies on the net."

webTitle: Regional news chiefs lobby for voice

fields.headline: Regional news chiefs lobby for voice
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Regional news chiefs are today expected to ask Chris Smith for an executive to be appointed to lobby for their interests following the reinstatement of News at Ten, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Regional news chiefs are today expected to ask the culture secretary, Chris Smith, for an executive to be appointed to lobby for their interests at a high-octane meeting following the reinstatement of News at Ten.

The biannual heads of news conference will be addressed by Mr Smith in an unprecedented move, at which he will try to soothe angry news chiefs. The announcement last month that News at Ten would be reinstated has caused fury among regional chiefs, who claim the separation of the regional bulletin from the main national news will see audiences plummeting.

ITN's editor-in-chief, Nigel Dacre, and ITV controller of documentaries, current affairs, arts and religion, Steve Anderson are also understood to be attending the meeting.

One source said: "Usually people are inhibited to speak out at these meetings, but this one will probably be more vocal." It is understood that in particular, regional chiefs want Mr Smith to appoint a head of regional news for independent television to represent their interests more vocally.

"No-one represents the interests of regional news chiefs when they have issues, and the secretary of state will be under pressure to address this," said the source.

After the move of News at Ten in 1999, ITV's regional news bulletins saw their viewing figures plummet. News managers fear that the split between the main bulletin and the regional round-ups will add to audience confusion and see figures falling further still.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date October 13.
fields.trailText: October 12: Satirical puppet-show Spitting Image is poised to make a comeback in an animated format
fields.body:
Satirical puppet-show Spitting Image is poised to make a comeback in an animated format. Independent 2DTV has been commissioned to make a ten-minute pilot to be screened next year, with a view to commissioning a full series.

The next phase of appointments at the BBC's factual and learning department confirms 21 creative directors and three managing editors under new chiefs Glenwyn Benson (controller of specialist factual programming), Jeremy Gibson (controller of documentaries) and Anne Morrison, (controller of leisure and factual entertainment). Former head of documentaries and history, Paul Hamann, is thought to have been offered a job heading a new production department by Pearson TV.

Jane Tranter has been confirmed as the BBC's head of drama commissioning, ending months of speculation. Other senior appointments include former BBC production controller of drama Susan Spindler, who becomes controller of innovation and factual drama, and former BBC drama executive producer Gareth Neame, who becomes head of drama commissioning, independents.

Granada Media chief Charles Allen has assured John Willis, head of United News and Media's production arm United Productions that the company will absorb the Bristol-based network production department of HTV.

Independent producer RDF is thought to be seeking to sell off 10% of the company in a bid to raise £3bn to invest in online rights.

And the new ITV soap Trafalgar Road is being forced to change its name, following complaints from residents of a real Trafalgar Road in south-east London.

webTitle: Channel 4 remains defiant over webcasting rights

fields.headline: Channel 4 remains defiant over webcasting rights
fields.trailText: October 12: Channel 4 is refusing to back down over its requirement that indie producers hand over all webcasting rights, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is refusing to back down over its requirement that independent producers hand over all webcasting rights, as revealed in a letter to independent producers' alliance Pact.

Pact has written to independents detailing the "minimum template" the broadcaster is offering producers for the management of online rights. The document says that "in many areas, Channel 4 has now acknowledged Pact's concerns and its position has moved considerably from its stance earlier in the year."

Channel 4 has softened its previous unwillingness to share the commercial revenue generated by websites spun off from programmes.

But the broadcaster's refusal to budge on webcasting rights could lead to further conflict. Under bandwidth restrictions, webcasting does not pose a serious risk to programme makers' ability to sell their rights around the world, but producers are worried that with the uptake of broadband this may change.

One source said: "At some stage a webcast of Channel 4 content could be available all over the world, and this could deprive producers of their rights to international sales."

The document states that the situation will be reviewed in 18 months' time.

The row broke out earlier this year after Channel 4 wrote to independents setting out its intent to take all online rights to programmes.

Indie producer Hat Trick has today resolved a dispute with the BBC over the corporation's refusal to provide a link to Hat Trick's website on its Have I Got News for You? home page.

fields.headline: Excursion rules list school guidelines
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government published detailed guidance on school trips two years ago after a series of incidents including the Lyme Bay canoeing tragedy in which four sixth formers died.
fields.body:
The government published detailed guidance on school trips two years ago after a series of incidents including the Lyme Bay canoeing tragedy in which four sixth formers died.

Although school trips are considered an essential extra dimension to work in the classroom, there are inevitably risks associated with travel and outdoor activities involving pupils at home and abroad. Schools are now required by law to carry out a risk assessment before taking children on any excursion.

The guidance published by the Department for Education sets out what group leaders are to do for a trip. It says planning is "essential" and that teachers in charge during a visit "have a duty of care to make sure that the pupils are safe and healthy". Staff on the trip also have a common law duty "to act as a reasonably prudent parent would".

Advice is given on organising activities at home and abroad, with recommendations on the number of teachers who should accompany pupils (no less than 1:10) as well as information about the law governing transport and health and safety issues. The group leader should also consider the location and type of activity, the experience of staff, the ages of the group members, their temperament and fitness, and the suitability of the activity. The seasonal conditions and timing are among the other factors group leaders should consider.

In the 1993 Lyme Bay case, four sixth formers from Southway school, Plymouth, died in what was described at the trial of the directors of the outdoor activity centre as an ill conceived and poorly executed canoe trip.

The four teachers who accompanied the pupils from Royds school belong to the National Association of School masters/Union of Women Teachers. Its general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, expressed sympathy for the bereaved families.

webTitle: CIA chief flies in as violence continues

fields.headline: CIA chief flies in as violence continues
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: The head of the US Central Intelligence Agency, George Tenet, has arrived in the Middle East to chair  a high-level security meeting to try to end two weeks of Israeli-Palestinian violence.
fields.body:
The head of the US Central Intelligence Agency, George Tenet, has arrived in the Middle East to chair a high-level security meeting to try to end two weeks of Israeli-Palestinian violence.

Despite the crack of gunfire that echoed throughout the West Bank there were signs that diplomacy to end deadly violence - now entering its third week - was having an impact.

UN Secretary General Kofi Annan said in a statement early today that "he received assurances," that Israeli and Palestinian security officials planned to meet together with their US counterparts to discuss the current unrest that has led to 91 deaths.

"The secretary-general feels this is an important step towards the cessation of violence which he hopes in turn will lead to a resumption of the peace process," the statement read.

Israel radio reported that Mr Tenet would chair the trilateral security committee created during a set of intensive negotiations outside of Washington in 1998. Israeli leader Ehud Barak said earlier in the week that he would consider allowing contacts between the sides on merit, even if the violence persisted.

Fierce West Bank gun battles in Bethlehem and Hebron continued into the small hours of Thursday. Israeli radio said the army used helicopter gunships to battle Palestinian gunmen outside of Bethlehem. An Israeli soldier shot in the stomach was evacuated near Hebron where four hours of fighting kept residents up through the night.

Israeli troops fired tank machine guns toward the village of Kufr Kalil where stone throwers and then Palestinian gunmen attacked Jewish settlers travelling to the funeral of an American-born rabbi.

Members of the new Nablus-based militia weaved in and out of narrow alleys under Israeli fire as settlers crouched behind their vehicles. Two Israeli soldiers and two Palestinians were injured.

The militia members are an offshoot of Arafat's Fatah faction in Nablus. The gunmen said they banded together to defend Palestinian towns and villages against what they said were settler rampages.

Annan extended his Mideast peace mission Wednesday, delaying a trip to Beirut - where he had hoped to help negotiate the release of three kidnapped Israeli soldiers - in favour of additional meetings with Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

The secretary-general's efforts may have had some impact. Aside from a possible security meeting, Israel came out in favour of a Mideast summit quickly to calm the situation and resume peace talks. Until now, Barak has said he would attend a summit only if Arafat took decisive steps to end the violence.

It was not clear whether Annan hoped to negotiate a formal truce or simply calm the atmosphere. The UN chief is well-respected by the Palestinians. Israel, which has traditionally considered the world body to be biased, has embraced Annan as a fair mediator.

fields.headline: Tech stocks bounce back
fields.trailText: 9.45am European tech stocks bounced back this morning after the technology-rich Nasdaq list recovered from early losses, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
European tech stocks bounced back this morning after the technology-rich Nasdaq list recovered from early losses.

The New York-based exchange closed 72.05 points down, after opening with a deficit of 88 points following indifferent results from mobile phone maker Motorola and internet portal Yahoo!

Buoyed by the good news, bargain hunters helped the FTSE 100 recover this morning after it had closed last night at its lowest level since May. The list was up 24.6 points at 6,150.10 in early trading, with the Techmark index, the benchmark of UK technology stocks, up 15.35 points at 3,455.46.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date October 13.
fields.trailText: October 12: Business Age founder Tom Rubython is reported to have linked up with Formula One overlord Bernie Ecclestone to launch a new motor racing magazine.
fields.body:
Business Age founder Tom Rubython is reported to have linked up with Formula One overlord Bernie Ecclestone to launch a new motor racing magazine that will go head-to-head with Haymarket's F1 Racing title. Called F1, the new magazine is expected to launch in time for the start of next year's Grand Prix season in February 2001. British ex-Formula One champion Nigel Mansell is said to have been signed up as a columnist; while another former champion, Niki Lauder, will be editor-in-chief.

The presenter of the last ever Monday night Panorama on the Omagh bombing, John Ware, has defended the BBC's decision to name four men suspected of carrying out the atrocity. Ware said the most important factor in deciding to transmit the investigation was the fact that under the Northern Ireland legal system any future trial would be before a judge, not a jury. He also expressed regret about Panorama's move to Sunday night, saying it would diminish the programme's impact.

The Sun has poached Sunday People news editor David Wooding, after losing three journalists this week. Columnist Ally Ross has gone to the News of the World as TV critic, former royal reporter Bill Coles is moving to World Entertainment Network as UK editor and reporter Adam Lee-Potter is going to the Scottish Daily Mail to work on features.

The Guardian Unlimited news team has moved to the Guardian's news floor, as a first step in the integration of the outfit's online and main newspaper journalists.

The BBC is considering creating a separate Newsnight-style Scottish current affairs programme following its decision to move the news to 10pm.

fields.headline: Hammer falls on Amazon/Sotheby's online auction venture
fields.trailText: 9.45am:Amazon and auction house Sotheby's have parted company, less than a year after they launched their joint online auction operation. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Amazon and auction house Sotheby's have parted company, less than a year after they launched their joint online auction operation.

The two, which linked up to sell collectibles, art and antiques, said that having two websites was confusing customers. Users had to switch between sites to see the full range of items for sale and register their credit card details twice to use the service.

From next month, visitors to the site will be directed to Sothebys.com.

The operation, run from the Sothebys.Amazon.com website, was set up as a joint venture in June 1999 when Amazon took a 1.7% share in Sotheby's for around $45m.

The terms of the new deal will see Amazon getting commission on sales from referred traffic.

The International Cricket Council has hired Porter Novelli to handle its global PR as it seeks to repair an image tarnished by match-fixing and corruption scandals.

Barclays Bank has confirmed it is embarking on a major PR drive to improve its image. The revelation follows the publication of a leaked internal report entitled Project Phoenix, in which the bank said its image had suffered major damage over the closure of local branches.

The pharmaceuticals company Novartis UK is looking for a new corporate affairs director after Fiona Fong resigned to join Bruswick PR.

Dotcoms are spending more money on PR and less on advertising, according to a survey by GFCNet.

The political transformation of Michael Portillo appears to be complete. PR Week says the shadow chancellor's press was mainly positive following his party conference speech last week.

Peter Salmon, the former controller of BBC1, has left his wife for ex Coronation Street star Sarah Lancashire . The story makes the front page. (p1)
It's "Apocalypse now" for internet companies with shares in freefall. (p16)

Journalists are "back in fashion" in America, with higher salaries and higher standards, writes Philip Delves Broughton.
Viral marketing firm Anti-Corp aims to take anti-capitalist messages to the young via viral marketing, reports Alex Benady.
Felix Dennis talks to Matt Born about the success of his men's mag Maxim in the US.

E-delivery firms like Urbanfetch and BagsofTime are rapidly running out of funds. (p4)
Tech share slides add to dot.com float delays. (p4)
Unmetered internet access has turned out to be "a nightmare" for providers and surfers alike. (p5)

A 19% drop in the value of Motorola shares has been seen as the harbinger of a slowdown in the demand for mobile phones. (p1)
E-commerce minister Patricia Hewitt has predicted that fewer than 1,000 of the UK's 6,000 local telephone exchanges would be ready for next July's deadline for local loop unbundling. (p3)
Lastminute.com has appointed Wal-Mart Europe chief Allan Leighton as its new chairman. (p25)
Enel, the Italian state-owned utility has bought telecoms group Infostrada for £6.6bn. (p25)
Bright Station is thought to be moving in on Boxman, the online CD retailer which yesterday announced that it was to go into voluntary liquidation. (p26)
German TV giant Kirch and Deutsche Telecom are poised to launch a new pay-TV alliance in Germany. Deutsche Telecom is to pay around $44m for a stake in Kirsch's technical services group. (p34)

EU clears Time Warner deal. (p1)
Motorola has cut its profit estimates, leading to fears of a mobile phone slowdown. (p1)

Peter Salmon, the former BBC1 controller, has left his wife for the former Coronation Street star Sarah Lancashire. (p3)
The teenage computer specialist who agreed to give up alcohol and have his girlfriend "vetted" for a year as part of a business contract has been rewarded. Ben Way, just turned 20, has now received the £25m-plus backing from investors he sought. (p3)

David Frankl has been ordered to pay £126,000 for an email libel. (p7)
E-tailer Boxman needs £20m to avoid liquidation. (p27)
Bertelsmann could force AOL to pay millions of dollars in compensation if their "worldwide alliance contract" is broken to satisfy EC competition rules. (p27)
Shares in worldwide advertising and marketing group WPP fell by 8% following concerns that the group was going to appoint Sir Christopher Lewinton as chairman. (p29)

The paper splashes on former BBC 1 controller Peter Salmon's departure from his marriage to start a relationship with Sarah "Raquel Watts" Lancashire. (p1)
Bra makers are understood to be "busting a gut" to sign up Judy Finnigan for adverts. (p3)

The paper reveals that SM:TV/CD:UK star Cat Deeley is poised to quit the series, and is thought to be being lined up to front the Big Breakfast. (p1)
Sharon Brown was apparently barred from appearing in TV's Stars In Their Eyes as soul singer Macy Gray, on the grounds that she is white. (p3)

The Mirror claims to have got the exclusive on Peter Salmon's dalliance with Sarah Lancashire, claiming that the pair are "so in love". (p3)
The paper reports that Tomorrow's World presenter Philippa Forrester has given birth to a son. (p14)

BBC boss Peter Salmon? (p9)

webTitle: Tranter takes BBC TV drama role

fields.headline: Tranter takes BBC TV drama role
fields.standfirst: The BBC
fields.trailText: Wednesday 5.15pm:BBC head of serials Jane Tranter will be confirmed tomorrow morning as the controller of TV drama commissioning, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC head of serials Jane Tranter will be confirmed this morning as the controller of TV drama commissioning, following months of speculation about what the job would be and who would fill it.

Ms Tranter is to continue in her current production role until a replacement is found, but after that will focus entirely on commissioning. The appointment was made jointly by director of television Mark Thompson and director of drama, entertainment and children's, Alan Yentob.

She will be responsible for commissioning both in-house and independent drama. BBC drama executive producer Gareth Neame is to take the job of head of commissioning for independents, reporting to Ms Tranter.

Ms Tranter joined the BBC drama department in 1997 from Carlton as an executive producer. Since then her executive producing credits have included Pure Wickedness, Wives and Daughters, All the Kings Men, David Copperfield and Warriors.

fields.headline: Still all to play for
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: 12 October, analysis: Following the second televised debate between the two presidential front runners, a reversal of fortune has boosted George Bush while Al Gore's "sighs and lies" are in the spotlight, reports Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
Army general staffs fight each new war on the basis of the lessons they learned in the last conflict. Politicians fight each new election according to the lessons they learned in the previous campaign. And, last night in North Carolina, Al Gore and George W Bush applied the same lesson, holding the presidential debate they failed to have in Boston a week ago.

This second debate of the presidential election season - there is one more in St Louis next week - was an altogether different contest to the one in Boston. Boston, especially in retrospect, was nervous, aggressive and riddled with tactical errors, particularly on Gore's part.

Last night's debate in Winston-Salem - the heart of tobacco country, though the issue never came up - was far more cautious and far more courteous. In many ways, it was a replica of the impeccably civilised vice-presidential debate in Kentucky last Thursday. Overall, like the veep debate, last night was a no-score draw.

Last week, the phrases that lingered in the mind were Bush's charge of "fuzzy math" and Gore's condemnation of tax cuts for "the wealthiest one per cent". Both phrases sat out the whole 90 minutes in Winston-Salem, although Gore twice talked about tax cuts for "the wealthiest of the wealthy". Last night, though, the most commonly repeated phrase from both men was the one the voters liked most in the Cheney-Lieberman vice-presidential contest - "I agree with you."

Coming into last night's debate, all the talk was about how Gore had blown it in Boston with his "sighs and lies" - audibly huffing and puffing in exasperation at Bush's answers and then embellishing the facts on a number of his own replies. By yesterday, most opinion polls had registered a small but significant shift to Bush as a result.

From the off, Gore made clear by his demeanour that he was not going to commit the same mistakes in Winston-Salem. When Bush was answering, Gore looked down at the table, disciplined and expressionless. In most of his answers Gore was more succinct and less rambling than before. The porkies - if there were any - were small ones, and the vice-president went out of his way to apologise for getting his facts wrong in Boston.

There were new themes last night that got no airing in the first debate. Race, a much criticised omission in the Boston debate, was prominent this time, with Gore trying to put some clear water between himself and Bush on issues like banning racial profiling by police, supporting affirmative action programmes and passing hate crimes legislation.

Most Republican congressmen are opposed to these ideas, but you would never have guessed so from Bush's tactics - to agree as much as possible and to avoid getting dragged into disagreements on the issues.

Fully 40 minutes of the debate concentrated on foreign affairs - even though the issue never comes up on the candidates' campaign stops. There was a substantial exchange on guns, too, another mostly silent issue on the campaign trail. But the most dramatic exchanges came when Gore tried to hammer Bush's record as Texas governor, charging that Texas was 49th out of 50 US states in the proportion of children and mothers with medical insurance, and 50th for families. For the only time in the evening, Bush looked a bit rattled.

At the end, the two men shook hands and sent their lieutenants out of the hall to try to persuade the media that each of them had won the debate. That task was probably easier for Bush, who emerged from the second debate looking relaxed and unscathed. When you are in the lead and have a lot of money in the bank, a draw will do quite nicely.

By that same token, a draw probably wasn't quite good enough for Gore, even though it will have steadied his side's nerves after Bush's post-Boston surge. Gore seemed to give few hostages to fortune, but at the same time he failed to make the kind of impact on Bush's record that his team were looking for. Gore desperately needs a good week on the campaign trail. Possibly, the Texas record will be his deliverance.

The great lesson of the 2000 presidential campaign, though, is never to underestimate the set piece moments. After years of being told how the party conventions and the presidential debates had now become purely ritual, without any political substance, this year has proved the know-alls wrong time after time. The conventions were both turning points, and so was the Boston debate.

Winston-Salem seemed to be a stand-off. But this means that there is all to play for. The final debate in St Louis next week now looks even more pivotal than it did before.

Gore desperately needs a good week on the campaign trail. Possibly, the Texas record will be his deliverance. The great lesson of the 2000 presidential campaign, though, is never to underestimate the set piece moments. After years of being told how the party conventions and the presidential debates had now become purely ritual, without any political substance, this year has proved the know-alls wrong time after time. The conventions were both turning points, and so was the Boston debate. Winston-Salem seemed to be a stand-off. But this means that there is all to play for. The final debate in St Louis next week now looks even more pivotal than it did before.

webTitle: BBC News 24 goes head-to-head with Sky

fields.headline: BBC News 24 goes head-to-head with Sky
fields.standfirst: The nine o'clock news - from Sky
fields.trailText: 8am: BBC News 24 is taking on Sky's new 9pm bulletin by launching an hour-long, live news programme fronted by Gavin Esler and Carrie Grace, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC News 24 is taking on Sky's new 9pm bulletin with an hour-long, live news programme fronted by Gavin Esler and Carrie Grace.

From next week, the BBC will broadcast 60 minutes of live news from 9-10pm.

The BBC's head of television news, Roger Mosey, said: "We've made News 24 the heartland of the BBC's news viewing. The figures suggest that on days where there are big stories breaking, there's a good argument for doing live news between 9pm and 10pm."

He denied that he would be cannibalising his own audience for the BBC's new 10pm news, saying that at the moment "virtually nobody" watches bulletins at both 9pm and 10pm.

The move coincides with Wednesday's announcement from Sky that it will run a half-hour news programme at 9pm fronted by Jeremy Thompson.

webTitle: Eskandarian takes top job at new Havas network

fields.headline: Eskandarian takes top job at new Havas network
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Ed Eskandarian, head of Arnold Worldwide, has been named chairman and CEO of Arnold Worldwide Partners, the new global network from Havas Advertising. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Ed Eskandarian, head of Arnold Worldwide, has been named chairman and CEO of Arnold Worldwide Partners, the new global network from Havas Advertising.

Havas announced the formal launch of the network earlier this month.

It will consist of nine agencies around the world, including Ata De Martini in Italy, devarrieuxvillaret in France, La Banda in Spain, Rempen & Partner in Germany and WCRS in the UK.

The agencies were all members of the European network, Campus, prior to the acquisition of the Snyder Group by Havas last month.

The purchase of Snyder allowed Arnold to enter the network, completing a transatlantic line-up.

Other key markets are also represented by agencies age in Brazil, Partners BDDH in the UK and Vickers & Benson in Canada. Further acquisitions are expected in the Far East and Australia.

Mr Eskandarian said: "There is a new breed of international clients searching for the highest standards of creativity and the passion that comes from strong entrepreneurial agencies. This is the first network that gives those clients that creativity combined with traditional network strength and cohesion."

fields.headline: Brown ponders deal with hauliers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is considering plans to cut diesel fuel duty as part of a wider deal to appease hauliers, which will involve restructuring the road haulage industry.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is considering plans to cut diesel fuel duty as part of a wider deal to appease hauliers, which will involve restructuring the road haulage industry.

Government ministers are still unpersuaded of the need to cut fuel duty for the general motorist. They are also deeply sceptical of the practicality of plans, widely supported by Scottish Labour, to offer cheaper vehicle exercise duty for the rural motorist.

Ministerial sources said last night that the chancellor wants to modernise the haulage industry, including investment in new computers and a crackdown on illegal foreign lorries operating in this country. Transport ministers have been studying the possiblity of increasing the cost of hauliers' entry licence from £6,000 to £20,000 in an effort to stop new entrants with little financial backing undercutting existing operators. Signs that the chancellor is willing to make some concession, in response to high fuel prices and last month's protests, emerged when it was confirmed that Mr Brown held a meeting with hauliers in Leeds last Friday.

The ad hoc group of 10 large and small hauliers had been convened by the transport minister, Lord MacDonald. The hauliers were surprised to see that the peer was accompanied by Mr Brown.

The treasury insisted that the meeting had not been secret and the chancellor had himself referred to the meeting in broadcast interviews in Wales this week.

In another indication that Mr Brown is willing to act, the treasury confirmed that the pre-budget report will be published around October 30, well before the end of the 60-day deadline set by the road hauliers at the end of their protest.

Mr Brown is under conflicting pressure from lobbying groups on how to act. The Freight Transport Assocation (FTA), the Society of Motor Manufacturers, the National Farmers' Union and the Confederation of British Industry will meet on Monday to try to finalise an unprecedented joint submission on cuts in diesel duty.

The FTA has been pressing for a 15p cut in diesel duty, which would cost the chancellor £1.5bn a year. They are also pressing for further cuts in the heavy lorries' vehicle excise duty and some form of tax on foreign hauliers using British roads. The legality of such a tax might be challenged by the EU.

Mr Brown is facing a difficult political judgment in deciding whether to centre the cuts on the road haulage industry or the general motorist. However, ministerial sources indicated last night that the bulk of the help will go to the farming and haulage industry.

Mr Brown is also being pressed to cut the annual road tax for drivers in rural areas to £45, but the treasury believes there are huge administrative difficulties, including exactly how to designate a rural area. The idea was also met with a cool response from motoring organisations yesterday.

Lobbyists want a £110 discount on the £155 vehicle excise duty on cars over 1200cc for motorists living in the Scottish Highlands, mid-Wales and remote parts of England. The cut could be implemented by examining the motorists' postcode.

Calum Macdonald, the Labour MP for Western Isles who has been pressing for cuts in rural fuel duty for more than a year, said: "I believe a postcode concession targeted at the most disadvantaged of our rural communities would be seen as fair. It is in these communities that low income households are most dependent on car transport. When a tax grows from being relatively small to fourth largest, it is inevitable that public tolerance comes under strain unless it is adjusted and adapted to make it be seen to be fair".

The proposal would have the advantage of bringing down the cost of motoring for farmers and rural drivers, who have been among the hardest hit by recent rises in petrol prices.

The AA warned that the scheme could be exploited by owners of second homes who could use their rural addresses to register cars.

fields.bylineHtml: Patrick Wintour, chief political correspondent

fields.headline: It's good to talk
fields.standfirst:
But Mr Brown should beware of promises

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is not the hair-shirted ascetic he is often painted. Street-wise would probably be going too far. But if he is now all ears to the the hauliers, it is a welcome sign of a politician who understands the need to act when the time is ripe.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is not the hair-shirted ascetic he is often painted. Street-wise would probably be going too far. But if he is now all ears to the the hauliers, it is a welcome sign of a politician who understands the need to act when the time is ripe. Those around him who have been ramping up divisions with Number 10 should be told to keep their hands off this one. Spinning is dangerous, stoking expectations of a sharp and immediate cut in the cost of using the roads for the aggrieved groups of September's protest. The pre-budget statement is less a constitutional document than a wish list. Mr Brown can use it to palliate without committing himself in detail. But he must also clearly articulate principles, such as the planetary necessity of taxing non- renewable fuel consumption.

Indeed Dunfermline's dour man must not be too generous. The real cost of motoring has been stable for decades - taking into account cost of buying vehicles, insurance and the rest. The case for making it cheaper, Opec notwithstanding, has not been made. The road haulage industry faces structural problems. It may have too many small contractors. Mr Brown will want to distinguish tax on vehicle ownership from taxing con sumption through the fuel duty. He will hesitate to increase the subsidy to people who happen to live in the "country". There are tried and tested measures of sparsity which might, conceivably, be used as the basis for helping far-flung road users. John Prescott has a brand new index of social deprivation. It plainly shows the poor live in cities; a chancellor, rightly concerned in his pensions policy to help the neediest most, should not forget that demographic fact.

Mr Brown has the resources for a two-pronged attack on the genuine causes of September's discontents. The Tory proposal to cut 3p per litre off fuel duty would save a motorist doing 5,000 miles a year the princely sum of £18. The Treasury could instead cut £50 off vehicle excise duty for cars with engines smaller than 1800cc - at one and the same time doing his duty by the environment and benefiting drivers who tend to be older and living in rural districts on moderate incomes. The public's unwillingness to do the basic arithmetic of their car use would make it hard to sell such a policy. But his room for fiscal manoeuvre is wide and deep, as long as perky inflation figures do not give the Bank of England cause for interest rate concern.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Lost data | On the cards
fields.body:
Lost data
Twice in the past two years I have lost my hard drive due to it becoming corrupted. Happily, I had backed up most of my data files, but I have been unable to back up my address book in the Contacts folder in Microsoft Outlook. The reason is that I cannot find it! So I end up having to retype my address book which is, to say the least, quite a chore. Fred Brooks
fred@redgrave.screaming.net

Jack Schofield replies: Nowadays, Outlook keeps the addressbook in its .pst file, and if you search for *.pst files, you may find your address data in the same folder.

However, your question highlights the fact that just backing up disk drives is not enough for important data. You should also export it into a separate file, so that if you lose the use of Outlook, or whatever, you can load the same data into a different program.

Outlook's File|Export to a File|Personal Folder File wizard will export your addresses in a number of formats including Comma Separated Values (ie text), Excel, and the dBase and Access databases.

Getting addresses into another program can be tricky as you have to map the field names in the data file to the field names in the new program, and they never match. However, it is not as bad as having to retype everything.

Ideally, addresses should be held in the standard business card data format called vCard, in .vcf files (See www.imc.org/pdi/vcardoverview.html ), which are recognised by both PCs and Apple Macintoshes and are also used on the web (by Yahoo, for example). That removes the mapping problem. Unfortunately, I don't know of a program that will export a whole addressbook that way.

As a journalist I am justifiably paranoid about losing my addressbook data, so I also synchronise my Outlook Contacts database with two handheld computers and two websites, including Yahoo, for an "off site" back-up.

On the cards
I would like to print some visiting cards. Do you know of an application that would be useful or do I just work it out on my WP? Rosalind Pulver
ros.mart@tesco.net

JS: It is certainly possible to produce all kinds of cards in a word processor. And if you need lots, you may be able exploit your program's label printing facility (in Microsoft Word 200: Tools|Envelopes and Labels|Labels).

However, there are a lot of utilities designed for producing business cards, which may do what you want. Business Card Designer Plus http://camdevelopment.com/bcdp.htm and Visual Business Cards seem to be the most popular, and the alternatives include Paraben's Business Card Builder and Klick-N-View Business Cards. For a quick listing from a long search term, see http://hotfiles.zdnet.com/cgi-bin/texis/swlib/ hotfiles/mlt.html?link=1&Utext= dtp+windows+soho+cards+template+design+print+business.

Most utilities are available free for a 30-day trial period.

Background
Control/At/Delete will pop up a window showing current running programs, many of which are in the "background" and perhaps started automatically on startup. They all have incomprehensible names and it is difficult/impossible to tell which program they represent. Also, there seem to be many more of them than programs in the Startup folder. Is there any way of getting a plain English explanation of these programs or preventing them loading up in the first place? John Pendlebury
Johnpend@dialstart.net

JS: On a standalone PC running Windows, the task list should normally have only two programs: Systray and Explorer. Most, or all, of the others should be associated with utilities that have icons in the Systray, next to the clock on the right hand side of the Task Bar. These could include programs such as ICQ and ZoneAlarm.

If you right-click on the icons, these should allow you to configure them so they don't run when you start your machine.

If there are any background programs you can't identify, open Windows Explorer at the C:\ drive or My Computer. Press F3 for the search box (or use Tools|Find|Files and Folders) and enter the name shown in the task list (for example, sysmon). This should find the associated programs for you.

Some background programs are useful but if you have too many of them, they can consume a lot of valuable system resources. Go to Start| Programs|Accessories|System Tools|Resource Meter to find out how much: and yes, it will load and sit in your Systray!

Background programs may also clash with one another, making your PC less stable.

Extension
I am writing Java programs and saving them in Microsoft Notepad with the suffix "java". However, my problem is that by default it adds ".txt" on the end. When I try to run the program through the compiler, it reads "bad command or file name". Ashley Wright
ashe.wright@tinyworld.co.uk

JS: Go to the data directory where you keep your files (so the directory name is highlighted) and pull down the File|New|Text Document menu to create a new text document. Give it a new name, such as test.java

You will be asked if you want to change the extension: say yes.

Double-click your new file, and a pop-up box will ask you which application you would like to open the file. Scroll down the list and select Notepad (and keep the box ticked for "Always use this program to open this file").

Now type some Java code into the test.java file and save it (Alt-F Alt-S), and it will still be a .java file.

Disk saver
I would like to compress my 1 gigabyte C: drive as I'm running out of space. Is there a safe way of doing it? Andy Brodie
arbpc@yahoo.co.uk

JS: The disk compression software provided with Windows should be safe, but I would not use it myself. Huge hard drives are now so cheap (under £100) that compression is no longer worth the risk. If you can't justify a new drive, second hand ones are available for a few pounds. A drive that re-formats with no bad sectors can be added as drive D.

Reprise
Since I upgraded to Internet Explorer 5.5, all new windows in Outlook Express open up very small. How can I make them open up maximised as they always used to? Dr Kambiz Boomla
k.boomla@qmw.ac.uk

JS: Sorry, when I answered this question last time, my reply was too brief. So....

Windows programs usually try to remember how they were when you closed them, and then open up the same way. To make a window open differently, use your mouse to grab the bottom right hand corner and drag the window to the size and shape you want. Close the window and open it again: it should open the way you want.

If you really want a window maximized, then click on the middle button on the top right of window.

fields.headline: 'Free as the air we breathe'
fields.standfirst: You don't need planning permission or a licence to build a network. Sean Dodson looks at how two people aim to break down the 'digital divide'
fields.trailText: You don't need planning permission or a licence to build a network. Sean Dodson looks at how two people aim to break down the 'digital divide'.
fields.body:
Using an aerial, a lightning conductor, a floppy disk and a microwave transceiver little bigger than a credit card, a pair of techies are hoping to beat the world's big telecommunication companies and launch the first broadband wireless internet in the UK.

James Stevens and Julian Priest of Consume.net represent a growing group of people who believe that the internet should be as free as the air we breath - and they are planning to make it so.

Everyone, they say, should have the right to access to the internet because the net is too valuable a thing to be owned by small groups of organisations, ie the big telecommunications companies. They believe that the network should be owned by its users, and it should be free. The current economic and regulatory framework is too slow, they say, and too expensive and is the cause of what is now being called the "digital divide".

The scheme will be piloted later this month in Shoreditch, east London. It involves the creation of a "data cloud" - a wireless internet network distributed through the radio spectrum. The technology is already commercially available and, as long as the network is used for non-commercial basis, no licences will be needed, say the pair.

Stevens says: "We have already established three sites for antennas or nodes - which are omnidirectional send and receive stations. Once people have the wireless cards in their laptops they will be able to connect with our networks." These first three nodes, adds Stevens, are enough to generate a data cloud. The right cards for laptops are called 802.11 or wireless Ethernet and are available from companies like Lucent Technologies for as little as £150.

Of course, the pair cannot build a network on their own. So last month they invited others to participate in its building and design. The response so far has been promising. Nearly 400 have already joined the mailing list. These include the chief executive of a leading UK internet service provider (ISP) and several high-end technologists. Already, another node is being developed in north London, and Medium Rare is building its own at London Bridge. The pair say that anyone can set up a node and that it can cost as little as £350.

The initial nodes will rely on connections to the "outside" internet - which will still have to be paid for. But the pair see no reason why the network cannot stand alone once it has grown big enough.

The idea for the network began in 1995. Then, Stevens had just co-founded Lateral, one of the UK's first web design agencies. Lateral was leasing a two megabyte connection from a business park in north London at a cost of £200,000 a year. Stevens found that he was using a mere quarter of the bandwidth and wanted to redistribute the spare capacity to the other creative groups in his neighborhood. One of those groups was web designer, Medium Rare, whose technical director is Julian Priest.

The trouble was that they were housed in the building opposite and it is illegal to string a cable across a street in the UK.

So, Priest went out and bought a pair of microwave transponders for £300, similar to those found in mobile phones, and hooked up to Lateral's bandwidth with a wireless connection. The pair say that the idea for a city-wide network came from there.

"The whole environment of communications is very tightly controlled. Because that's where the power is, especially these days," says Priest. "That's the reason why we couldn't hang a wire across the street.

"The good thing about what we are doing now is that you don't need planning permission to build our network. And you don't need a licence." This is because they plan to operate on the part of the radio spec trum usually used by CB enthusiasts.

The data cloud, they say, is not the internet for free, but the internet in return for participation. Although the protocols are still to be thrashed out, they will give access only to those prepared to build a node. The nodes work by both transmitting and receiving large amounts of data. This means that those participating in the creation of the data cloud are effectively sharing bandwidth. So, although technically feasible, simply buying the correct PC card will not be enough.

Beyond that, the group hopes to connect local networks and get backbones between local networks running under their own rules. Similar networks are already under way in Sweden and the US. Consume is constructing a legal framework that will be built into its software that will define how resources should be shared, "both inside and outside the network", says Stevens.

To Stevens in particular - who for years ran Backspace, the UK's first digital access space - the point of all this is to allow people to produce their own media.

"This has been possible for some time," he says. "But the missing link has always been issue of connectivity. It is easy to stream media between two people, but to stream to 10 people is already beyond the bandwidth of most users. So we have stepped in to give people the idea that it is within their own capabilities to develop a network of their own."

It was because of this desire that they got fed up waiting for the big telcos to get their wireless networks together. Also, the government's auction of bandwidth has driven the price up to a point where any successful bidder will have to make so much money out of it that the chances of a fast cheap public access network emerging are virtually nil. At no point do they ever mention the desire to make any money from Consume - they operate as a strictly non-profit making organisation.

"We are just trying to build in the scraps of what's left," says Priest. "But we believe that there is more than enough. And if we can populate the space with free public access networks - then we might even provide some competition for the big telecommunications companies."

webTitle: Town 'under water' as floods hit South

fields.headline: Town 'under water' as floods hit South
fields.standfirst:
Special report: weather watch
Map
fields.trailText: Life-threatening levels of flooding cut a swathe across southern England this morning after a reported deluge of up to six inches of rain last night.
fields.body:
Life-threatening levels of flooding cut a swathe across southern England this morning after a reported deluge of up to six inches of rain last night.

A man was plucked to safety from fast-flowing floodwaters early today after torrential rain inundated hundreds of homes and caused traffic chaos.

The night of unceasing rain left much of east and west Sussex under water and several main roads impassable.

Police said the man had been swept away by floodwater outside Somerfield's store in High Street, Uckfield, east Sussex, shortly before 7.20am. One eyewitness said: "Uckfield is under water".

A search was launched before Solent Coastguard's rescue helicopter, India Juliet, was sent to the scene.

Twenty minutes later the man was spotted in the River Uck, which had burst its banks, close to a sewage works.

He was pulled shivering from the river by a ground-based coastguard team and flown to the Princess Royal Hospital in Haywards Heath, suffering from shock and cold.

Every available fire crew in east Sussex was this morning taking part in a massive operation to pump flood water from properties while Environment Agency workers tried to keep swollen rivers free flowing.

The River Teise and Lesser Teise and the River Beult in Kent were put on "Severe Flood Warnings" - which means imminent risk to life and property.

Several drivers were stranded on flooded main roads and police asked owners of four-wheel-drive vehicles to help out if they pass motorists in difficulty.

Uckfield was among the worst hit areas after more than 100 millimetres (3.9 inches) of rain in the past 24 hours.

Weather experts warned there could be another 40mm (1.5ins) to come in the next eight hours. Other areas badly hit by the floods include Haywards Heath, Hassocks and Steyning in west Sussex and Tonbridge in Kent.

A spokesman for AA Roadwatch said: "The police have been putting out so many road flood warning signs in Sussex that they have run out."

webTitle: Grieving settlers are determined to stay put

fields.headline: Grieving settlers are determined to stay put
fields.standfirst:
Violence rages around the funeral of a rabbi in the West Bank while Jewish-Arab tensions flare up in France
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian gunmen fired on cars arriving at the funeral of an American-born settler in the West Bank yesterday, hardening the resolve of a Jewish community that has been defiantly living on the edge for years.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Psagot, West Bank
fields.body:
Palestinian gunmen fired on cars arriving at the funeral of an American-born settler in the West Bank yesterday, hardening the resolve of a Jewish community that has been defiantly living on the edge for years.

With combat helicopters circling overhead, and amid the distant crackle of machine-gun fire, bulletproofed buses unloaded hundreds of Jewish settlers at Elon Moreh, the adopted home of Rabbi Hillel Lieberman, whose brutally beaten body was discovered at the weekend.

He is believed to have been abducted after he tried to stop Palestinians tearing apart the Jewish pilgrimage site of Joseph's tomb in Nablus, to the north of Elon Moreh.

The tomb has been a constant flashpoint during a fortnight of bloodshed. For the mourners yesterday, its destruction was a symbol of the Palestinians' refusal to accept their presence in Israel.

"We are shocked, we are saddened, we are angry," said Hindy Cohen, one of the mourners bused in from the Psagot settlement, who watched the rabbi's body being laid to rest at Yitzar, another nearby Jewish outpost on occupied Palestinian land. But Ms Cohen insisted she was unafraid.

"We are going to stay here; you can see it on the faces of everyone at the funeral," she said. "This is a Jewish country, it is the land God gave to Israel, and the Arabs have to accept that this is where we belong."

As she and some 200,000 other Jews living in settlements in the West Bank and Gaza see it, this is the fulfilment of a pioneer dream: they are turning the words of the Bible into a 21st century truth. However, most Israelis dismiss the mainly religious settlers as dangerous extremists.

For the Palestinians, the existence of Jewish settlements ranks among the greatest humiliation of the occupation. As the pitched battles between Israeli armour and stone-throwing Palestinian youths begin to taper off, both sides are reporting a new twist - civilians killing civilians.

Earlier this week, a senior Palestinian official, Hassan Asfour, said the settlers "must now be a target for every Palestinian in order to stop their terrorism, and they must be uprooted from our Palestinian-occupied land".

Lieberman was the second Jewish civilian to die, a death that has been avenged many times by settlers, who have stoned Palestinian cars in the West Bank, shot at Palestinian homes on the outskirts of Jerusalem and beaten, shot and abducted several Palestinian men.

In that increasingly ugly struggle, Psagot, perched on a hill barely 150 metres from the West Bank city of Ramallah, is on the frontline. Overlooking the ridge where Israeli troops are now dug in, a handful of armoured personnel carriers guards the approach roads, and cement blocks surround the local creche.

A ban on Palestinians entering the Jewish state has been extended indefinitely, transforming some 2.3m people into virtual prisoners in the West Bank and Gaza, and cutting them off from jobs in Israel that are the lifeline for the community.

Meanwhile, the 240 Jewish families of Psagot prepare for war. Their defences did not stop their tidy red-roofed homes from being hit by Palestinian sniper fire during several days and nights of shooting.

Even before their homes were in the line of fire, the people of Psagot were deeply suspicious of Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister. In July, when there was talk of peace, this isolated settlement was among those destined to be handed over to Palestinian control.

Now, amid the bloodshed, there is evident satisfaction that those days are gone, and that in this fortnight of violence the Palestinians have lost more than 90 souls.

fields.headline: Going down
fields.standfirst:
The failures

Net news
fields.trailText: This year has been a grim one for the internet fraternity; the problems at Boxman.com are just the latest.
fields.body:
This year has been a grim one for the internet fraternity; the problems at Boxman.com are just the latest.

While sports fashion e-tailer Boo.com made the biggest headlines when it ceased trading in May, there have been others since.

Earlier this month Powernet Telecom , the internet company chaired by the Marquess of Huntly, was forced into receivership with debts of £30m.

Before this, Callnet , the internet service provider, went into administration and was forced to bring in BDO Stoy Hayward to try to find a trade buyer.

Leisureplanet.com , a travel site, went the same way and Clickmango, the health e-tailer, was forced to cease trading earlier this year.

Even ventures with heavyweight support have found the going hard. Efdex , backed by IBM and Dell, closed its UK arm and despite Disney backing Toysmart.com fell by the wayside.

webTitle: Business: Hoover's Online sweeps into Europe

fields.headline: Hoover's Online sweeps into Europe
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Hoover's Online, the American company that provides business information both on and off line, launches its European business in London today.
fields.body:
Hoover's Online, the American company that provides business information both on and off line, launches its European business in London today.

The company has more than 3m customers through the internet and provides information to professionals, such as City traders, investors and journalists, and students.

Patrick Spain, president and chief operating officer of Hoover's Online, said: "We are trying to revolutionise the way people get their jobs done by using this information and this technology."

Hoover's Online is expanding into London first because the lack of a language barrier means people can access the 65,000 companies which have already been researched and profiled by the company.

With Hoover's Online planning to open similar services in Germany, France, Italy and Spain during the next four months, London is also seen as a good springboard for the rest of Europe.

The company, which has a 10-year track record in the United States, provides research on businesses. The information ranges from brief overviews of companies to summaries of their activities and their competitors along with in-depth profiles.

According to the company, Hoover's Online business researchers have looked at more than 10,000 UK-listed and private companies. British users, 60,000 of whom are already using Hoover's Online's information, will also have access to its global service.

Gehan Talwatte, managing director of Hoover's Online Europe, said: "Launching Hoover's Online in Europe means our European specialists can deliver new research on European companies direct to millions of desktops here.

"We can offer useful new services to help business people in Europe do their jobs more effectively."

fields.headline: Leighton joins Lastminute
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Allan Leighton, the former boss of Asda and one of the most successful executives in British retailing, yesterday gave the youthful founders of Lastminute.com a huge boost by agreeing to become the company's non-executive chairman.
fields.body:
Allan Leighton, the former boss of Asda and one of the most successful executives in British retailing, yesterday gave the youthful founders of Lastminute.com a huge boost by agreeing to become the company's non-executive chairman.

Mr Leighton, who last month quit as president of the European division of Asda's owner, Wal-Mart, to build a portfolio of jobs, pledged to take a hands-on role at the company and give it "as much time as it takes".

"At the moment the company is in an unusual position where it is outperforming its plan but the share price is not. Everyone is still having difficulty valuing these firms but if value is based on performance the share price should be picking up. The winners in this business will be those with the best brand, people and execution - and Lastminute has plenty of that," he said yesterday.

The appointment is Mr Leighton's first since leaving Wal-Mart. He is already a non-executive director of BSkyB and Leeds Sporting. He is expected to announce other roles over the next month.

Mr Leighton will not be paid a fee for his role, but has been granted options over 1m shares, exercisable at 137.5p at various stages over the next three years.

He said a main aim would be to bring forward profitability at the company, which analysts forecast will not break even until 2003. "Getting to break-even would be a huge psychological boost," Mr Leighton said. "To do that we have to continue to grow the business and hit our targets. The market can be pretty unforgiving if you don't."

Mr Leighton agreed to join Lastminute less than one month after being approached by co-founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox. "Brent and Martha are exceptionally talented people, they work hard and have developed a compelling business model."

Capturing an executive of Mr Leighton's experience and profile is a coup for Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox. Although widely regarded as bright and able, their inexperience has been cited by some investors as a reason why they would not buy shares in the company.

"We are thrilled that someone with Allan's track record of leadership in customer-focused businesses is joining Lastminute.com," said Ms Lane Fox.

"Allan is someone we have respected for a long time. From the moment we started speaking to him his ability to cut through all the rubbish that has been said about us and pinpoint what this company is about became apparent."

One of his tasks will be to help improve customer service. Several clients have complained about technical problems affecting its website, although the company reported record sales for July and August. A more advanced version of the site is due to start operating shortly, after a delay of several months.

"We know there are issues with technology but they can be resolved," Mr Leighton said. "If there weren't problems there wouldn't be anything to improve on."

The market's initial response to Mr Leighton's appointment was muted. He has previously been linked with top jobs at retail firms and each time the speculation surfaced the share prices of those companies rose sharply. Yet Lastminute shares remained relatively stable, slipping 9p to 128p. Analysts said that, given the huge sell-off of technology stocks taking place in the wider market, Lastminute had performed credibly. The shares are still well below the issue price of 380p and high of 555p, however.

Ms Lane-Fox said she was not disappointed that the market had failed to react more positively to the announcement. "We haven't brought in Allan just for a short-term kick to the share price, we want him for his vision and for capacity to think back to the customer."

Lastminute.com's present chairman, Pieter Bouw, will become a non-executive director when Mr Leighton takes over on October 20.

fields.headline: IT may be secret of painless growth
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The government's failure to measure accurately the impact of the IT revolution could be leading to systematic mistakes about the economy's ability to grow without igniting inflation, one of the Bank of England's leading policymakers will say today.
fields.body:
The government's failure to measure accurately the impact of the IT revolution could be leading to systematic mistakes about the economy's ability to grow without igniting inflation, one of the Bank of England's leading policymakers will say today.

In a controversial speech to be delivered in the City, Sushil Wadhwani will say that businesses may be using twice as much computer hardware and software as official statistics suggest, resulting in under-recorded increases in productivity.

Dr Wadhwani will say the mistake in measuring productivity growth could stem from a failure by the office for national statistics to take full account of rapidly falling prices for IT equipment, which means that the volume of equipment bought has been underestimated.

Together with intensified competition and a more flexible labour market, the failure to detect improved productivity may be one reason why the economy has consistently performed better than expected since 1992.

Pointing to the important role of new technology in boosting US productivity and the true extent of British investment in IT, he says it is "rather puzzling" that a similar upturn has not been detected in Britain.

"More research is needed, but, as a policymaker, it is important to be alive to the possibility that measured productivity growth numbers significantly understate actual growth," Dr Wadhwani will say.

Dr Wadhwani's comments, to be delivered at a seminar organised by HSBC, help to explain his refusal to vote for higher interest rates in recent months. However, it is understood that his decision to go public has proved controversial with some colleagues.

fields.headline: 300p a share 'will buy Freeserve'
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Freeserve is at the centre of renewed takeover bid speculation after the American investment bank JP Morgan last night predicted that Britain's leading internet service provider could be taken over for about 300p a share.
fields.body:
Freeserve is at the centre of renewed takeover bid speculation after the American investment bank JP Morgan last night predicted that Britain's leading internet service provider could be taken over for about 300p a share.

That price values Freeserve at £3bn - almost half the sum its parent company, Dixons, was reported to be seeking in the summer when it was in sale talks with Germany's T-Online. Freeserve shares have declined sharply since the talks collapsed and last night closed down 1.25p at 209p.

Jamie Wood, an internet analyst at JP Morgan, said he expected Freeserve and Dixons to be open to new talks to merge Freeserve with another pan-European ISP or portal, or a British telecommunications or media company.

He said Freeserve's long-term business model appeared unsustainable and despite an impressive management team it was what he described as "a house built of straw".

"Freeserve represents the key asset in a consolidating sector and an auction could ensue. In a sale scenario we believe Freeserve would fetch 300p a share. It has major strategic problems - there are no language obstacles or cultural barriers to US entrants, the business lacks scale and it has a brand associated with free access."

T-Online and Wanadoo of France have been mooted as suitors. American players such as AOL and Yahoo, or a British group like cable firm NTL could also enter the fray.

Freeserve is the only leading European ISP not backed by a telecoms group, even though Dixons's ability to pre-install Freeserve in its PCs has been crucial in sales.

"Without telco parentage and with limited proven usage of its portal, the move into broadband and mobile distribution is costly and rife with execution risk," Mr Wood said.
