webTitle: Business: Boxman races against time for survival

fields.headline: Boxman races against time for survival
fields.standfirst:
But here's a struggling start-up with one week to raise £20m

Net news
fields.trailText: Tony Salter, chief executive of Boxman.com, yesterday warned that his online CD retailing company had less than two weeks to find a purchaser or face oblivion.
fields.body:
Tony Salter, chief executive of Boxman.com, yesterday warned that his online CD retailing company had less than two weeks to find a purchaser or face oblivion.

A creditors' meeting will be called for the week beginning October 23 after the Boxman website was shut down on Monday night and trading halted. Approval will be sought at the meeting to put the company into voluntary liquidation.

Mr Salter is already in advanced discussions with one venture capital group in his attempts to raise £20m. The e-tailer remains confident a deal can be struck but it has to be done quickly.

"We are in talks with a company which is fully aware of what Boxman is and what the assumptions of the market are but time is really against us. We must get the [web] site back up and running by Friday week. You cannot put an operating company into mothballs," Mr Salter said.

The former oil engineer who went on to head EMI's operations in eastern Europe blamed the company's inability to raise more money on investors taking a negative blanket approach to business-to-consumer - B2C - organisations.

This is the third high-profile e-tailer - the others being clothing groups Boo.com and Dressmart.com - to hit serious financial problems this year as investors become increasingly jittery about the technology sector.

Boo.com collapsed in May and Dressmart.com sought court protection against its creditors in July. All three ventures were started in Sweden.

Analysts warned that the problems at Boxman were a public example of the kind of difficulties being faced behind the scenes by many other online businesses.

"For some dot.coms the writing has been on the wall for months. You either raise additional funding or gently fade away," said Peter Bradshaw, technology analyst with Merrill Lynch.

The Boxman venture was acknowledged to be well run and was backed by prominent figures such as Suggs from pop group Madness and Marie Fredriksson of Swedish rock group Roxette. Bernard Arnault, from French luxury goods group LVMH, was an investor and Alain Levy, a former chief executive of PolyGram, was a non-executive director.

Boxman was recenly supported by some notable blue chip institutions such as ABN Amro, GE Europe and Lehman Brothers.

Formed in 1997, the company forged a groundbreaking cross-promotion deal with music video channel MTV and merged with British online home entertainment group iMVS.com.

But in May it was forced to abandon a £300m London stock market flotation as the climate for technology stocks cooled.

The 120 Boxman staff - including 40 in Abingdon, Oxfordshire - were informed by managers yesterday of the seriousness facing the competitor of Amazon.com and BOL.com.

The start-up, which has operating companies inBritain, Holland and Sweden, was spending between £1m and £2m a month and had failed to pull off a new cash-raising exercise with its financial adviser, Lehman Brothers.

The group attracted 750,000 customers and had turnover of £5.8m in the first half of the year but losses had were more than £24m over the same period.

Mr Bradshaw said it did not matter how well managed a venture was. The crucial factor was to be number one or number two in the chosen field of operation - or to have tremendously deep pockets courtesy of one really big investor. "This is a winner takes all environment."

 Going down, the failures

This year has been a grim one for the internet fraternity; the problems at Boxman.com are just the latest.

While sports fashion e-tailer Boo.com made the biggest headlines when it ceased trading in May, there have been others since.

Earlier this month Powernet Telecom, the internet company chaired by the Marquess of Huntly, was forced into receivership with debts of £30m.

Before this, Callnet, the internet service provider, went into administration and was forced to bring in BDO Stoy Hayward to try to find a trade buyer.

Leisureplanet.com, a travel site, went the same way and Clickmango, the health e-tailer, was forced to cease trading earlier this year.

Even ventures with heavyweight support have found the going hard. Efdex, backed by IBM and Dell, closed its UK arm and despite Disney backing Toysmart.com fell by the wayside.

webTitle: Who will be the next first minister?

fields.headline: Who will be the next first minister?
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Henry McLeish, 52
fields.body:
Henry McLeish, 52

The man widely regarded as having the best chance of taking over from Donald Dewar. He will act as spokesman for the Labour party in the Scottish parliament until a new leader is elected.

The Fife Central MSP has a long track record in Scottish politics and a stronger ministerial pedigree than his likely challengers.

Mr McLeish served as a minister with Mr Dewar in the Scottish Office and he became the enterprise minister in the new parliament.

Before the Scottish elections Mr McLeish was seen as a certainty for Mr Dewar's deputy. But Labour's lack of an overall majority meant he had to cede that position to Jim Wallace, a Liberal Democrat.

He enjoys broad appeal among the unions and constituency parties which make up around two-thirds of the electoral college. He is also well regarded by cabinet colleagues, although some think him too close to certain sections of the press.

Wendy Alexander, 37

The Scottish communities minister and Paisley North MSP can perhaps more than any other cabinet colleague claim the title of Mr Dewar's favoured choice as successor.

Ms Alexander drafted much of the Scotland Act which created the Scottish parliament and almost everyone who has worked with her has praised her backroom skills.

She was in charge of driving plans to repeal section 28. It was obvious she passionately believed in the repeal and she was successful. But the campaign against repeal, financed by businessman Brian Souter was damaging to Ms Alexander. It would play badly against her in the election.

Jack McConnell, 40

The Scottish finance minister may be one of the strongest contenders for the post.

He is MSP for Motherwell and Wishaw, a former general secretary of the Scottish Labour party and is well known among trade unionists. He is also liked by cabinet colleagues. But as his former role involved keeping the constituency parties in line, he may be at a disadvantage to Mr McLeish.

Although exonerated from any wrongdoing, the spectre of Scotland's cash-for-access controversy, dubbed Lobbygate, still hangs around him.

He may be the favoured choice of those looking for a new start for Scottish politics.

fields.headline: Burst vessel proved fatal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Donald Dewar underwent heart surgery to repair a damaged aortic valve five months ago, but made a good recovery and was to all intents and purposes fit and healthy yesterday morning. But the operation meant he was taking warfarin, a blood-thinning drug.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar underwent heart surgery to repair a damaged aortic valve five months ago, but made a good recovery and was to all intents and purposes fit and healthy yesterday morning. But the operation meant he was taking warfarin, a blood-thinning drug.

This medication, a standard prescription for people undergoing all sorts of surgery, would have guarded against the risk of a blood clot reaching the brain after the operation and causing a stroke.

But, as it turned out, it was an aggravating factor in Mr Dewar's fatal brain haemorrhage.

There have been conflicting reports as to whether Mr Dewar hit his head when he fell. What is certain is that a blood vessel in his brain burst, which can happen spontaneously or after an injury to the head.

Because Mr Dewar was taking warfarin, his blood did not clot when the blood vessel burst and the haemorrhage became rapidly and progressively worse. He fell at around midday but did not go to hospital until 5.30pm.

By the time the haemorrhage was diagnosed and he had been transferred to the Western General hospital's neurological unit, there was little that could be done for him.

webTitle: United in praise for a decent, sincere man

fields.headline: United in praise for a decent, sincere man
fields.standfirst:
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: As politicians from across the political spectrum offered their praise of Donald Dewar's life yesterday, the same words appeared over and over again: honesty, integrity, decency and sincerity.
fields.body:
As politicians from across the political spectrum offered their praise of Donald Dewar's life yesterday, the same words appeared over and over again: honesty, integrity, decency and sincerity.

Tony Blair paid a sincere tribute: "In a world often of intrigue, he was a man of integrity. In a world of ambition, he was a man of service.

"I will remember him simply as a really good friend, funny, irreverent, warm, loyal."

The Conservative party leader, William Hague, said Mr Dewar's sudden death left him greatly saddened.

"He sacrificed his health, he gave his life and he gave all his working hours to politics, to serving people, to the people of Scotland and, of course, to the new Scottish parliament."

Mr Dewar's Liberal Democrat deputy, Jim Wallace, offered a simple and eloquent epitaph. "Donald was the kind of person who gives politics a good name," he said.

Buckingham palace issued a statement saying the Queen was "saddened" by the loss of Mr Dewar.

Much of Mr Dewar's political life was spent striving for a Scottish parliament.

When his close friend John Smith died, he achieved what the Labour leader called the "settled will" of the Scottish people.

"Donald was devolution. The architect of the most successful constitutional change this century," said the Scottish enterprise minister, Henry McLeish.

There was praise also for Mr Dewar's prowess within the parliament he fathered.

"Of the 129 of us who had the honour of being elected to the Scottish parliament, he was the most dominant figure," said presiding officer Sir David Steel.

But there was sadness that he was denied the opportunity of fulfilling his role as the first Scottish first minister.

"He was a man of great vision. He lived to make his vision a reality but was robbed of the chance to see it completely fulfilled," said the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy.

From Alex Salmond, the former leader of the Scottish National party and the man Mr Dewar battled against for most of his political life, there was acknowledgement that an era in Scottish politics had passed.

"I will miss the debates and miss the arguments," he said.

But, ultimately, in the manner of his death, said the Scottish secretary, John Reid, there was something of his life.

"It is not surprising that despite Donald's fall yesterday his first reaction was to pick himself up, dust himself down and get back to work. For those of us lucky enough to have known him well over many years, this typifies his character and determination," he said.

Alongside the commendations of Mr Dewar's life in public affairs, there was praise of the private man.

"I will miss him, not least because of his wicked sense of humour and his immense kindness," said Margaret McDonagh, general secretary of the Labour party.

Lord Robertson, the secretary general of Nato and a former defence secretary and cabinet colleague of Mr Dewar, said: "He was a warm, generous, plainly decent human being."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Web spend cuts GMG profits
fields.body:
Web spend cuts GMG profits

Heavy spending on new-media ventures dented operating profits in the year to April 2 at Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian, figures published yesterday showed.

Exceptional gains on the sale of the group's 15% stake in GMTV, however, helped boost headline pre-tax profits from £47m to £51.2m in the period, on turnover up 8% at £444m.

GMG's net cash stands at just over £175m, up from £137m a year earlier, while net assets have increased to £284m - a rise of more than 50% in two years.

Bob Phillis, group chief executive, said the new financial year had started well, with a favourable trading outlook. Advertising revenues were firm and showing year-on-year growth in many sectors. But he warned that new ventures would involve some heavy start-up losses which required careful monitoring.

Chairman Paul Myners, who replaced Lord Gavron in March, said that GMG was a unique organisation in a communications world where corporate consolidation could often seem to be a greater prize than independence.

He added that, although the challenges facing the group were arguably more complex than any in its history, he was confident that GMG would not only thrive but sustain its primary mission of serving the public interest. This was "the only allegiance we wish to have".

Halifax turns up the heat

Halifax, the mortgage bank, yesterday stepped up its assault on its banking rivals by introducing a range of low-interest credit cards. It follows yesterday's decision to offer an inflation-busting 4% interest rate current account. Halifax will launch two cards on Monday offering people who switch their balances to it rates pegged at 2.9% for the first five months.

The new Halifax Platinum and Gold cards will come in Visa and MasterCard versions, while the bank's classic Visa card will be relaunched.

Corus cuts a further 210 jobs

Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus is cutting 210 more steel jobs at its British operations and scaling down production because of difficult market conditions. The job losses come on top of the 4,000 announced over the past few months by the company, formed by the merger of British Steel and Hoogovens.

The cuts will hit strip steel works at Port Talbot and Shotton in Wales and Lackenby in the north-east. Last month Corus announced a surprise third-quarter operating loss of £96m. The group's shares fell p to 52p.

EC confirms AOL go-ahead

Internet company AOL yesterday won European approval for its $129bn (£92bn) takeover of Time Warner after agreeing to sever links with Germany's Bertelsmann group. The EC said the company's concessions plus last week's withdrawal of the planned joint venture of Warner Music and EMI had convinced it that the merged group would not be able to dominate the online music market.

Chairman Paul Myners, who replaced Lord Gavron in March, said that GMG was a unique organisation in a communications world where corporate consolidation could often seem to be a greater prize than independence. He added that, although the challenges facing the group were arguably more complex than any in its history, he was confident that GMG would not only thrive but sustain its primary mission of serving the public interest. This was "the only allegiance we wish to have". It follows yesterday's decision to offer an inflation-busting 4% interest rate current account. fields.headline: An unlikely and irreplaceable hero
fields.standfirst:
Few candidates of the calibre that made first minister liked and admired

Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: As he said the phrase which will pin his name to history, Donald Dewar allowed himself a smirk. "There shall be a Scottish parliament," he said. The first sentence of the Scotland Act, the deliverance of the first Scottish parliament in 300 years. "I like that," he added.
fields.body:
As he said the phrase which will pin his name to history, Donald Dewar allowed himself a smirk. "There shall be a Scottish parliament," he said. The first sentence of the Scotland Act, the deliverance of the first Scottish parliament in 300 years. "I like that," he added.

Against all odds - for Mr Dewar was ill-dressed, anti-spin, often mumbling and deeply unfashionable - the first Scottish first minister achieved every parliamentarian's dream of moving from the filigree of political tussle to the annals of history. His loss will be felt deeply by the Labour party - inside and outside Scotland.

More than any other figure, he dominated modern Scottish politics. His contemporaries - Gordon Brown and the late John Smith - made their names at Westminster. Mr Dewar, uniquely, made his at Westminster and in the Scottish parliament he created. Both these institutions will have to examine how they will adapt now he has gone.

There was, of course, no appetite yesterday for the political manoeuvring which is bound to follow his departure. He was a figure genuinely liked and respected within his party. But that manoeuvring will have to come soon. Although there will be no campaigning until after Mr Dewar's funeral, under the terms of the Scotland Act a successor must be appointed within 28 days.

There is no obvious choice to replace him. Bluntly, no Scottish minister has yet proved to be of sufficient calibre. The man who most obviously wants to take on the mantle is Henry McLeish. The trouble for the enterprise minister is that he may want it just a little too much.

Mr Dewar's successor will be appointed through an electoral college made up of the Scottish parliamentary party, the trade unions and constituency parties.

Mr McLeish will command broad support in each of these groups; he has long experience as a minister at Westminster and latterly Holyrood, which will undoubtedly play well.

He does, however, have a habit of irritating his cabinet colleagues by leaking stories to the press. He also rarely enters the political ring when things go wrong, as they have so often for Labour recently. Mr McLeish may have gained an image as the biggest hitter left in Scottish politics, but this does not guarantee him victory.

His greatest challenge will come from a man virtually unknown outside Scotland: Jack McConnell, the finance minister.

Crucial job

In the short time he has served, Mr McConnell has proved himself to be an able minister. For a brief period, his star was dimmed by last year's Lobbygate affair over accusations of cash for access to ministers. He was, however, cleared of any impropriety. Since then he has steadily managed the Scottish budget while working behind the scenes in the unglamorous but crucial job of wresting power from the hands of truculent Scottish civil servants.

Mr McConnell is the outsider. He is relatively untested and carries with him a faint allusion that he would be prepared to take Scotland on a path quite different to Labour's agenda in London. Mr McLeish is tried, tested and safe - he is probably Labour in London's preferred choice.

Neither of these men, however, were favourites of Mr Dewar. Mr Dewar had planned to stand down one year after the next Scottish elections. His anointed successor would have been the ferociously capable communities minister, Wendy Alexander. The election comes too early for her as it does for the talented health minister, Susan Deacon.

In theory, this election should take place free from Westminster interference. It will not. Labour in London may have had its interfering fingers burned over the Alun Michael debacle at the Welsh assembly, but its influence will still be felt here.

Westminster and Holyrood enjoy something approaching a symbiotic relationship. The prime minister will have a strong interest in who becomes Scotland's new first minister. But, in matters Scottish, he most frequently doffs his cap to the judgment of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Mr Brown played a key role in getting Mr Dewar elected as Scotland's first first minister last year; he will also have significant influence on who becomes his successor. His most likely choice is Mr McLeish. The two men have Fife constituencies and they know each other from Westminster. Mr Brown and Mr McConnell also worked closely when Mr McConnell was general secretary of the Scottish Labour party.

But Mr McLeish, at least, believes his relationship with the chancellor is deeper. For his part, the chancellor may hold the faint notion that he would be able to assert more power over Mr McLeish than Mr McConnell.

These are the machinations in Edinburgh, but Mr Dewar's death affects Labour more widely than that. He was the statesman Labour hoped would help ensure Scotland remained a bedrock at the next election.

Under Mr Dewar, Labour succeeded in making sure Scotland voted out each of its Conservative MPs in the last general election. Without Mr Dewar, Labour will find it difficult to repeat that success in a fight for a second term next year.

The Scottish secretary, John Reid, though he occasionally had a turbulent working relationship with Mr Dewar, now must campaign in the absence of the headwind provided by a man who held the affection of much of Scotland.

The death of Donald Dewar yesterday may turn out to mark a sea change in British political life. With his death and the departure of the Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, to the back benches, Scottish politics becomes obscure to the rest of the Britain.

The parliament the father of the nation delivered will continue, but will the rest of Britain continue to look on?

webTitle: Baby girl saved by torchlight delivery

fields.headline: Baby girl saved by torchlight delivery
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Staff at an Eastbourne hospital carried out a caesarean section operation by torchlight yesterday - successfully delivering a 6lb girl - after emergency generators failed to start after a power cut.
fields.body:
Staff at an Eastbourne hospital carried out a caesarean section operation by torchlight yesterday - successfully delivering a 6lb girl - after emergency generators failed to start after a power cut.

Eastbourne district general hospital's two emergency generators, which are computer operated, failed to start after lightning hit the town's power supply at 2.15am, leaving the obstetrics team in the dark.

The problem was compounded when the computer registered that the generators had started, so when mains power returned 20 seconds later it was prevented from entering the hospital's mains.

Fifteen minutes before the blackout, doctors had decided to perform a caesarean on Shopna Paul, 35, after her unborn baby's heart rate fell dangerously low. Hassan Azadeh, the consultant obstetrician who performed the operation, was scrubbing up when the lights went out.

"We had to do the operation then and there or we would have lost the baby," Mr Azadeh said. However, emergency lights above the operating table were not powerful enough for the surgeon to work safely.

"The nurses ran from the theatre to get torches from wherever they could. Everyone nearby rushed into the theatre to see if they could help."

The nurses held the torches over Mrs Paul's abdomen in shifts to prevent their arms becoming stiff during the 40 minute operation. "Once the baby came out and started crying everyone was extremely happy," Mr Azadeh said.

The surgeon said he owed his composed response to his 10 years' experience in Africa. "Lack of resources and being unable to run a generator prepared me well. At least twice a month we had no power so I was quite familiar with alternative systems.

"In developing countries operations often have to be performed by candlelight. This is my first experience of using torches in the UK but it was certainly one of the most romantic caesarean sections I've ever done.

"There was a good atmosphere in the theatre. When I was operating I cheered the rest of the team up by telling them they were lucky to have torches. Things could be worse, I said. We could be doing this with candles."

Mr Azadeh said that if Mrs Paul had needed a general anaesthetic, the operation would have been unlikely to have been successful. "The fact that she was comfortable and calm before the power cut enabled us to progress with the delivery," he said.

A spokesman for the hospital said: "Staff responded as you would expect doctors and nurses to. They clicked into another gear and got on with the job in hand."

Hospital engineers returned power to the hospital 10 minutes after the baby was born.

Doctors at the hospital also treated a man who had suffered a heart attack in the back of an ambulance. They met the vehicle in the forecourt but could not resuscitate him.

The spokesman said an investigation was being held into why the generators failed.

fields.headline: Panorama switch under fire
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The reporter who made one of the hardest hitting Panorama films yesterday rebuked BBC managers who have shifted the current affairs show to a "graveyard" slot on Sundays.
fields.body:
The reporter who made one of the hardest hitting Panorama films yesterday rebuked BBC managers who have shifted the current affairs show to a "graveyard" slot on Sundays.

John Ware, whose programme on the Omagh bombing stirred much controversy this week, said he was "highly critical" of the decision to move Panorama out of its peak time Monday night slot on BBC1 to make way for the new Ten O'Clock News.

The Guardian has learned that the BBC is to spend £350,000 on newspaper advertisements promoting the new bulletin - £50,000 more than the cash injection given to Panorama this year.

Mr Ware is the first senior member of the programme's team to go public with their concerns. It is understood that all its staff, who include senior reporters such as Jane Corbin and Tom Mangold, are furious at the decision to shift it to Sunday nights at 10.15pm.

Many fear that its audiences will fall dramatically and doubt managers' commitment to serious current affairs on BBC1.

The move was forced by the decision of Greg Dyke, director general, to transfer the main evening news bulletin from 9pm, stealing a march on ITV, whose 10pm bulletin three nights a week starts in January. BBC governors had prevented Mr Dyke and his director of television, Mark Thompson, from moving Panorama to BBC2.

Mr Ware said: "I sincerely mean this. I am highly critical of, and very sad about, the BBC's decision to move Panorama from a weekday slot. The fact that it will go out on BBC1 is a figleaf to cover the fact that it will no longer air in prime time."

This week's programme, which named four men suspected of involvement in the 1998 Omagh bombing, was the last to air in the 10pm slot on Monday. BBC staff were delighted with the programme, which drew a highly respectable 4.2m viewers and front page newspaper coverage.

Michael Buerk, who will anchor the first 10pm news bulletin on Monday, has expressed his concern at the prospect of two major channels' news programmes going head to head. "You could be effectively halving your audience."

The BBC says that if Panorama audiences fall dramatically it will review the position.

 Sky News is launching a 9pm bulletin from Monday, presented by Jeremy Thompson, "to allow disillusioned former BBC Nine O'Clock News viewers to make the transition to Sky News", said its head of news, Nick Pollard.

webTitle: Clinton set for Middle East return

fields.headline: Clinton set for Middle East return
fields.standfirst:
Diplomacy brings reduction in violence and boosts prospect of a peace summit with US president

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Madeleine Albright's office
Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office
Israeli government
Palestinian National Authority
fields.trailText: The most dogged peacemaker in the Middle East, Bill Clinton, was considering a new visit to the region yesterday after a flurry of diplomatic activity helped produce a relative respite from two weeks of violence.
fields.body:
The most dogged peacemaker in the Middle East, Bill Clinton, was considering a new visit to the region yesterday after a flurry of diplomatic activity helped produce a relative respite from two weeks of violence.

Mr Clinton's admission that Washington is eager to resume its diplomatic role comes after several days spent on the sidelines of a peace effort spearheaded by Kofi Annan. The UN secretary general has shuttled between meetings with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

The Pope added his voice to the appeals for peace yesterday. "Faced with such a dramatic situation, I can only beg everyone to put an end to this spiral of violence without delay," he said.

Last night the intense diplomatic activity appeared to be producing results, and even speculation that Israel and the Palestinians could be willing to look beyond the bloodshed towards convening a summit. Mr Annan is expected to travel to Lebanon today to try to secure the release of three Israeli soldiers kidnapped by Hizbullah guerrillas at the weekend. That would prepare the ground for a return to the negotiating table by President Clinton.

"I am prepared to do whatever I can to help," he said yesterday, adding that his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, might also travel to the region.

Yesterday Hizbullah warned Israel that any attempt to free the soldiers by force would be doomed. "Israel knows very well there is no solution except through an exchange operation. Let them decide what they see as appropriate."

Israeli officials said a peace summit could be convened as early as the weekend. Norway and Italy have offered to act as hosts.

Mr Barak appeared to support such a schedule yesterday and he suggested for the first time that the violence appeared to be dying down. "You know, if it [the reduction in violence] will continue for some time, this should be taken into account," he said.

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, yesterday completed a whirlwind tour of Syria, Lebanon and Israel during which he has been trying to defuse the crisis. The Itar-Tass news agency quoted him as saying there was an increasing chance of a Barak-Arafat meeting.

"It is becoming clear there is a possibility of holding multilateral meetings with the participation of Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat," he said. "The participants and the venue are being agreed upon."

However, the Palestinians say that any talk of a summit is premature. "We welcome efforts exerted by President Clinton, but it is too early to speak about holding a three-way summit before the convening of the Arab summit [on October 21], especially since the Israeli aggression against the Palestinian territories is continuing," Nabil Abu Rudeineh, a senior Palestinian official, said.

Egypt is also opposed to an early summit, but President Clinton played down this rejection.

"I don't think you should over-read that as a reflection that either the Israelis or the Palestinians do not want to continue the peace process," he said.

The key to the gradual easing in tensions appears to be an emerging agreement between Israel and the Palestinians on an investigation team to look into the violence, in which more than 90 people have died. All but five of the dead were Palestinians or Israeli Arabs.

Yesterday a Palestinian teenager was killed during clashes in the West Bank, and another man died in Gaza. A third Palestinian was shot dead in clashes with Israeli forces in the West Bank village of Jama'in, near Nablus.

webTitle: Victims to be consulted before prosecution

fields.headline: Victims to be consulted before prosecution
fields.standfirst: Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: Crown prosecutors are to be told for the first time that they will have to take account of the views of victims or, in case of murder, the victim's family, in deciding whether to prosecute.
fields.body:
Crown prosecutors are to be told for the first time that they will have to take account of the views of victims or, in case of murder, the victim's family, in deciding whether to prosecute.

The rule forms part of an updated code for crown prosecutors, redrafted to include the recommendations of the Macpherson inquiry into the death of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence. The prosecution service consulted Sir William Macpherson before drafting new code sections.

Crown prosecutors will also have to take account of the consequences for victims of their decision whether to prosecute and to tell victims of any decision which makes a significant difference to their case.

The decision is a two stage process. First, the prosecutor must decide if there is a "realistic prospect of conviction". If the answer is yes, the next question is whether it would be in the public interest to prosecute.

In another important change following the Lawrence case, factors weighing in favour of prosecution will not just include racial motivation for a crime, but the mere fact that the suspect showed hostility to a victim based on racial origin.

If there are concerns about a witness's accuracy or credibility, prosecutors must now ask themselves whether these are based on evidence or "simply information with nothing to support it". They must also consider whether the police could look for further evidence which would support or detract from the witness's account.

New sections cover the sensitive area of dropping charges in return for guilty pleas to lesser charges. Prosecutors are told they should accept a plea only if satisfied that the court has power to pass a sentence matching the seriousness of the crime, particularly where there are aggravating factors.

"Particular care must be taken when considering pleas which would enable the defendant to avoid the imposition of a mandatory minimum sentence," the code says. If a defendant pleads guilty to the charges on the basis of facts which differ from the prosecution's case, and this might significantly affect the sentence, prosecutors should ask the court to hear evidence about what actually happened.

Following the case of Harold Shipman, the GP convicted of 15 murders but thought to have killed more, the code states that a prosecution is less likely to be needed if a defendant has already been sentenced and a further conviction is unlikely to produce a heavier sentence.

Prosecutors are told they should accept a plea only if satisfied that the court has power to pass a sentence matching the seriousness of the crime, particularly where there are aggravating factors. "Particular care must be taken when considering pleas which would enable the defendant to avoid the imposition of a mandatory minimum sentence," the code says. If a defendant pleads guilty to the charges on the basis of facts which differ from the prosecution's case, and this might significantly affect the sentence, prosecutors should ask the court to hear evidence about what actually happened. Following the case of Harold Shipman, the GP convicted of 15 murders but thought to have killed more, the code states that a prosecution is less likely to be needed if a defendant has already been sentenced and a further conviction is unlikely to produce a heavier sentence.

fields.headline: Move to get poorest online
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Thousands of people living in the poorest communities in Britain will be brought online by a computer scheme intended to bridge the digital divide between rich and poor.
fields.body:
Thousands of people living in the poorest communities in Britain will be brought online by a computer scheme intended to bridge the digital divide between rich and poor.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has announced that £10m will be invested in 10 pilot schemes in some of the most deprived areas of the country.

The first area to benefit will be the inner city area of Kensington in Liverpool, where unemployment is three times the national average.

Recycled computers, printers and software applications will be delivered to 2,000 homes in the area when the project goes live in the new year. Customers will be expected to contribute £60 to the cost.

A community website linking those involved in the project to the internet will give training and advice on jobs and access to local services. IT training centres will be provided as part of the venture, which is being funded by public and private money.

The scheme will eventually provide computers for 35,000 households.

The chancellor said that half the richest families were now on the internet, but only one in 20 of the poorest families was linked up.

"It is the determination to bridge the digital divide that makes us adopt such an innovative approach," he said. "Our aim is not just that people can access new technology, but that they also have the skills to make the most of that technology.

"We want to see not just some, but everyone equipped for the challenges of the future. No one should be excluded from the benefits of the IT revolution."

Families will have to pay their telephone bills for internet use to their own homes, but free internet use will be available at computers installed in community centres.

Michael Wills, the minister for learning and technology, said: "Those on high incomes are eight times more likely to have access to the internet than people on low incomes. We are committed to providing universal access to the internet.

"New technology has tremendous power to connect people to opportunities in education, employment and with one another."

He said the risk of a digital divide was real but the government alone could not bridge the gap, which was why it was working with the private sector.

Tony Blair has pledged that everyone should have access to the internet by 2005.

fields.headline: Most women feel too fat
fields.trailText: British women are a nation of Bridget Joneses, obsessed about their body size and shape, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
British women are a nation of Bridget Joneses, obsessed about their body size and shape, according to a survey published today.

Most women are unhappy about their bodies and the average woman has gone on at least 32 diets.

Just one in 100 women is satisfied with her body shape and size with 85% admitting that they worry about their body every day.

More than three quarters of women of a "normal" weight still wanted to lose an average of 10lbs while one in 10 says she is on a constant diet, mirroring the obssession of the thirtysomething diarist Bridget Jones, who chronicles her daily calorie intake and weight fluctuations, said the survey of more than 5,000 for Top Sante magazine.

But any attempt to convince the female population that size does not matter seems doomed - with 88% convinced that big cannot be beautiful.

The findings offer a bleak outlook for a new advertising campaign by Marks and Spencer which celebrates bigger women.

Despite their constant quest for the perfect body, seven out of 10 women indulge in snacks to cheer themselves up and more than half admit to being "chocaholics".

The poll found that 85% felt inhibited by their body. Just 4% were happy with their hips and thighs, 9% with their bottom and 18% with their waist.

Half of all women classified themselves as overweight - a figure backed by government statistics which show that more than two in five women weigh more than they should for their height.

Four out of 10 women said they had suffered from some kind of eating disorder, with 25% admitting to binge eating, 10% saying they had been bulimic and 8% having suffered from anorexia.

But only a quarter of those with an eating disorder had sought medical help for their problems.

A quarter of women have tried slimming pills to lose weight, 25% had fasted and half have attempted "faddy" diets.

But women, it seems, are their own worst enemy, with three quarters of those questioned saying other women were most likely to criticise their weight and shape.

Karen Williamson, editor of Top Sante, said: "British women have become incredibly critical of their bodies and their obsession with their shape and size is spoiling their lives."

webTitle: Milosevic cronies defy Serbia's new rulers

fields.headline: Milosevic cronies defy Serbia's new rulers
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic cronies defy Serbia's new rulers
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Allies of Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, issued a dangerous challenge to the country's new rulers yesterday by insisting they still run the police and ordering units to take control of offices and enterprises which workers had seized in recent days.
fields.body:
Allies of Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, issued a dangerous challenge to the country's new rulers yesterday by insisting they still run the police and ordering units to take control of offices and enterprises which workers had seized in recent days.

Scores of cronies appointed to lucrative jobs by the former president have been forced to resign. The order is designed to lift the morale of those resisting the handover and give others a chance for a comeback. It is the most dramatic act of defiance since Mr Milosevic was forced by street protests last week to end his effort to steal September's election.

The army also issued an ominous statement rejecting purges of the high command after senior generals met Vojislav Kostunica, the new president. They warned against "possible negative consequences of increased attacks and attempts to discredit certain individual of the Yugoslav army".

Opposition leaders are threatening to call protesters back on to the streets if plans for new elections for a Serbian parliament are thwarted. They feel confident of winning them and breaking Mr Milosevic's resistance. They have no doubt the former president is co-ordinating the effort to use his Socialist party's control over Serbia's government against the more limited constitutional rights which Mr Kostunica has as Yugoslav president.

Symbolising the half-way na ture of the transition, Mr Milosevic is still protected by the presidential guard, an elite unit of the army. "He is a private citizen, but is protected by the presidential guard. He is not under arrest," Zoran Djindjic, the new rulers' chief strategist, told the Guardian yesterday.

The ex-president is in his home in the well-to-do suburb of Dedinje behind a high metal fence. A lone police car is parked across the road but TV cameras watch the front, and the guard is inside. A few times a day the gates swing open and cars speed through with visitors for Mr Milosevic. According to Mr Djindjic, they are mainly from JUL, Yugoslav Left, the party founded by his wife Mira Markovic. JUL members were appointed to run many of the country's most important enterprises. Many have been sacked over the last few days as workers demand they go.

The army high command is not fully reconciled to the changes at the top and the security police are getting back into action. "They have four places in Belgrade from which they monitor phones. They listen to everybody. It's more than it used to be. They give the reports to Milosevic," Mr Djindjic said.

Rade Markovic, the security police chief and a strong Milosevic loyalist, is still in office. President Kostunica has no power to sack him.

While holding the weapon of street demonstrations in reserve, Mr Djindjic offered a compromise last night if the socialists accepted early elections. The ministries of police, justice, finance, and information would each have "collective management" without ex tensive changes of personnel. The socialists could also have the prime ministership, provided Mirko Marjanovic, one of Mr Milosevic's closest allies, stepped down.

Still celebrating Mr Milosevic's formal concession of power, the Kostunica camp had felt triumphant on Monday when leaders of his Socialist party seemed to agree to hold early elections for the Serbian parliament in December. They were also delighted when the police minister resigned.

Things later went sour. The socialists stalled talks on forming an interim government and refused to dissolve parliament, pending the elections. They went further yesterday by saying the Serbian government remained in power and Mr Marjanovic would take charge of the police.

A statement issued after a meeting of the republic's government yesterday described the purges of company directors as illegal.

fields.headline: Death of a decent man
fields.standfirst:
Tributes pour in for Donald Dewar, the architect of devolution and 'the best first minister Scotland could have had'
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: He would not have wanted the fuss. But the death of a man who could in all honesty carry the title of father of the nation could have no other outcome.
fields.body:
He would not have wanted the fuss. But the death of a man who could in all honesty carry the title of father of the nation could have no other outcome.

At 12.18pm yesterday Donald Dewar was pronounced dead at Edinburgh's Western General hospital, his two children at his side. The news, when it came, was brief and terrible. A brain haemorrhage, the consequence of a simple stumble and the medication he took for his heart, had robbed Scotland of the architect of devolution.

"Scotland has lost a great man," said David Whitton, Dewar's spokesman, and the country faltered with him under the weight of his words. As the news spread, Scots voiced their grief for the brilliant, difficult, decent man who gifted them a parliament and never lost his faith in its power or place.

News bulletins were extended, but no other item made the TV screens. Radio presenters rarely interrupted as Dewar's friends paid tribute. The headline of the Edinburgh Evening News put it bluntly: "Dewar is dead"; a fact that by evening was still only just beginning to sink in.

"Is he dead?" asked an elderly lady waiting for her own hospital appointment. When she heard he was she put her hand to her mouth and the tears came. "He was a good man," she said.

Rugby matches started late as players observed a minute's silence. As far away as Zagreb, the loss was observed as the Scottish football team donned black armbands.

Throughout the night, members of the public had been phoning the hospital switchboard to pass on their best, to express their hopes and fears. From early morning, though, there was the certain knowledge that death was imminent. Dewar's cabinet colleagues met to confront what they knew was to come. "It was like a gathering of friends," said Mr Whitton.

Then, almost two hours after Dewar died, these friends joined his many others in offering tributes.

In Downing Street the prime minister appraised the legacy of Scotland's first first minister: "The Scottish parliament is his achievement. It will be his testament. History will remember him for that."

Up on the Royal Mile, where the parliament has its temporary home, colleagues choked on tributes, ashen-faced. There were no soundbites or fancy phrases. The greatest eloquence came in the simplest words. Jim Wallace, Dewar's deputy and the man who must temporarily fill his post, offered an epitaph. "Donald was the kind of person who gives politics a good name," he said.

Scotland had been expecting the worst. A stumble on Tuesday morning turned into the worst possible scenario. A few hours after Dewar tripped he complained of feeling unwell. Typically, he did not want a fuss. He only received medical attention on the insistence of his aides. But by 7pm that night, Dewar had lost consciousness in hospital.

He had been joking until the end - even as he was pushed in on a trolley. His children, Marion, 35, and Ian, 33, were called to his bedside and it was there, yesterday morning, that the decision was taken to turn off his life support machine.

At a press conference in the hospital grounds, the doctors who attended him said nothing could have been done. A brain haemorrhage, before or after his fall, had set in train a sequence of events that was irretrievable. By the time he reached the Western General he had suffered irreversible brain damage.

Mr Whitton, struggling to control his emotion, spoke of the cultured, literate and principled man he had worked for: "You talk about him being stubborn but it was a sense of duty on his behalf. He took very seriously the position that he held and he just wanted to do his best."

Journalists, too, those who had judged Dewar's every move and frequently questioned his political future, were shaken. As the press conference drew to a close, one asked Mr Whitton what he would remember most about his minister.

"He was a man of many parts," Mr Whitton said, his voice breaking for the first time. "He's the best first minister Scotland could have had. I can't put it any plainer than that."

webTitle: Inquiry ruled out on £1m loan to Labour

fields.headline: Inquiry ruled out on £1m loan to Labour
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The public standards watchdog, Lord Neill, has declined to hold an inquiry into whether Tony Blair or Gordon Brown lied about their knowledge of the £1m donation accepted by Labour from the formula one boss, Bernie Ecclestone.
fields.body:
The public standards watchdog, Lord Neill, has declined to hold an inquiry into whether Tony Blair or Gordon Brown lied about their knowledge of the £1m donation accepted by Labour from the formula one boss, Bernie Ecclestone.

The chairman of the committee on standards in public life has turned down a request from Andrew Lansley, the shadow Cabinet Office minister, to investigate following fresh disclosures by Observer journalist Andrew Rawnsley in his book Servants of the People.

The book alleged that Mr Brown misled the public by saying he knew nothing of the loan, and Mr Blair, contrary to statements at the time, was already aware the loan was contentious when he asked Lord Neill for advice on whether to return it. This came after the government had offered to exempt formula one from a tobacco advertising and sponsorship ban. Mr Blair and Mr Brown have denied the fresh allegations.

Lord Neill says in a letter released yesterday: "The commitee will not undertake any investigation ... as it is not empowered to do so. The then prime minister, John Major, made it clear when he announced the establishment of the committee in 1994 that our remit does not extend to investigating individual allegations of misconduct."

Lord Neill adds that he did exceptionally give advice to the prime minister about the controversial donation as it occured before he had started his inquiry into the funding of political parties and required a speedy response.

He defends making public the decision at the time "to prevent any misleading impressions from gaining currency and to ensure that any misinterpretations are corrected".

Last night Mr Lansley said he had to accept Lord Neill's ruling, but would table questions to ministers on the isssues when parliament returned later this month.

fields.headline: Back to prison
fields.standfirst:
Fijian coup leader on treason charge is refused bail

Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: Fiji's highest court refused yesterday to grant bail to rebel leader George Speight, sending the one-time insurance salesman back to his island prison to await trial for treason.
fields.body:
Fiji's highest court refused yesterday to grant bail to rebel leader George Speight, sending the one-time insurance salesman back to his island prison to await trial for treason.

The high court ruling in the capital, Suva, followed a decision by prosecutors to drop treason charges against nine soldiers who backed the coup led by Mr Speight, the office of the director of public prosecutions said.

Mr Speight and his supporters stormed the parliament on May 19 and took the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and most of his multiracial cabinet hostage in the name of indigenous Fijians. They were held for 56 days.

Mr Speight and 14 of his co-conspirators will remain in custody until their next court appearance on October 25, when defence lawyers are expected to plead for their release under an immunity deal. They were offered immunity in exchange for releasing the hostages, but prosecutors claim the rebels failed to meet the terms of the deal. Treason carries the death penalty in Fiji.
Reuters, Suva

webTitle: Bulger killers to learn release date in weeks

fields.headline: Bulger killers to learn release date in weeks
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the young killers of two-year-old James Bulger, will learn their likely release date within the next three weeks.
fields.body:
Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the young killers of two-year-old James Bulger, will learn their likely release date within the next three weeks.

The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, is to set their long-awaited "tariff" in open court before the end of October.

Guidelines made public by Lord Woolf for the first time in July suggest 10 years as the most likely term. That could lead to the pair being released at the age of 21 and make it possible for them to avoid a transfer to an adult prison.

Before release their lawyers are expected to invoke the right to privacy which became part of English law this month when the Human Rights Act came into force, to try to ban the media from disclosing the new identities they assume.

If successful, they could be the first adult ex-offenders to win such protection under the law. The new identity of the child killer Mary Bell was protected by a blanket injunction, but it was granted to protect her underage child.

The European convention on human rights, incorporated into English law by the Human Rights Act, guarantees a right to privacy and a right to freedom of expression. When the two rights have come into conflict, the European court of human rights has tended to give greater weight to freedom of expression as an essential safeguard of democracy.

Whether the right to privacy should outweigh the media's right to freedom of expression in the Thompson and Venables case will be thrashed out next month in a high court hearing.

In July the court made an interim injunction extending past their 18th birthdays a ban on publishing photographs of the pair or information about them, which was imposed by the trial judge. The teenagers have been in a local authority secure unit since their conviction in 1993, when they were sentenced to be detained at her majesty's pleasure - the equivalent of an adult life sentence.

Lord Woolf said he would take the standard starting point for an adult murderer, 14 years, with reductions for mitigating factors such as the killers' age at the time and increases for aggravating factors.

The European convention on human rights, incorporated into English law by the Human Rights Act, guarantees a right to privacy and a right to freedom of expression. When the two rights have come into conflict, the European court of human rights has tended to give greater weight to freedom of expression as an essential safeguard of democracy. Whether the right to privacy should outweigh the media's right to freedom of expression in the Thompson and Venables case will be thrashed out next month in a high court hearing. In July the court made an interim injunction extending past their 18th birthdays a ban on publishing photographs of the pair or information about them, which was imposed by the trial judge. The teenagers have been in a local authority secure unit since their conviction in 1993, when they were sentenced to be detained at her majesty's pleasure - the equivalent of an adult life sentence. Lord Woolf said he would take the standard starting point for an adult murderer, 14 years, with reductions for mitigating factors such as the killers' age at the time and increases for aggravating factors.

webTitle: UK young cannabis users top EU league

fields.headline: UK young cannabis users top EU league
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Children in Britain use cannabis more than in almost any other country in Europe, according to a report published yesterday by the EU's drug monitoring agency.
fields.body:
Children in Britain use cannabis more than in almost any other country in Europe, according to a report published yesterday by the EU's drug monitoring agency.

The figures also show that one in 10 British adults - a higher proportion than anywhere else in the EU - is using cannabis, while across the union one in five people has tried it once. British adults also use more than twice as much amphetamine as anyone else in Europe.

Luxembourg, the smallest state in the 15-member EU, has the highest proportion of "problem" drug users - mostly heroin addicts - at around seven for every 1,000 people between the ages of 15 and 64. It is followed by Italy, with six, and Britain and Spain with five.

According to the annual report, State of Drugs in the EU, cannabis is now the most widely available and commonly used drug. Use of cannabis by British children is in the range of 30% to 40%, along with Ireland and the Netherlands, compared with 5% to 7% in Portugal and Sweden.

The Lisbon-based European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction said that at least 45m Europeans had now tried it, up 5m from more than a year ago.

"Recreational use of cannabis is simply not considered as the first step down the road to drug abuse," George Estievenart, director of the centre, told reporters in Brussels.

But in remarks that will have resonance for debate in the UK, he warned that prison was not the answer. "If you slap people in prison for having a small amount of cannabis for their own use, after a few years you choke the prisons. Prisons are overcrowded, so they share cells with people who have done much worse. Someone who enters prison as a weekend consumer of cannabis comes out with very different habits," he said.

Ecstasy and amphetamines were the second most popular recreational drugs, with use of the former showing signs of stabilising, or even falling, while the latter could still be on the rise. Amphetamines are generally used by 1%-4% of adults across the EU, but by up to 10% in Britain.

Although Britain heads the list for cannabis use over the past 12 months, Denmark is top of the table for taking the drug over the past decade.

The report highlights the rise in Britain and Spain in the availability of cheap heroin. Mr Estievenart pointed to concern about heavy multiple drug use arising from the ecstasy/rave scene.

"Patterns of weekend and recreational drug use increasingly involve combinations of illicit and legal drugs, including alcohol and tranquillisers," the report said.

"There is a significant rise in drug use, often in conjunction with heavy alcohol consumption. Abuse of lighter fuel, aerosols and glue is often more common among children than amphetamines and ecstasy and is increasing in some countries."

Cocaine is less commonly used than either amphetamines or ecstasy, but its use is still rising and spreading to a broader population.

The report shows too that women drug users are deterred from seeking treatment because they fear being labelled as unfit mothers and losing their children. The result is that only one female drug user goes into drug treatment for every three men.

fields.headline: One of us
fields.standfirst: When Judy Finnigan accidentally exposed her lingerie at an awards show, 12m viewers cringed with shared embarrassment. But while other celebrities would have been suspected of courting headlines, Judy's inadvertent striptease only confirmed her status as the country's best-loved TV presenter.  Gareth McLean unravels the extraordinary appeal of a very ordinary icon and below Claire Phipps on Judy's life through a lens
fields.trailText: When Judy Finnigan accidentally exposed her lingerie at an awards show, 12m viewers cringed with shared embarrassment. But while other celebrities would have been suspected of courting headlines, Judy's inadvertent striptease only confirmed her status as the country's best-loved TV presenter. Gareth McLean unravels the extraordinary appeal of a very ordinary icon.
fields.body:
Had Carol Vorderman's breasts popped out of her dress at the National Television Awards, it would have been viewed as a deliberate attempt to steal the show. If Gail Porter's made a guest appearance, the nation would simply have rolled its eyes in indifference. And had Michael Barrymore bared his man breasts, it would have been deemed so last year. That Judy Finnigan's breasts, albeit bra-clad, were on display at the telly gongfest was a genuine showstopper, a moment of TV history, a prime cut of future blooper tapes.

While the main feature of the outfit worn by Coronation Street actress Naomi Russell to the same ceremony was two bits of double-sided Sellotape and her cleavage, it barely warranted a sideways glance in the tabloids. Judy's bra-baring incident made front-page news. This sort of thing wasn't supposed to happen to professional TV show hosts.

Judy - for as with Madonna and Britney, she needs only her first name to be identified in the public consciousness - found herself in the kind of mortifying scenario that most of us only endure in nightmares. As she and husband Richard (again, the Madeley is optional) took to the stage to accept their award for Most Popular Daytime Programme for This Morning, her black velvet halter-neck dress slipped away to reveal her peachily ample bosom lovingly cradled in what appeared to be a strapless bra. For a few moments, which, like those before an accident, seemed measured on a melting clock, Judy was unaware of her prime-time exposure. She and the equally ignorant Richard began making their speeches before her friend John Leslie leapt in to protect her modesty. Only then did realisation dawn: she had been indisposed in the Royal Albert Hall, in front of a television audience of nearly 12m people, the biggest audience ITV has had on a Tuesday night for two years. Displaying another of her best attributes, Judy did what she always does in awkward situations - she blamed Richard.

Actually, there was nothing to blame Richard for (for a change) as the most remarkable thing about Judy's embarrassment was that she walked away with her dignity, if not her frock, intact. If anything, baring her bra has enhanced her standing, fortifying her position as a national icon.

According to recent research for Broadcast magazine, she and Richard are the most pervasive faces on television, watched by more people than the erstwhile ubiquitous Carol Vorderman, Des Lynam or Cilla Black. In what can only have been a minute on screen, Judy's flesh-toned push-up bra and the breasts within them became a metaphor for the secret of her success. It might sound sexist to reduce a woman to her bosom but it isn't: Judy's breasts and the circumstances surrounding their new-found notoriety say everything you need to know about her. And what you need to know about Judy Finnigan is that she is real.

Judy isn't a cosmetically-altered dolly bird whose career will last as long as her looks. There is nothing manufactured about her. At times she looks fantastic, at others she looks terrible. This is life-affirming. With a background in journalism, she is, at 52, an attractive older woman who successfully combines having a family ("Jack, Chloe and the twins") and having a career. As such, she is testament that working hard and climbing the ranks - in television and, by extension, everywhere else - pays off. And she has suffered.

After her first marriage ended, she met and married Richard, a younger man, and found happiness. That happiness has been tempered with post-natal depression and "women's troubles" which culminated in a hysterectomy and widely publicised absences from This Morning. But even these have an upside - both are badges of honour for someone who empathises for a living.

For over a decade, Richard and Judy have been dispensing their own particular brand of homely wisdom to housewives, students, the unemployed and the bedridden, earning a place in the nation's heart along the way. Your head might tell you that This Morning is the ultimate in feelbad, misogynist, tabloid television but it is so alarmingly watchable, you begin to know the This Morning "family" better than your own. After a couple of days off work, you find yourself automatically tuning in to it to see how agony aunt Denise is getting on or how Richard will humiliate himself today. This Morning is addictive partly because Richard and Judy believe in what they are serving up and partly because the dynamic of their relationship is so fascinating.

They have an almost evangelical zeal when it comes to their diet of makeovers, soap star chinwags, and, of course, diets while the audience is wondering whether they had sex before the show and how long it will take for Judy to exclaim "For Goodness sake, Richard!" Like someone whose inhibitions have been loosened by half a bottle of wine, if there's something Judy doesn't believe, she will say so. There seems to be something in her DNA that prevents her from quiet submission. One imagines she can be a bit of a bitch were one to cross her.

So far, so Anne Robinson, you might say. But Judy Finnigan is softer, plumper, more approachable than Anne. Like her breasts, she is maternal, welcoming. You can imagine crying on her shoulder. And her crying on yours. She cries a lot, something you won't find Anne Robinson doing on TV too often and is quite genuine about it. When This Morning moved from Liverpool to London, she sobbed despite "promising I wouldn't do this" and when Princess Diana died, she wept and worried about William and Harry. Or as she called them "The Boys." When they have particularly heart-rending items on This Morning - gravely ill children, orphaned children, poor children - her voice often gets choked with emotion. Sometimes she laughs hysterically for no apparent reason. A lot of the time, she looks quite scared, like she has found a freakishly large spider in the bath just before going on air. This is one of the most alluring things about her. She simply doesn't seem comfortable on television, like your next-door-neighbour reading the news. A consummate professional, she can look amateur in a good, non-threatening way. She is One of Us on the telly.

It is perhaps for this reason that Tony Blair chose to grace the This Morning sofa with his presence as opposed to going head-to-head with Jeremy Paxman. As a concerned, sceptical, reasonably liberal conservative, Judy represents the kind of woman who put Blair in power and who can remove him again. The prime minister is aware of Judy's mighty sway and you can bet Blair will appear on This Morning again before the next election.

Should Judy need further credentials as a compassionate and patient icon of touchy-feely Britain, there is the small fact that she puts up with Richard. While Judy seems almost reluctant about being on TV, Richard acts as though he is the best thing ever to be on television. No matter what the subject or whoever the guest, Richard knows everything. And if he doesn't, he will simply change the subject of the conversation or interview onto one he does know all about (which is often himself). During makeovers, Richard will, as a matter of course, tell the frumpy/fat/spinsterish victim that she - for it is invariably a she - should dress better/lose weight/get out more. A typical interaction goes as follows:

Richard: Do you wear make-up very often?

Dowdy Woman: No.

Richard: You should.

Judy meanwhile empathises with the frumpy fat spinster.

Richard adopts stranger ideas with every passing week. There is a rumour that the This Morning production team have a RSI box into which they deposit slips of paper detailing Richard's Stupid Ideas. Some escape, however: at the tail end of last year, he started stocking his "millennium cupboard" lest the Y2K bug brought civilisation - and his local Sainsbury's - to its knees. He has also dressed up as Ali G and conducted an interlude in the style of the comic persona, sung along with the South Park Christmas song, Chocolate Salty Balls, and he rarely misses an opportunity to put into words whatever tumbleweed of thought is rolling across the prairie of his brain.

At every apposite moment, as well as some inopportune ones, he will mention Judy's hysterectomy, their sex lives (how many times a week, where in the house, the last time), their home life, arguments they have had and Disastrous Things Judy Has Done. Indeed, if there's any downside to Judy's bra-baring, it is that Richard now has a legitimate, in-the-public-domain excuse to talk about them. Yesterday on This Morning, he had started already. Holding their trophy, he said: "Thank you very much for this sort of silver globe, but it wasn't the nicest globe on display last night."

Despite his idiosyncrasies, Judy loves Richard and, like many long-suffering wives, humours his more outlandish behaviour and ideas. She nods and enthuses appropriately and only very occasionally will shoot him a death stare when he is veering dangerously close to Saying Too Much. His response is to throw his arms in the air and adopt a "I'm just an open kinda guy" expression and carry on regardless. Like an embarrassing uncle who cannot see himself as others see him - perhaps because he took too much LSD in the 60s - his behaviour makes hers all the more admirable.

Richard, to give him credit, clearly loves Judy very much too: she humours him, he makes her feel special. Which, of course, she is. That Judy has managed to present This Morning for more than 10 years without strangling Richard, never mind being married to him for longer, makes her positively saintly.

Judy's show-stealing moment at the National TV Awards was her life in miniature. A triumph followed by an embarrassing moment, blame assigned to Richard, a bit of bickering, and then it's back to the script, and a even warmer place in the nation's heart. It could almost be a movie. (A made-for-TV one starring Donna Mills, naturally). Judy's greatest talent is that sometimes she forgets she is on TV - and then, so do we. By transcending the barrier between Them on telly and Us at home, she is both. A mother figure of Britannia-esque proportions, we love her because she isn't perfect.

Finnigan's wake: Judy's life through a lens

Sex: In 1993, Judy is "very embarrassed" after sex therapist Dr Ruth Westheimer advises her on air how to satisfy Richard in bed. Similarly squeamish when Richard goes public with his reasons for having a vasectomy - it's all down to Judy's irregular ovulations - but more upfront in May 1998, when she reveals that her sex life has improved no end thanks to HRT.

Weight: Horrified when, in 1993, photos of her on holiday are published under the headline "Blancmange in a bikini". Obesity is banned from the This Morning list of discussion topics. In 1999, she lambasts the industry's sexism: "I hated the way they treated Kelly Brook on the Big Breakfast."

Health, a catalogue of misfortune:

September 1995: Sports a black eye after bumping into a mantlepiece. Friends cite exhaustion.

November 1997: An "under the weather" Judy skips This Morning. After rumours of a marriage split circulate, she reveals that she is to take a break to have a hysterectomy. She returns to the show in April 1998 atop a hospital trolley, but admits to being "petrified".

July 1999: Takes a two-week break; Richard blames a wheat allergy. "She had a sandwich yesterday. I said it would come back to haunt her and it did."

Marriage: Richard and Judy marry in 1986. In 1991, Richard is acquitted on charges of stealing wine and soap powder from Tesco's in Didsbury.

This Morning: On October 3 1988, This Morning is launched, later seeing off BBC rival, Good Morning with Anne and Nick. In 1996, the programme uproots from Liverpool to London to attract big-name interviewees.

Beyond This Morning: A coup in May 1996, when OJ Simpson turns down Jeremy Paxman and Jonathan Dimbleby to be interviewed on Tonight with Richard and Judy. Simpson is asked to "tell us about the Nicole that you loved".

In May 1998, Judy goes solo with We Can Work It Out, a consumer programme, despite her admission that "I don't like making a fuss". She quits the show a year later.

Claire Phipps

fields.headline: People 'rely on friends at work'
fields.trailText: People are more likely than ever to make friends and meet their partners at work, according to a report yesterday.
fields.body:
People are more likely than ever to make friends and meet their partners at work, according to a report yesterday.

A quarter of people will meet their life partner at work, said the report.

Individuals are becoming increasingly reliant on the workplace to provide them with a sense of belonging because of the breakdown of traditional networks and the increase in divorce, single person households and self-centred urban living, it said.

Sally Davis, director of the career consultancy Sanders and Sidney, which published the report, said: "We urge organisations to consider strategies to strengthen workplace communities and encourage productive friendships.

"These not only create a better atmosphere, but result in more motivated staff, improved team working and better staff retention."

Companies could create better working environments by reviewing training, introducing a more relaxed dress code, and improving the design of work and social areas.

"Research among our international partners suggests that UK employers are lagging behind in this area," she said. "Workers in Finland, Germany and the Netherlands and the United States in particular benefit from company sponsored social activities."

The survey found that employees said emotional factors such as friendship were as important in binding them to an organisation as factors such as pay and benefits.

More than 70% of the employees questioned said they had experienced a sense of loss when leaving a job. Seven out of 10 men and nine out of 10 women said they had made lasting friendships at work.

Yet the survey found that fewer than one in 10 employers had a policy of encouraging a sense of belonging.

Ken Rushton, director of the Institute of Business Ethics, said: "There is a risk that if a company provides too elaborate a social programme, a dependency culture may emerge.

"Nevertheless, an organisation that builds its employee relationship on a foundation of trust and effective team-working is likely to be one that attracts and retains high quality staff."

A quarter of people will meet their life partner at work, said the report. Individuals are becoming increasingly reliant on the workplace to provide them with a sense of belonging because of the breakdown of traditional networks and the increase in divorce, single person households and self-centred urban living, it said. Sally Davis, director of the career consultancy Sanders and Sidney, which published the report, said: "We urge organisations to consider strategies to strengthen workplace communities and encourage productive friendships. "These not only create a better atmosphere, but result in more motivated staff, improved team working and better staff retention." Companies could create better working environments by reviewing training, introducing a more relaxed dress code, and improving the design of work and social areas. "Research among our international partners suggests that UK employers are lagging behind in this area," she said. "Workers in Finland, Germany and the Netherlands and the United States in particular benefit from company sponsored social activities." The survey found that employees said emotional factors such as friendship were as important in binding them to an organisation as factors such as pay and benefits. More than 70% of the employees questioned said they had experienced a sense of loss when leaving a job. Seven out of 10 men and nine out of 10 women said they had made lasting friendships at work. Yet the survey found that fewer than one in 10 employers had a policy of encouraging a sense of belonging. Ken Rushton, director of the Institute of Business Ethics, said: "There is a risk that if a company provides too elaborate a social programme, a dependency culture may emerge. "Nevertheless, an organisation that builds its employee relationship on a foundation of trust and effective team-working is likely to be one that attracts and retains high quality staff."

fields.headline: Concorde delay angers UK pilots
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Concorde will never fly again if the French authorities continue to drag their feet on the investigation into the Air France crash in July, Christopher Darke, the head of the British pilots' union Balpa, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Concorde will never fly again if the French authorities continue to drag their feet on the investigation into the Air France crash in July, Christopher Darke, the head of the British pilots' union Balpa, said yesterday.

On the eve of Anglo-French talks to discuss the future of the aeroplane, Mr Darke said: "They are taking an age to investigate what happened."

He criticised the French system under which a magistrate is appointed to lead the inquiry and handle references passed on by the safety team.

This view was echoed by Ken Smart, head of the UK's accident investigation branch. He spoke of the "unacceptable procedural delays" imposed by judicial authorities. Mr Darke called on Britain to put pressure on the French to speed up the procedure.

It is understood that changes costing £500,000 for each of the remaining 12 Concordes are likely to be introduced to prevent any re-occurrence of the shattering of the tyre which led to the Paris crash. The accident claimed 113 lives and led to the grounding of BA and Air France Concordes.

Air France engineers say the reasons for the crash have not been fully investigated.

BA said last night it was confident that Concorde would be flying again in the next few months. It is thought that BA would be ready to commence flights to the US again without Air France, so long as the Civil Aviation Authority returned its certificate of airworthiness.
