webTitle: Mystery art donor's parcel gift to gallery

fields.headline: Mystery art donor's parcel gift to gallery
fields.standfirst: 'I have lived in obscurity and wish to remain so in death'
fields.trailText: Fridays, free admission day, are always busy at the Dulwich Picture Gallery. Nobody noticed the tall, elderly man in the panama hat coming in. Instead of heading for the exhibition, or stopping at the postcard racks, he approached an attendant and took a small brown paper package from his pocket.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Fridays, free admission day, are always busy at the Dulwich Picture Gallery. Nobody noticed the tall, elderly man in the panama hat coming in. Instead of heading for the exhibition, or stopping at the postcard racks, he approached an attendant and took a small brown paper package from his pocket.

"I have something for the trustees," he said quietly. "I found it on the P4 bus." And he turned to leave. Startled, the attendant asked if he wouldn't like to stay and look at the pictures, but he shook his head and left - sparking a bomb scare, an international stolen art inquiry, and finally the unresolved mystery of the most touching gift the 200-year-old gallery has ever received.

The puzzled attendant took the package to the office of the director, Desmond Shawe-Taylor, joking that it was probably a bomb - and caused a minor panic as staff realised it could well be. The police were called, removed the package, tested it, and gingerly opened it.

It contained a red Chinese silk gift box, holding three beautiful 17th and 18th century miniatures wrapped in tissue paper, and a touching unsigned, unheaded message printed out from a computer

"I am dying and have asked a dear friend to deliver the enclosed three miniature portraits to the trustees of Dulwich Art Gallery as my anonymous gift, because I have lived in obscurity into old age and wish to remain so in death. If they are unsuitable for display at Dulwich, it is my wish that they be given to a gallery where they blend in. May God be with you. Anon."

Dulwich refused even to speculate on their value, but the gold framed, thumbnail sized paintings could be worth more than £10,000, according to leading London auction houses. They have been examined by specialists at the Victoria and Albert Museum and the National Portrait Gallery who believe that one is by a 17th century amateur, but that the others are important works by the leading miniaturists of their day: John Hoskins, who died in 1665 and whose top auction price, in 1994, was £8,500, and the mid-18th century artist Gervase Spencer.

Although Dulwich owned no miniatures, the pictures did blend perfectly with its outstanding collection of 17th and 18th century portraits. However, Mr Shawe-Taylor was forced to look the gift horse in the mouth and check Scotland Yard and other databases of lost and stolen works of art. No matches were found.

The package was handed in in August, and yesterday the trustees concluded that it was, indeed, a gift. The miniatures will probably be hung together, in a specially made case, with the contemporary portraits.

Staff are left with heads full of questions. The police could not establish whether the package was really found on the P4 bus, which does run through Dulwich village. They do not know whether the man in the hat was the dear friend, or possibly the donor. The attendant said that, though elderly, he was dapper and looked healthy.

It is a bizarrely suitable place for a deathbed bequest. The gallery, with a small but internationally renowned collection, was designed by Sir John Soane and is unique in including a mausoleum holding the bodies of its founders, the 18th century collectors Sir Francis Bourgeois and Noel Desenfans.

webTitle: Bush retakes lead as voters question Gore's character

fields.headline: Bush retakes lead as voters question Gore's character
fields.standfirst:
'Sighs and lies' factor starts to hurt vice-president

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush has picked himself up off the floor and reopened a narrow poll and credibility lead over Al Gore in the US presidential election.
fields.body:
George W Bush has picked himself up off the floor and reopened a narrow poll and credibility lead over Al Gore in the US presidential election.

Mr Bush went into last night's second televised debate with Mr Gore oozing with fresh confidence after a damaging week for the Democratic nominee. Since opening up a lead over Mr Bush in mid-August, Mr Gore has struggled to rebut damaging claims that he bent the facts during last week's first televised debate.

As the two men arrived in North Carolina for yesterday's debate - the second of three this month - a range of opinion polls showed Mr Bush recapturing a narrow lead nationally, recovering in key battleground states and even threatening to carry Mr Gore's home state, Tennessee.

A Washington Post/ABC News poll showed Mr Bush reversing the vice-president's lead from the start of the month, establishing a 48% to 45% lead over Mr Gore, with Ralph Nader, the Green candidate a distant third on 3% and Pat Buchanan of the Reform party on 1%.

Two daily tracking polls - based on a three-day rolling sample in which one third of the total sample is changed daily - also confirmed Mr Bush's lead. A Gallup poll for CNN and USA Today put him ahead by 47% to 44%, while a Zogby poll for Reuters put him ahead by 43% to 42%. The Pew Research Centre also gave him a one-point lead.

There was some more good news for Mr Bush in the most important state of all, California, where a statewide Zogby poll had the Republican narrowing Mr Gore's recent double-figure lead to six points: Mr Gore led Mr Bush by 45% to 39%. The vice-president still leads in the most recent polls in the battleground states.

Although Mr Gore was at first widely perceived to have "won" last week's first debate, the polls have steadily swung towards Mr Bush in recent days. Dissatisfaction with Mr Gore's performance at first focused on his audible sighs of exasperation about Mr Bush's answers during the Boston debate, but has now focused on the vice-president's questionable embellishments in his own responses.

In last week's debate, Mr Gore told three anecdotes - about his own role in disaster relief, about Florida school overcrowding and about an Iowa pensioner's struggle to pay for medicines - aspects of which were untrue.

Voters' exasperation with him is reflected in the Pew survey that shows only 48% of Democrats view themselves as "strong backers" of Mr Gore, compared with 63% of Republicans who identify themselves as strong backers of Mr Bush.

The bad publicity for Mr Gore's self-inflicted "sighs and lies" at the Boston debate showed little sign of abating yesterday as Republicans pounced on a February 1988 memo to Mr Gore by his then press secretary which stated: "Your main political pitfall is exaggeration. Be careful not to overstate your accomplishments."

Republican researchers also unearthed a 1979 statement by Mr Gore in a congressional committee hearing that he had "raised 10,000 chickens" as a farmer in Tennessee, a claim which has not otherwise featured on his curriculum vitae for the White House.

"Ever since the debate, which he won by a small margin, the news about Gore has been dominated by his embellishments and exaggerations and that has been more dominant in the news than anything," said the pollster John Zogby yesterday.

Mr Gore pledged to "do my best to get the details right" in last night's debate.

With less than four weeks to go before the November 7 election, the two final debates - in Winston-Salem and next week in St Louis - have taken on an even greater significance amid the apparent voter volatility. Mr Gore still leads comfortably on most of the issues which voters tell the pollsters are important to them, but Mr Bush is profiting from the vice-president's slippage on questions of character.

webTitle: Girl's body found in river as inquiry starts

fields.headline: Girl's body found in river as inquiry starts
fields.standfirst: Hopes of finding second girl alive fade as search widens to Irish sea
fields.trailText: The body of a schoolgirl was recovered from a swollen river yesterday as police launched an investigation into a tragic school adventure trip from which another girl is still missing.
fields.body:
The body of a schoolgirl was recovered from a swollen river yesterday as police launched an investigation into a tragic school adventure trip from which another girl is still missing.

The body of 14-year-old Rochelle Cauvet was found 18 hours after the accident by search teams in the swollen river Ribble just west of the boundary of the Dales national park.

The body of Hannah Black, 13, has not been found but hopes were fading that she could still be alive.

Yesterday afternoon, as torrential rain gave way to bright autumn sunshine, the search was extended to the Ribble estuary, 50 miles from the scene of the accident, where the river flows into the Irish sea near Lytham St Anne's.

North Yorkshire police called off the search as night fell and will resume operations at first light today.

Rochelle, from Stourton Grange, Leeds, and Hannah, from Rothwell, Leeds, were pupils at Royds School at Oulton, near Leeds.

With 13 other teenagers and two teachers, a man and a woman, they were spending a week in the Dales based at Ingleton. At 3.25pm on Tuesday, the girls, believed to have been wearing blue anoraks and green helmets, were carried away as they were "river walking" in a rushing beck half a mile above the village of Stainforth.

Police said one of the girls caught her foot in a rock and was helped by a teacher and another girl. As her foot came free from her boot, she lost her balance.

She slipped from the teacher's grip and fell into the water, dragging the other girl with her. A boy also fell into the water but was saved by a teacher as the foaming brown waters of the beck threatened to wash him away.

Police confirmed that they have spoken to the two teachers but have not carried out formal interviews.

"We will carry out an investigation on behalf of the coroner," said Detective Superintendent Ian Lynch, who led the operation to recover the body.

"We will have to speak with the education authority, the teachers involved in the trip and the children who were involved when the two young children fell into the water."

Det Supt Lynch said it was too early to say whether the inquiry would turn into a criminal investigation. Much of the inquiry will centre on the decision by the teachers to take the children into the stream which had risen quickly, fed by waters flowing from the fells to the east.

Royds' head teacher, Peter Roberts, said Leeds education authority was also investigating the tragedy which had left the whole school community "devastated".

He told reporters: "We have been doing residentials for 13 years, 2,500 have been involved, and this is the first accident we have had."

Mr Roberts said he shared the concern that parents might feel about how the children came to be in the beck, but it was too early to talk about blame.

All the students involved in the residential trips, based at four centres across the north of England, were brought back by coach with staff last night. Counselling was made available at the school for all students yesterday, Mr Roberts said.

Iain Peter, chief executive of an outdoor pursuits centre at Plas-y-Brenin in north Wales, said gorge or river walking was regarded as an emergency activity because it was so dangerous.

Students on the centre's courses were trained how to cross rivers in spate as part of their mountain training. "But it's an incredibly dangerous business and best avoided," said Mr Peter. "It's so easy to underestimate how powerful water can be.

"You need a very good reason for going in. It's hard to see how it is either an adventure or a fun activity. It's not a paddle in a river."

The school party entered the Stainforth beck about half a mile below the waterfall at Catrigg Force.

Rochelle's body would have been carried past boulders and round bends towards Stainforth, passing under a wooden bridge near the edge of the village and then under a stone bridge next to the Craven Heiffer, the village pub, and close to the parish church. Half a mile west, the beck joins the Ribble which flows south through the market town of Settle.

The body travelled for five miles and came to rest in reeds on a bend between the hamlets of Rathmell and Mearbeck.

"Despite the best efforts of everyone involved in the search, unfortunately and sadly shortly after 9.30am the child's body was seen in the water at Rathmell," said Det Supt Lynch.

The body was spotted from the Lancashire police helicopter by a water bailiff with intimate knowledge of the local river system.

"The search team at ground level was directed [to the river bend] and confirmed that there was an object in the water," added Det Supt Lynch.

"The police underwater search unit entered the river and with the assistance of a canoeist confirmed that it was a body.

"It was a surprise that they found the child's body so close to Settle. Where the other child is found remains to be seen. But hopefully we will find that child alive ... As every hour passes, the chances for the other child diminish. But no one has given up hope."

Rochelle's body was taken to Airedale hospital in Keighley, West Yorkshire, where it was due to be examined by a Home Office pathologist. Rochelle's family was informed. The families of both girls had been taken by police to the Falcon Manor hotel south of Settle.

Police said that the Cauvet family are "absolutely distraught" and too distressed to comment.

fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac yesterday condemned a series of attacks on French synagogues, as tensions between Muslim and Jewish communities outside the Middle East were stretched to breaking point by Israeli-Palestinian violence.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and David Pallister
fields.body:
President Jacques Chirac yesterday condemned a series of attacks on French synagogues, as tensions between Muslim and Jewish communities outside the Middle East were stretched to breaking point by Israeli-Palestinian violence.

In Egypt, a formal investigation was opened into violent clashes on Tuesday between police and students in Cairo, which left one police officer and nine soldiers wounded.

A number of smaller Muslim protests in Britain have resulted in the arrest for public order offences of 12 members of the militant Al-Muhajiroun group in London, Birmingham and Manchester, police said.

And police are investigating the daubing of racist graffiti at the Fieldgate Street synagogue in Whitechapel, east London.

In France, a synagogue in Trappes, west of Paris, was burned to the ground and another, also in the western suburbs, was firebombed early yesterday.

The incidents follow attacks on two Paris synagogues at the weekend, and the throwing of stones at Jewish worshippers in Lyon.

"The president condemns these acts of intolerance," Mr Chirac's spokeswoman said.

Jewish schools and community centres in France have had windows smashed and walls daubed with anti-Jewish slogans, and some 20 assaults on Jews have been reported.

"We do not condone this violence," said Yamine Makri, a Muslim organiser in Lyon. "People must remember that the Jews and Israel are not one and the same thing. But when you see small children up against the world's fourth biggest army, you cannot but protest."

The escalating violence is not one-sided. France's large Muslim community has complained of retaliatory attacks by Jewish groups.

"I have rarely seen such hatred. Everyone's nerves are exposed," said Mouloud Aounit, president of the anti-racist group MRAP, whose office windows were smashed after Jewish radio stations mistakenly identified him as one of the main organisers of anti-Israeli rallies in France.

webTitle: Cold relief warning is hard to swallow

fields.headline: Cold relief warning is hard to swallow
fields.trailText: At the first signs of a cold you could do worse than reach for a bottle of cough mixture from Boots the chemist. The problem is that even if the medicine works you may be left with more than you bargained for.
fields.body:
At the first signs of a cold you could do worse than reach for a bottle of cough mixture from Boots the chemist. The problem is that even if the medicine works you may be left with more than you bargained for.

According to the high street chemist, its medicine Nirolex Day Cold Comfort will bring relief to those runny nosed days and nights. But some sufferers have found the warnings on the side of boxes of the cough mixture a little hard to swallow.

Instructions warn: "This medicine may cause diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, constipation, headache, blurred vision, ringing in the ears, irritability, nightmares, loss of appetite, difficulty in passing urine, rapid heart rate, shaking or skin rashes, sputum (phlegm) retention and sweating." It adds: "If anything else unusual happens talk to your doctor."

Boots said yesterday that it understood why some customers might find the list of possible side effects on its £4.19 cold remedy unpalatable. A spokeswoman said: "This particular product contains three active ingredients and we recognise that the list of side effects can be quite alarming to some people.

"However, the MCA (medicines control agency) requires us to list all reported side effects to any of the active ingredients in the product."

She added that EU directives stated that consumers had the right to be fully informed about all medicines and this had to be done in a "patient-friendly manner".

Nirolex had been approved for its "favourable benefit-risk ratio" and was an extremely popular product, she added.

The medicines control agency, the government body responsible for safety, demands the listing of all side effects reported by various users about every ingredient contained in the medicine.

Roger Odd, of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society, said yesterday: "The list is there for the protection of patients in the event of a rare case when there may be an adverse side effect."

webTitle: It's not cricket, but men throw better

fields.headline: It's not cricket, but men throw better
fields.trailText: It did not look that way when Denise Lewis demonstrated her skill with shot and javelin to win gold in the Olympic heptathlon last month but US researchers say they have discovered an innate difference in men's and women's throwing ability - a difference that does not exist in monkeys.
fields.body:
It did not look that way when Denise Lewis demonstrated her skill with shot and javelin to win gold in the Olympic heptathlon last month but US researchers say they have discovered an innate difference in men's and women's throwing ability - a difference that does not exist in monkeys.

There is a narrow base to the experiment at the US national institute of child health and human development, given such an inflammatory conclusion. Twenty-five human volunteers and 17 capuchin monkeys threw balls or stones into buckets three or six metres away. The results, reported in New Scientist magazine, found men 32% more accurate than women. Female monkeys, however, were no less accurate than male monkeys. The researchers' aim was to explore human evolution but their finding adds to the debate on whether gender differences are innate or learned.

Some will argue that boys get taught and peer pressured into honing throwing skills. But yesterday Rachael Heyhoe Flint, former captain of the England women's cricket team, thought the difference was natural.

"If you went into a playground with eight or nine-year-old children, half boys and half girls, the boys just naturally know how to throw," she said. "There is a physical coordination that the majority of males have over the majority of females. It is very peculiar."

Yet it was a woman, Christina Willes, who, playing with her brother in the 19th century, invented overarm bowling to overcome the obstruction of her crinoline. Mrs Heyhoe Flint had a suggestion to eliminate gender bias in one sport in the light of the latest research: "Perhaps we should have a team of monkeys playing cricket for England."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The man accused of murdering Jill Dando is expected to hear today if he is to be committed to the Old Bailey for trial.
fields.body:
Dando accused appears in court

The man accused of murdering Jill Dando is expected to hear today if he is to be committed to the Old Bailey for trial.

Barry Michael George, 40, appeared before Bow Street magistrates in central London yesterday to hear the prosecution outline its case, and his lawyer, Michael Mansfield QC, argue he should not be sent to crown court. He was charged in May with murdering the TV presenter outside her Fulham home in April 1999.
Nick Hopkins

Perils of internet shopping

Internet shoppers had problems with an average 37% of online purchases, according to the Trading Standards Institute.

Some 38% of orders did not arrive at the specified time and 17% did not arrive at all. Bigger, well known retailers were deemed among the worst offenders.

Scaffold pole spears bus

A Salford bus driver and four passengers escaped serious injury when a 20ft scaffolding pole speared through the driver's seat and several rows of passenger seats. The bus had collided with a scaffold tower.

Sisters could not live apart

Britain's longest surviving sisters have died. Sophia Lacy passed away at 102 on Tuesday, five days after the funeral of Margery, 106. Both were unmarried and lived at a nursing home in Neath, south Wales.

Chat show hunt as Evans quits

Channel 4 is seeking a host for TFI Friday after Chris Evans quit the chat show's final series, which is due to start on November 3.

webTitle: Why Hizbullah's kidnap gamble is likely to pay off

fields.headline: Why Hizbullah's kidnap gamble is likely to pay off
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Madeleine Albright's office
Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office
Israeli government
Palestinian National Authority
fields.trailText: You will no longer find Hizbullah at Sheba'a. Its militants melted away within hours of kidnapping three Israeli soldiers on Saturday, an action which prompted fears that Israel would go to war against Lebanon, and even Syria too.
fields.body:
You will no longer find Hizbullah at Sheba'a. Its militants melted away within hours of kidnapping three Israeli soldiers on Saturday, an action which prompted fears that Israel would go to war against Lebanon, and even Syria too.

Hizbullah set up a position at this spot, where Lebanon, Syria and Israel intersect, as soon as Israel withdrew from south Lebanon in May. Its compound, a stone's throw from Israeli patrols, was one of many such outposts along the frontier. In the runup to the kidnapping, its members wore civilian clothes and kept their weapons hidden. And now they have gone.

You will not find Lebanese soldiers either. For after the Israeli withdrawal, they never came up to the frontier. The most the government did was to dispatch a 1,000-strong force, half-police, half-army, who barely leave their barracks.

Hizbullah has withdrawn because it does not want to be a sitting target for the Israelis, and because it has achieved its aim - to get hold of bargaining counters to win the release of 19 Lebanese held in Israeli prisons, including two Hizbullah sheikhs kidnapped by Israel.

Hizbullah's second-in-command, Sheikh Naim Kassem, said yesterday that his group would accept the mediation of the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, in any prisoner exchange.

Hizbullah does not want a resumption of generalised war in the south - it knows that it would be greatly unpopular if it were seen to have gratuitously reignited such fighting. And it seems confident of avoiding such a war, despite Israeli threats.

It is argued here that Israel's larger, immediate dilemma - how to deal with Palestinian violence and the anger that fuels it - is so overwhelming that it would be taking an enormous gamble if it acted hastily on this, essentially secondary, front, opening up the risk of a military showdown with Syria.

There is also no way Israel could rescue its soldiers by force. Nothing would risk their lives more than an onslaught in which many Lebanese civilians died.

The snatch was intended to be seen as a one-time coup de force. Indeed, Hizbullah had given ample warning of its intentions. Since the Israeli withdrawal, its militants had repeatedly insisted that their struggle would only be over with the recovery of the last part of claimed Lebanese territory still in Israeli hands, and, more important, with freedom for the 19 "hostages".

For hostages they clearly are; Israel holds them as bargaining chips for information about its men who vanished in Lebanon in the 1980s.

Their hostage status was a key factor in the finely tuned calculations which are a hallmark of Hizbullah's operations. The calculations may well have paid off again - international mediators have made it plain that they see a swap as morally acceptable and politically sensible.

One thing is almost sure. If the calculations are wrong, and the Israelis opt for a military solution, Hizbullah will immediately be back on the frontier again.

fields.headline: Fast movers (2): the thieves' favourites
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The people carrier, vehicle of choice for the New Labour middle classes, is the car least fancied by car thieves, according to Home Office research.
fields.body:
The people carrier, vehicle of choice for the New Labour middle classes, is the car least fancied by car thieves, according to Home Office research.

The official 1999 index of car theft in Britain shows that when it comes to a Ford Galaxy or the Renault Espace, five out of every 1,000 are stolen each year, while a 16-year-old Toyota Carina is the car most likely to be stolen, with 154 thefts per 1,000.

The figures were disclosed yesterday as the home secretary, Jack Straw, launched an anti-car crime campaign to highlight how simple measures can dramatically cut theft.

Mr Straw said car crime was down 17% in three years but motorists could cut it further by parking in safe areas, using alarms and immobilisers, shutting windows, locking doors, and not leaving things on display.

"One in eight of thefts are from vehicles that have simply been left unlocked by the driver," he pointed out.

The trend for modern cars to be fitted with ever more sophisticated anti-theft devices means that thieves are now targeting older cars. Cars that are 15 years old have the highest theft rate - 27 per 1,000 stolen each year. In comparison, cars first registered in 1997 had a theft rate of four per 1,000 cars.

Mr Straw admitted that his car, a 1986 Ford Orion, was stolen some years ago in his Blackburn constituency, and he only got it back after he of fered a reward. Its steering lock had been broken, but he still owns the car and uses it.

The Home Office says 391,271 cars are stolen each year, and the government is aiming for a 30% cut by 2004. Somebody whose car is broken into on average ends up £100 out of pocket. If a car is driven off but recovered it costs its owner an average of £470.

webTitle: Complaints against doctors up by a third

fields.headline: Complaints against doctors up by a third
fields.standfirst: Rising complaints show growing dissatisfaction with doctors
fields.trailText: Complaints against doctors are set to rise by more than a third this year, the General Medical Council has said. The GMC's professional conduct committee, which hears cases against doctors, expects to sit for a marathon 50 weeks next year to cope with the increase.
fields.body:
Complaints against doctors are set to rise by more than a third this year, the General Medical Council said yesterday.

The GMC's professional conduct committee, which hears cases against doctors, expects to sit for a marathon 50 weeks next year to cope with the increase.

Complaints to the GMC are predicted to reach 4,300 by the end of this year, compared with 3,000 in 1999.

Not all the accusations will be heard by the GMC. Some will be dealt with by NHS complaints procedures and others concern trivial grumbles.

But the 43% increase reflects a growing dissatisfaction with doctors in recent years. In 1994, the professional conduct committee sat for just 20 weeks as a single panel.

Next year three panels will sit simultaneously as the GMC attempts to counter criticism that the profession's regula tory body has been too slow to act against and strike off incompetent doctors.

The GMC president, Sir Donald Irvine, disclosed the rise as he announced a public consultation into proposed reform of his beleaguered organisation.

Patients and doctors are invited to give their views on proposals, which will increase lay membership of the GMC, slim down the ruling council and change the way misconduct hearings are handled.

The reforms come after a series of scandals over which the GMC has been slow to react, including the Bristol heart babies inquiry, disgraced gynaecologists Rodney Ledward and Richard Neale, and the serial killer GP, Harold Shipman.

Earlier this year, the British Medical Association passed a vote of no confidence in the GMC. The government has also hinted that it may scrap self regulation of doctors un less the GMC reforms itself. Proposals from a GMC working party involve scrapping the present 104-member council and replacing it with a smaller ruling board of 15-25 people, with around 40% lay membership and a medically qualified president.

They would meet once every four to six weeks and have overall responsibility for the running of the GMC. The board would be backed by a larger conference of up to 200 members - of whom half would be lay - which would meet twice a year.

Under the proposals, the traditional role of the GMC as prosecutor and judge of accused doctors would be split, with a separate hearings agency responsible for preparing cases.

The agency would still come under the umbrella of the GMC, but would have separate staff, management and legal advice.

Sir Donald said: "The GMC has been criticised for being slow and out of touch.

"The proposed changes are part of our sweeping programme of reform which includes clear professional standards for doctors, an education system which produces doctors with the qualities patients expect, regular checks on doctors' performance, and new powers to deal with doctors who fall short of standards.

"Our reforms make it clear that the patient is at the heart of everything we do."

The consultation period will end on November 15 and the GMC council will consider the responses in December, with some reforms being implemented "as soon as possible", Sir Donald said.

The working group chairman, Dr Brian Keighley, was presenting the proposals to the BMA council today.

webTitle: Serbs must face up to Kosovo crimes, says freed reporter

fields.headline: Serbs must face up to Kosovo crimes, says freed reporter
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Like most first-time prisoners, Miroslav Filipovic, the courageous Serbian journalist who was given a seven-year sentence for "revealing state secrets" and "spreading false information", says he learned a great deal from his time behind bars.
fields.body:
Like most first-time prisoners, Miroslav Filipovic, the courageous Serbian journalist who was given a seven-year sentence for "revealing state secrets" and "spreading false information", says he learned a great deal from his time behind bars.

"I shared a cell with two or three others. The inmates were moved around but I usually had Albanians with me. I had never had such close contact with them before," Filipovic said in Belgrade after he was freed on Tuesday on the instructions of the new president, Vojislav Kostunica.

His crime was to be the first Serb journalist to write directly about atrocities in Kosovo and to try to explain how some Serb units attacked Albanian civilians.

He was tried in a military court and held in a military prison in Nis, in southern Serbia. Some of his Albanian fellow inmates were convicted of membership of the Kosovo Liberation Army. Others were awaiting trial. He believes most are innocent and ought to be freed.

"The Albanians treated me well. I made friends with several. I had written about Kosovo and in some way was on their side," he said. They listened together to radio reports of Slobodan Milosevic's downfall.

Exhausted but neatly dressed in a suit, ready for an interview on a Serbian TV channel, Filipovic does not look the part of a brave investigative reporter. Now 50, he was not trying to start a career as a young journalist with a splash. He had not done any critical reporting before he joined the London-based Institute for War and Peace Reporting as its correspondent in Kraljevo, a town in southern Serbia.

"If I had known what would happen to me, I would not have written those articles. I am not so brave," he said. "I was just in the right place at the right time."

What he picked up, and then published, was a series of searing accounts given after the war by several officers and men who had served in Kosovo. One saw a three-year-old Albanian boy beheaded in front of his family. Others witnessed the artillery shelling of defenceless villages, and forces going in to massacre civilians.

Filipovic does not believe that collective guilt can be placed on a whole people. The atrocities were carried out by particular units. But he does not accept that few Serbs knew what was happening in Kosovo.

"Everyone who was in Kosovo knew, as well as their friends and families. They talked about it. There are people who still cannot sleep properly for thinking about what was done," he said.

Unlike most Serbs, he believes that Mr Milosevic and the other suspected war criminals should go on trial in the Hague, not in Serbia. "They will get a fairer trial there," he said.

Serbs have to start to face up to and discuss war crimes fully, he believes. This is vital if good relations are to be restored with Croatia, Bosnia, and Kosovo. "We cannot go forward otherwise."

After some rest, Filipovic plans to write a book and more articles on atrocities. The pieces which caused the military to put him in prison this summer appeared only on the internet.

webTitle: Kray myth lives on at last funeral

fields.headline: Kray myth lives on at last funeral
fields.standfirst: Gangsters and celebrities from Reggie's past keep a low profile as smaller-than-expected crowds turn out for a classic east end send-off
fields.trailText: Things, as they are fond of saying in the east end, are not what they used to be. Not even a Kray funeral. Reggie Kray, the last of the notorious family line, was buried yesterday but the event was a shadow of the send-offs afforded to his mother and brothers before him.
fields.body:
Things, as they are fond of saying in the east end, are not what they used to be. Not even a Kray funeral. Reggie Kray, the last of the notorious family line, was buried yesterday but the event was a shadow of the send-offs afforded to his mother and brothers before him.

No more than 2,500 people turned out to watch the gangster's last trip down the Bethnal Green Road yesterday morning, and the gawpers would have been disappointed by the mourners. The official party was notable more for who was not there than who was. It would have been impressive for an ordinary east end lad perhaps, but not for a Kray. It was a limp end to the legend.

When the twins' mother, Violet, made the same trip in 1982 it is said more than 60,000 people lined the route from undertakers W English & Son to St Matthew's church little more than a mile away; in 1995 when Ronnie was buried similar numbers turned up. Even brother Charlie, whose reputation was far less fearsome than his younger brothers', drew a five figure crowd earlier this year. But each of those occasions had something this by its very nature did not: a real live Kray to look at.

Outside English & Son at 10am, as scores of wreaths were delivered including one from from EastEnders' Barbara Windsor, it seemed the mourners might be outnumbered by the security.

With police keeping a discreet distance, about 100 burly men in dark suits, dark glasses and gold chains cleared a path from the chapel of rest to the horse drawn coach in which Kray's coffin was to be carried. It looked more like a doormen's convention than a funeral. Each wore a red badge bearing the initals RKF (Reggie Kray Funeral), and a red armband.

"They symbolise all the blood and tears that have been spilt over the years," said the head of security, Richard Grayston. "Today is the end of an era, when we close the chapter. I think this is the end of the whole Kray illusion."

Behind the cordon ageing men greeted old acquaintances and swapped stories of failing health and dimly remembered days when the brothers were free. Many of them would once have gone by the euphemistic description "associate of the Krays", but the watching crowds, now swelling, struggled to put names to faces.

This was no surprise. The celebrities the Krays had assiduously courted in their pomp were largely absent although Stephen Berkoff, who played Ronnie's victim George Cornell in the film The Krays, was there. He spoke of the twins performing "a mythic service in a dull, dreary post-war environment", and providing "a sense of colour and identity".

Also absent were some of the gangsters with whom the Krays stood trial, men who did time for crimes committed on the brothers' behalf. Freddy Foreman, who admitted killing Frank "The Axeman" Mitchell at the Krays' request, was absent, as was Tony Lambrianou who cleaned up the mess after Reggie had stabbed Jack "The Hat" McVitie to death in a flat in Stoke Newington.

Both stayed away after Roberta Kray, who married Reggie three years ago in Wayland prison, Norfolk, declared it was not to be a day for grandstanding by men from Reggie's past. Perhaps the twins, with their respect for strong women, would have approved.

Foreman had visited Kray on his death bed a week ago and left thinking that he was to be a pall bearer. Roberta, however, chose four friends from Reggie's latter years and Foreman stayed away. Two of them, Bradley Allardyce, an armed robber who shared a cell with Kray in Maidstone prison, and Tony Mortimer, former singer of East 17, were not even born when the Krays went down in 1968.

The service at St Matthew's was also dominated by characters from his last days, and focused on Kray the reformed Christian, not the hoodlum who stabbed McVitie so ferociously his liver fell out.

Kray's solicitor, Mark Goldstein, gave an address. "I had first hand knowledge of his generosity. Reg was an icon of the 20th century," he said, before the coffin left the church to Frank Sinatra's My Way.

Back on the Bethnal Green Road, as the cortege of 18 hearses began the journey to the family plot in Chingford cemetery, opinions were mixed as to the significance of the day. One shopkeeper, a Pakistani who moved to the east end two years ago, said he did not understand the fuss. "I have seen the film though," he said. Edward Peek, 82, had nothing but regrets. "He was a nice man, he'd help anyone. May he rest in peace," he said.

At the cemetery a planned flypast by a Spitfire failed to happen. Sam Glazebrook and his pal David Kerr, both 16, had bunked off school in Ruislip, Middlesex, to be there.

"He is an idol. He stood for good morals. There were nasty things too but I think he was a good man who was misunderstood," said Sam, adding that he thought the streets were safer when Reggie was free, too. The last of the Krays may be dead, but there is some life in the old myth yet.

webTitle: Dick Morris on Al Gore's unpopularity

fields.headline: No one wants teacher's pet to be head boy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A story is making the rounds in US politics of a tycoon who decided to invest in a dog food company. He hired the top market research people, the best packaging experts, a front-rank media firm and a highly regarded public relations company.
fields.body:
A story is making the rounds in US politics of a tycoon who decided to invest in a dog food company. He hired the top market research people, the best packaging experts, a front-rank media firm and a highly regarded public relations company.

After spending tens of millions, however, sales were dismal. Gathering his minions together, he demanded to know why his investment was not paying off. "The dogs won't eat the food," the promotional team concluded.

This is Al Gore's problem. No matter how his speechwriters, image consultants, issue experts and pollsters package him, the US people just don't like Al Gore. They do not want to spend the next four years listening to his lectures, tolerating his patronising attitude or watching his pious posturing. If the president is going, constantly, to be in our face, Americans figure, let him be, at the very least, appealing.

Al Gore comes across as the teacher's pet - the earnest, fresh faced boy in the class who always has the right answer. The teacher loves him and the other students hate the sight of him.

A curious dichotomy emerged in the reactions to the first Gore-Bush debate. The experts - myself included - watched the ebb and flow of the arguments and concluded that Mr Gore had won, decisively. He out-debated his inarticulate rival, scoring point after point, aiming his shots with precision. Mr Bush seemed to flounder, unable to respond effectively. To us it was a knockout.

But the public saw it differently. After an initial round of polls indicating Mr Gore had "won", Mr Bush began to move ahead smartly. As evidence mounted that the Democrat had misrepresented his role in meting out sympathy to flood victims in Texas and had exaggerated the extent of overcrowding in a Florida school, voters turned away from Mr Gore.

By the week's end, the CNN-Gallup poll showed Mr Bush pushing above 50%.

The issues clearly work for Mr Gore. Few disagree that he could best handle problems such as gun control, the environment and poverty. Even on issues the GOP (Grand Old Party) contests, such as education and healthcare, Mr Gore wins decisively in most polls.

Public enthusiasm for Mr Bush's tax cuts is sharply limited, and most identify with Mr Gore's spending priorities - eliminating the national debt and solidifying the fiscal basis for social security and Medicare.

So why don't Americans vote for Mr Gore? Because they just do not like him.

With the differences between the candidates so narrow, Americans feel at liberty to indulge their affections rather than their ideology in casting their votes.

While some voters speak of Mr Bush's superior character, most just frankly admit that they like him. They like his cockeyed grin, his torturous English, his sense of himself, his willingness to be human.

Mr Gore seems too anxious to please and too willing to lie. He said he invented the internet, founded the strategic petroleum reserve and worked on his farm in Tennessee. He was shot at in Vietnam. His marriage was the model for the film Love Story. His mother sang a union song as a lullaby. His mother-in-law pays more for her medicine than for her dog's. As a crusading journalist, his stories sent politicians to jail.

All appealing anecdotes. But all are untrue.

The harmless quality of his Walter Mitty inventions only serve to remind Americans that Mr Gore is artificial. Reared as the son of a senator in a Washington hotel room he called home, Mr Gore is like the baby born in a bubble to limit his exposure to the germs other people carry.

With issues counting for little and the country doing fine, distinctions of character and personality become the fulcrum for the election.

Ironically, the success of Bill Clinton and Al Gore has paved the way for George W Bush.

 Dick Morris was chief strategist for President Clinton in his successful 1996 re-election campaign. He is head of www.vote.co.uk

webTitle: Protesters will come out again, Socialists warned

fields.headline: Protesters will come out again, Socialists warned
fields.standfirst:
New president's aide gives three-day ultimatum to Milosevic cronies
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Unexpectedly stubborn resistance by Slobodan Milosevic and his Socialist party allies to the loss of the Yugoslav presidency has pushed Serbia to the brink of new street protests and created a dangerous struggle for power.
fields.body:
Unexpectedly stubborn resistance by Slobodan Milosevic and his Socialist party allies to the loss of the Yugoslav presidency has pushed Serbia to the brink of new street protests and created a dangerous struggle for power.

The Socialists have walked out of talks on forming an interim government to rule Serbia until the elections in December, and they insist that they still run the republic's police force.

In response, President Vojislav Kostunica and his colleagues are planning to bring back the popular anger which turned the federal parliament and the state television headquarters into smoking ruins last week.

"If they delay [Serbian] elections we will bring the demonstrators out again in three days," said Zoran Djindjic, the chief strategist behind the movement which brought Mr Kostunica to victory.

Mr Djindjic's driver and the bodyguard of another party leader were detained by eight men in plain clothes as they sat in their car outside his office late on Tuesday night. Although they were freed two-and-a-half hours later it was a reminder of the power that the old regime still has to harass Mr Kostunica's team.

A week after the popular uprising which forced Mr Milosevic out of office, Serbia has entered a limbo in which Mr Milosevic is mounting a rearguard action by mobile phone while the new rulers find it hard to sideline him completely and achieve a full transfer of power. The contra diction is well illustrated by Mr Djindjic. "He [Milosevic] is a private citizen who's protected by the presidential guard, which is an elite unit of the army," Mr Djindjic said.

A dissident philosopher who was persecuted under Tito and lived in Germany for 12 years, Mr Djindjic leads the Democratic party, the largest member of the 19-party alliance known as the Democratic Opposition of Serbia. As Mr Kostunica's campaign manager, he is widely seen as the mastermind behind the successful strategy of strikes and protests which was launched when Mr Milosevic tried to force a runoff.

One reason why the new rulers cannot act more decisively is that they have only won power over federal institutions. The Serbian presidency, parliament and government are still controlled by the Socialist party.

Another reason is that Mr Kostunica does not want to be too radical. "We could make a revolution but it wouldn't be good. It would create too much instability," Mr Djindjic said. "Our problem is that we want to change as much as possible without overstepping the boundary of legality. To some extent the crisis which the Socialists have provoked by refusing to discuss the formation of a new government is one of posturing. The Kostunica camp controls the street, and most of Mr Milosevic's allies cannot go outside their houses without bodyguards.

"The Socialist party has no structures anymore," he said. "Milosevic can give orders by phone but there are no instruments to carry them out."

The Yugoslav army chief of staff, General Nebojsa Pavkovic, cannot send army units against protesters. But he can block changes.

Similarly, police at the grassroots level would not dare tp act against crowds although sections of them - such as security service operators who still tap telephones - are an irritant, Mr Djindjic said.

The media is completely in the hands of the Kostunica team, with many analysts claiming that Mr Milosevic made a major blunder by not conceding defeat after the first round. Then he would have avoided the muscle-flexing street protests and the loss of Serbian state television.

With the television still in his hands, Mr Milosevic would have been in a much stronger position to resist the changes today. Mr Djindjic is not surprised that people have not so far tried to storm Mr Milosevic's mansion.

"We kept things under control last week, going after him was not part of the plan. We didn't want to risk lives."

But he admitted that the events of last Thursday, when protesters set fire to the parliament and the TV headquarters, were not planned.

When Mr Milosevic tried to push the election into a second round, the opposition developed its strategy of civil disobedience. There were to be five days of street blockades in every major city in Serbia to show that people were not ready to accept the fraud. Next would come a coal miners' strike to show the opposition's industrial muscle. Finally, protesters would converge on Belgrade from all over the country in convoys of buses.

"We planned to occupy buildings in Belgrade and then use them as a base from which to negotiate Mr Milosevic's departure. But more happened than we thought," Mr Djindjic said.

Parliament and the television offices were burned, and the police switched sides. The constitutional court went into reverse and declared Mr Kostunica the election winner.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Thousands protest at Eta killing | Africa debt of £820m written off | Ex-nuclear plant's staff arrested | Neo-Nazi crimes rise in Germany | Sri Lanka faces hung parliament
fields.body:
Thousands protest at Eta killing

Hundreds of thousands of Spaniards poured on to the streets in a show of revulsion at the latest killing by Eta, the Basque separatist group.

Candlelit marches and vigils were held throughout the country on Tuesday night after the shooting of a senior lawyer in Granada, southern Spain.

Luis Portero, 59, the chief prosecutor at Andalucia's superior justice tribunal, was shot through the head at his home on Monday. He was the 14th victim attributed to Eta since it ended a truce at the start of the year.

The largest protest took place in Granada itself, where more than 100,000 people packed the streets, chanting "Eta out" and waving the palms of their hands covered in white paint.

Outside the town hall, they heard the city's mayor deliver a defiant speech against violence. "Our future is written in two words - peace and freedom," Jose Moratalla said. Earlier, the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, who led the mourners in Granada's 15th-century cathedral, had urged Spaniards "to continue showing their outrage and keep faith in the government's policy". His words prompted rallies in Madrid, Seville and several Basque cities.

Portero is the first lawyer to be killed in the current wave of violence and follows the crackdown by Spanish police and magistrates on members of Eta's political wing last month. Madrid has also given the courts special powers to charge juveniles who take part in pro-Eta riots.
Adela Gooch, Madrid

Africa debt of £820m written off

China will write off more than £820m owed to it by the poorest African states to help boost development and strengthen Beijing's ties with the continent.

Yesterday's announcement by the foreign trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, came on the second and penultimate day of a Sino-African forum in Beijing that China hopes will position it as a leader of the developing world. Forty-four African countries have sent heads of state or senior officials to the Chinese capital.

Liberia and Malawi also sent observers, though they have diplomatic ties with Taiwan and will not receive any debt relief, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman said.

Aid, often low-or zero-interest loans repayable on flexible schedules, has been a pillar of Chinese ties with Africa. Chinese officials have not put a figure on the country's total loans to Africa, but Mr Shi said Beijing would cancel 10bn yuan (£820m) owed by "heavily indebted poor countries and the least-developed countries in Africa in the next two years".

Beijing hopes that writing off a portion of its loans will encourage other countries and financial institutions to write off the continent's £220bn of foreign debt.

Mr Shi said China will also gradually boost assistance to Africa in line with its own economic growth, and will give credit incentives for Chinese firms to invest in Africa.
AP, Beijing

Ex-nuclear plant's staff arrested

Japanese police made the first arrests yesterday concerning the worst nuclear accident since Chernobyl.

Six former executives and employees of JCO - the plant operator - have been charged with negligence resulting in death for illegally changing the safety manual to cut costs at the uranium processing plant in Tokaimura, 80 miles north-east of Tokyo, in September last year.

Lacking training and following the illegal guidelines, two men mixed almost eight times the safe amount of uranium, using stainless steel buckets rather than a machine, setting off a chain reaction that raged for almost 20 hours.

Both men died, at least 439 people were exposed to radiation and some 200,000 residents were told to close their windows and stay indoors.

Police also plan to charge JCO and its then president, Hiroharu Kitani, for breaching nuclear reactor laws.

The government hopes the arrests will draw a line under the accident, which has crushed public confidence in an industry that generates about a third of Japan's electricity. But environmental groups criticised the police for failing to consider the responsibility of nuclear safety authorities, which had not inspected the JCO plant for seven years before the accident.
Jonathan Watts, Tokyo

Neo-Nazi crimes rise in Germany

Crimes against immigrants and Jews nearly doubled in Germany during August, the interior ministry said. Officials attributed part of the rise to the public reporting more incidents - the government has recently urged Germans to take a stand against neo-Nazis.

There were 1,112 offences committed in the following month, compared to an average of 668 in the first seven months of the year, the ministry said. Crimes against foreigners rose to 403, from an average of 210, while anti-semitic offences rose to 121, from an average of 68.

There is little sign of the violence abating, with several minor attacks on synagogues and other Jewish sites recently. On Tuesday, the authorities in the eastern city of Dessau said vandals had attacked the memorial to Alberto Adriano, a Mozambique-born immigrant whose murder by skinheads became a focal point for concern over racism in Germany.

In a statement yesterday the ministry said that the latest figures showed "it was right to step up police surveillance and efforts to punish those responsible for these crimes, and that this must continue". Few would dispute that. But the fact that neo-Nazi crimes have increased since the government announced its crackdown leaves its methods open to criticism.

A row is already simmering over the authorities' key initiative - an attempt to ban the extreme right National Democratic party of Germany (NPD). The NPD has reported a surge in membership applications since the initiative.

The interior minister, Otto Schily, who was originally sceptical about the effectiveness of such a move, confirmed on Monday that he would be seeking a ban. He said he was confident he could secure the backing of a majority of Germany's regional governments, needed to make a request to the constitutional court.

The federal cabinet is expected to approve a petition to the court next month, but the Greens, the junior partners in Germany's centre-left coalition, remain uneasy.
John Hooper, Berlin

Sri Lanka faces hung parliament

Sri Lanka was last night heading for a hung parliament after early results from a general election indicated that neither the governing People's Alliance nor the United National party (UNP) would get the seats required for a majority.

A hung parliament would mean that the president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, and the opposition leader, Ranil Wickremasinghe, would have to work together, even though their personal relationship in recent months has often been characterised by personal animosity.

Ms Kumaratunga wants the constitution to be altered to include a devolution package that would allow Tamil majority areas in the north and east to have more autonomy, to try to bring an end to the 17-year civil war in which 60,000 people have died.

But Mr Wickremasinghe has criticised her for not entertaining the idea of talking to the Tamil Tigers. Without their support or consent, he argues, a political settlement will be impossible to implement.

Both the alliance and UNP were set to start some frantic horse trading to win support from smaller parties.

Many may be attracted to the governing coalition, because Ms Kumaratunga can appoint and dismiss ministers and retains the finance and defence portfolios. Under the country's emergency legislation she can even ignore the parliament.

fields.bodyText: Thousands protest at Eta killing Hundreds of thousands of Spaniards poured on to the streets in a show of revulsion at the latest killing by Eta, the Basque separatist group. Candlelit marches and vigils were held throughout the country on Tuesday night after the shooting of a senior lawyer in Granada, southern Spain. Luis Portero, 59, the chief prosecutor at Andalucia's superior justice tribunal, was shot through the head at his home on Monday. He was the 14th victim attributed to Eta since it ended a truce at the start of the year. The largest protest took place in Granada itself, where more than 100,000 people packed the streets, chanting "Eta out" and waving the palms of their hands covered in white paint. Outside the town hall, they heard the city's mayor deliver a defiant speech against violence. "Our future is written in two words - peace and freedom," Jose Moratalla said. Earlier, the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, who led the mourners in Granada's 15th-century cathedral, had urged Spaniards "to continue showing their outrage and keep faith in the government's policy". His words prompted rallies in Madrid, Seville and several Basque cities. Portero is the first lawyer to be killed in the current wave of violence and follows the crackdown by Spanish police and magistrates on members of Eta's political wing last month. Madrid has also given the courts special powers to charge juveniles who take part in pro-Eta riots. Adela Gooch, Madrid Africa debt of £820m written off China will write off more than £820m owed to it by the poorest African states to help boost development and strengthen Beijing's ties with the continent. Yesterday's announcement by the foreign trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, came on the second and penultimate day of a Sino-African forum in Beijing that China hopes will position it as a leader of the developing world. Forty-four African countries have sent heads of state or senior officials to the Chinese capital. Liberia and Malawi also sent observers, though they have diplomatic ties with Taiwan and will not receive any debt relief, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman said. Aid, often low-or zero-interest loans repayable on flexible schedules, has been a pillar of Chinese ties with Africa. Chinese officials have not put a figure on the country's total loans to Africa, but Mr Shi said Beijing would cancel 10bn yuan (£820m) owed by "heavily indebted poor countries and the least-developed countries in Africa in the next two years". Beijing hopes that writing off a portion of its loans will encourage other countries and financial institutions to write off the continent's £220bn of foreign debt. Mr Shi said China will also gradually boost assistance to Africa in line with its own economic growth, and will give credit incentives for Chinese firms to invest in Africa. AP, Beijing Ex-nuclear plant's staff arrested Japanese police made the first arrests yesterday concerning the worst nuclear accident since Chernobyl. Six former executives and employees of JCO - the plant operator - have been charged with negligence resulting in death for illegally changing the safety manual to cut costs at the uranium processing plant in Tokaimura, 80 miles north-east of Tokyo, in September last year. Lacking training and following the illegal guidelines, two men mixed almost eight times the safe amount of uranium, using stainless steel buckets rather than a machine, setting off a chain reaction that raged for almost 20 hours. Both men died, at least 439 people were exposed to radiation and some 200,000 residents were told to close their windows and stay indoors. Police also plan to charge JCO and its then president, Hiroharu Kitani, for breaching nuclear reactor laws. The government hopes the arrests will draw a line under the accident, which has crushed public confidence in an industry that generates about a third of Japan's electricity. But environmental groups criticised the police for failing to consider the responsibility of nuclear safety authorities, which had not inspected the JCO plant for seven years before the accident. Jonathan Watts, Tokyo Neo-Nazi crimes rise in Germany Crimes against immigrants and Jews nearly doubled in Germany during August, the interior ministry said. Officials attributed part of the rise to the public reporting more incidents - the government has recently urged Germans to take a stand against neo-Nazis. There were 1,112 offences committed in the following month, compared to an average of 668 in the first seven months of the year, the ministry said. Crimes against foreigners rose to 403, from an average of 210, while anti-semitic offences rose to 121, from an average of 68. There is little sign of the violence abating, with several minor attacks on synagogues and other Jewish sites recently. On Tuesday, the authorities in the eastern city of Dessau said vandals had attacked the memorial to Alberto Adriano, a Mozambique-born immigrant whose murder by skinheads became a focal point for concern over racism in Germany. In a statement yesterday the ministry said that the latest figures showed "it was right to step up police surveillance and efforts to punish those responsible for these crimes, and that this must continue". Few would dispute that. But the fact that neo-Nazi crimes have increased since the government announced its crackdown leaves its methods open to criticism. A row is already simmering over the authorities' key initiative - an attempt to ban the extreme right National Democratic party of Germany (NPD). The NPD has reported a surge in membership applications since the initiative. The interior minister, Otto Schily, who was originally sceptical about the effectiveness of such a move, confirmed on Monday that he would be seeking a ban. He said he was confident he could secure the backing of a majority of Germany's regional governments, needed to make a request to the constitutional court. The federal cabinet is expected to approve a petition to the court next month, but the Greens, the junior partners in Germany's centre-left coalition, remain uneasy. A hung parliament would mean that the president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, and the opposition leader, Ranil Wickremasinghe, would have to work together, even though their personal relationship in recent months has often been characterised by personal animosity. Ms Kumaratunga wants the constitution to be altered to include a devolution package that would allow Tamil majority areas in the north and east to have more autonomy, to try to bring an end to the 17-year civil war in which 60,000 people have died. But Mr Wickremasinghe has criticised her for not entertaining the idea of talking to the Tamil Tigers. webTitle: BA cuts flights at Gatwick to reduce losses

fields.headline: BA cuts flights at Gatwick to reduce losses
fields.trailText: British Airways is to suspend its services to Kuala Lumpur next year because it is losing money on the route, the company said yesterday. The service is being withdrawn to reduce BA's loss-making operation at Gatwick. It is part of a move to trim the airline's capacity at the airport by 15%.
fields.body:
British Airways is to suspend its services to Kuala Lumpur next year because it is losing money on the route, the company said yesterday. The service is being withdrawn to reduce BA's loss-making operation at Gatwick. It is part of a move to trim the airline's capacity at the airport by 15%.

BA will maintain a sales presence in Malaysia, offering connections through Singapore. But it plans to resume its own flights to Melbourne from Heathrow four times a week. Currently the only "BA" services are its code share operated by alliance partner Qantas. The resumption of flights to Australia will be the first for two years.

Reducing the losses at Gatwick has been one of the priorities of Rod Eddington, BA's new chief executive. The company loses £300m a year on its short-haul operations from Gatwick and makes only a small profit on long haul.

The short-haul changes include the suspension of services to Ljubljana in Slovenia and Salzburg in Austria, the suspension of Heathrow services to Jersey, and the halving and eventual withdrawal of flights between Heathrow and Paris Orly.

Some successful routes, such as Rome, Prague, Munich, Barcelona and Frankfurt, will see increased frequencies.

Mr Eddington said: "Our drive to return our business to proper levels of profitability is moving up a gear. We must properly address poorly performing routes."

webTitle: Market woes lead to chorus of dismay

fields.headline: Market woes lead to chorus of dismay
fields.standfirst: Notebook
fields.trailText: Time to sell has gone - as usual
fields.body:
Time to sell has gone - as usual

Remember all those gold rush analogies, where investors in the new economy were warned that the man supplying the shovels was always going to make more money than those doing the digging? Well, yesterday there were worrying signs that, in an internet infrastructure sense, the handle might be coming adrift from the blade.

Both diggers and shovel-sellers took the brunt of the stock market's irritation as Lucent, the big US networking specialist, and mobile maker Motorola became the latest internet darlings to warn that the hills of the new economy are not quite as rich as first thought.

At moments like this it is worth remembering the Twelve Choruses of a Market Cycle, as identified by the American financial author John Train. *

1. The Washout or Selling Climax: "Stocks are going way down."

2. The Early Surge: "Things look better, but its too early to buy."

3.The Surge Continues: "Prices seem high. It's too late to buy."

4. The Second Stage of the Rocket: "Maybe it's ok to buy."

5. Not a Cloud in the Sky: "Buy!"

6. The Blowoff: "Stocks can only go up."

7. Coasting: "The market is high, but this time is different."

8. The Top: "Hold."

9. Over the Hump: "It's too soon to sell."

10. The Slide: "Prices are cheap, but it's too late to sell."

11. "It's OK to sell."

12. The Cascade: "Sell!"

Anyone with half an eye on the London market over the past 12 months will see how Train's pop-analysis fits.

On November 4 last year, the Stock Exchange launched its new-fangled TechMark 100 index, designed to give fresh focus to companies with high growth potential. Retail investors went wild and the TechMark surged 45% in the space of eight weeks.

The market was singing Chorus 5. Business news was excellent, jazzy investment vehicles, such as internet incubators, were springing up all over the place. A particular area of the market had become manic, with prices quickly bid up to irrational levels.

By Christmas, the market had moved on to Chorus 6. To quote Train, writing five years earlier: "Hot managers become famous. Young, glib, impatient of conventional wisdom, they collect huge sums from trustful greedy investors hoping for miracles. They chase new themes as a pack."

The early months of this year epitomised Chorus 7 - business starts to peak, but a conviction has already developed that the business cycle has been mastered. Market operators manufacture stock to feed quacking investors.

The top, Chorus 8, was clearly reached at the beginning of March when the TechMark 100 stood at 5743, up 135% in four months. The intervening months, during which the TechMark has lost close to 40% of its value, have probably seen us through 9 and 10 - "It's too soon to sell" and "It's too late to sell."

So there has to be a risk now that we are heading for the final choruses.

11: "Often some extrinsic event punctures the balloon, such as a stunning major bankruptcy," Train writes. "After a while we may see a severe decline...[but] there is often a powerful deceptive rally, which one might call a 'trap rally'."

12: "Now the river sweeps over the brink, carrying everything with it. A cardinal point of market strategy, if one is a trader at all, is to get out before this cascade..."

*Global Guide to Investing, edited by James Morton, Pitman Publishing.

Go gure

A £400m hole, and how to fill it. This is the problem the government faces as a result of its logical plan to update the way social security is paid in the 21st century. Out goes grubby old cash, in comes payment through bank accounts.

In the process, beleaguered post office masters and mistresses lose a combined £400m in business. At the same time the government faces another irritation: how to pay benefits to 3m claimants who do not have bank accounts at all?

This so-called "financial exclusion" dilemma was being tackled by the Treasury, which had ordered the banks to set up basic bank accounts, without overdrafts, to reach the "unbanked". The banks, who like rich customers rather than poor ones, are now even more annoyed by the plan for the universal bank which they believe duplicates these efforts inside the Post Office.

Profits and costs are the only thing banks care about, however much they might protest publicly. At the very least it looks as if they will have to pay out £130m annually, through what many regard as a recurring windfall tax.

It is hard to sympathise with a sector making billions in profits, but the figures are hazy and the calculations a mystery. It is time everyone, including bank shareholders, was told how they were reached and when they might diminish.

fields.headline: Electricity price hopes dashed
fields.trailText: Government hopes of overseeing a cut of at least 10% in domestic electricity bills before the next general election took a nosedive yesterday when the industry regulator postponed an important reform.
fields.body:
Government hopes of overseeing a cut of at least 10% in domestic electricity bills before the next general election took a nosedive yesterday when the industry regulator postponed an important reform.

Ofgem said reform of the wholesale power trading market, the Pool, could not now take place until after January 30 next year. Ministers had hoped the new trading arrangements, known as Neta, would begin on November 21.

The complex trading arrangements, which are designed to bring a better balance of supply and demand and hence competition to electricity generation, require extensive testing of computer systems.

But Ofgem, which had planned to launch Neta between October 30 and mid-December, said a full dummy run of the new arrangements could not go ahead as planned because of initial problems.

While the delay was not unexpected, it raised the prospect that the reforms would not be in place until the winter of 2001. Ofgem said Neta could not be introduced during the holiday period it set between December 14 and January 30 because of fluctuating and uncertain demand.

"We won't start end-to-end testing until we are completely sure that everything is right. When we know a date we will make a statement," an official said.

With an election likely in May, consumers may not have seen any benefit before they cast their votes.

fields.headline: October is the cruellest month
fields.trailText: The City does not like October and with good reason: the stock market calamities of 1927 and 1987 fell in this autumnal month, as did the hedge fund crisis of 1998. So far October 2000 is showing signs of being another bleak time
fields.body:
The City does not like October and with good reason: the stock market calamities of 1927 and 1987 fell in this autumnal month, as did the hedge fund crisis of 1998. So far October 2000 is showing signs of being another bleak time

Yesterday, bourses across the globe were in retreat having downed a cocktail of dreadful news ranging from earnings disappointments to fears of default in the junk bond market.

In London, a sea of red engulfed trading screens sending the FTSE 100 index down 130.1 points to 6,117.6 - a four and half month closing low. It has fallen 273 points this week.

Elsewhere, the Techmark tumbled 178.7 to 3,440.11 - its lowest close since early August - and the FTSE 250 shed 134.8 to 6,461.5.

In Europe it was much the same picture with the CAC-40 in Paris ending below its 1999 closing level and Germany's Neuer Markt falling to its lowest level of the year.

The reasons for the retreat were too numerous to mention but they had one thing in common - they came from the other side of the Atlantic.

The market had to contend with a string of disappointing US earnings reports and the legacy of another dreadful performance from Nasdaq on Tuesday night. This continued into Wednesday taking the Dow Jones industrial average with it.

Late on Tuesday, Lucent, the world's largest telecommunications equipment company, cut its profit forecast for the third time this year and Yahoo! indicated that advertising revenue was beginning to slow. On top of tha,t mobile phone company Motorola lowered its 2001 earnings expectations.

If all of that were not enough, there were rumours that a big investment bank had taken a bath in the junk bond market. Various names were being mentioned by jittery traders from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to Deutsche Bank.

Technology, media and telecom (TMT) shares, the most highly rated in the market, were hit hardest in the rout. Telecom company Energis fell 49p to 395p, advertising outfit WPP gave up 61p to 693p, while internet security group Baltimore Technology dived 48p to 561p and software concern Logica surrendered 167p to £19.80.

Lucent's troubles left optical chip maker Bookham Technology looking exposed and the stock duly plunged 404p, or 14.11%, to £24.60, the worst performer in the FTSE 100. Telecoms equipment maker Marconi was also rattled by Lucent's woes, closing 57p lower at 839p.

Things were not much better away from TMTs. It was another day of pain for Marks & Spencer shareholders. The shares fell 5.5p to 183p as SG Securities set a 165p target price.

Banks were also in the doldrums as competition fears continued to cut into stock prices. Barclays fell 42p to £16.72 and Royal Bank of Scotland lost 41p to £12.99.

Amid the carnage, oil stocks of all shapes and sizes offered a safe haven. With the oil price continuing to gush higher the sector offers the prospect of rising, not falling earnings. BP advanced 11.5p to 638p, while Shell put on 16p to 597.5p. Lower down, Lasmo advanced 7.5p to 143.25p and Enterprise Oil gained 35p to 600p.

Elsewhere, worried investors were busy seeking out defensive stocks. Tobacco groups BAT , up 8.5p to 447.5p, and Imperial Tobacco , 23.5p higher at 663.5p, were particular favourites.

The prize for ramp of the day went to composite insurer Royal & Sun Alliance . Its shares improved 10.5p to 457p on renewed talk of a bid from a European rival. The shrewder players pointed out that as an insurer Royal was a good defensive stock that boasts a solid yield of 5.5%.

Lower down, control systems group Roxspur slipped 10p to 24.5p after discussions over a management buyout ended. Newcomer Raft International , a supplier of software to financial institutions, ended at 64.5p, a 0.5p premium to its offer price.

fields.headline: Powell Duffryn in play
fields.trailText: Confusion reigned over the near-term prospects for Powell Duffryn yesterday.
fields.body:
Confusion reigned over the near-term prospects for Powell Duffryn yesterday.

Shares in the ports and engineering group, which received a mystery takeover approach in July, slipped 13p to 565p despite reports that a £500m bid from the private equity arm of a Japanese bank - either Nikko, IBJ International or Daiwa - could be on the way.

There is a risk that such a deal might not happen but with nearly 78m shares in issue a £500m bid for Powell would value each at just below 650p. Not surprisingly, sector specialists were telling clients to stick with Powell Duffryn shares yesterday.

Analysts at Old Mutual Securities reiterated their "hold" rating and set a share price target of 620p-640p. At WestLB Panmure, analysts were said to be telling clients that, based on the multiples implied by the failed bid for rival Forth Ports earlier this year, fair value for Powell shares was 640p-650p.

fields.headline: At this price?  SkyePharma
fields.trailText: Two of the City's biggest investment banks are tussling over the prospects for SkyePharma, the FTSE 250 drug delivery outfit headed by Ian Gowrie-Smith.
fields.body:
Two of the City's biggest investment banks are tussling over the prospects for SkyePharma, the FTSE 250 drug delivery outfit headed by Ian Gowrie-Smith.

On Friday, Swiss bank CSFB issued a "sell" note and said the shares were worth just 50p. German rival Dresdner Kleinwort Benson yesterday countered by initiating coverage of the stock with a "buy" rating and a 140p target price.

SkyePharma's shares, which hit a month's low of 61p after the CSFB note, responded by rising 3p to 66p. So who is right?

For two years SkyePharma has been transforming itself into a one-stop shop for pharmaceutical companies looking to outsource their drug delivery needs. Its range of delivery techniques can, for example, help reduce side effects and improve patient compliance. Instead of taking several tablets a day, a patient might take just one.

Dresdner argues that SkyePharma is a lower-risk play on the growth of this sector because it is underpinned by a rising number of product partnerships, a diversified portfolio and low regulatory risk, given that key products are already launched or approvable.

Concerns remain about visibility of the revenue streams. In its sell recommendation, CSFB cited disappointment at a change in the company's trial strategy.

With the proceeds of a £57m bond issue tucked away, SkyePharma decided to delay seeking marketing partners for a number of promising products until much later in the development phase. In theory, this should allow SkyePharma to maximise its royalty income. In practice, it means the move to profitability will be delayed by six or even 12 months, while its risks have been concentrated.

The stock is one to watch - from a safe distance - while the picture becomes clearer.
