fields.headline: Double standards
fields.standfirst:
The US celebrates Serb freedom, but the case of the Palestinians is, apparently, different

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Misreported and hopelessly flawed from the start, the Oslo peace process has entered its terminal phase - of violent confrontation, disproportionately massive Israeli repression, widespread Palestinian rebellion and great loss of life, the vast majority of it Palestinian.
fields.body:
Misreported and hopelessly flawed from the start, the Oslo peace process has entered its terminal phase - of violent confrontation, disproportionately massive Israeli repression, widespread Palestinian rebellion and great loss of life, the vast majority of it Palestinian. Ariel Sharon's visit to Haram al-Sharif on September 28 could not have occurred without Ehud Barak's concurrence. How else could the paunchy old war criminal have appeared there with a thousand soldiers guarding him? Barak's approval rating rose from 20% to 50% after the visit, and the stage seems set for a national unity government ready to be still more violent and repressive.

The portents of this disarray, however, were there from the 1993 start. Labour and Likud leaders alike made no secret of the fact that Oslo was designed to segregate the Palestinians in non-contiguous enclaves, surrounded by Israeli-controlled borders, with settlements and settlement roads punctuating and essentially violating the territories' integrity, expropriations and house demolitions proceeding inexorably through the Rabin, Peres, Netanyahu and Barak administrations along with the expansion and multiplication of settlements (200,000 Israeli Jews added to Jerusalem, 200,000 more in Gaza and the West Bank), military occupation continuing and every tiny step taken toward Palestinian sovereignty - including agreements to withdraw in minuscule, agreed-upon phases - stymied, delayed, cancelled at Israel's will.

This method was politically and strategically absurd, even suicidal. Occupied East Jerusalem was placed out of bounds by a bellicose Israeli campaign to decree the intractably divided city off limits to Palestinians and to claim it as Israel's "eternal, undivided capital". The 4m Palestinian refugees - now the largest and longest existing such population anywhere - were told that they could forget about any idea of return or compensation.

With his own corrupt and stupidly repressive regime supported both by Israel's Mossad and the CIA, Yasser Arafat continued to rely on US mediation, even though the US peace team was dominated by former Israeli lobby officials and a president whose ideas about the Middle East were those of a Christian fundamentalist Zionist with no exposure to or understanding of the Arab-Islamic world. Compliant, but isolated and unpopular Arab chiefs (especially Egypt's President Mubarak) were compelled humiliatingly to toe the American line, thereby further diminishing their eroded credibility at home. Israel's priorities were always put first, as was its bottomless insecurity and its preposterous demands. No attempt was made to address the fundamental injustice done when Palestinians as a people were dispossessed in 1948.

Behind the peace process were two unchanging Israeli/American presuppositions, both of them derived from a startling incomprehension of reality. First was that given enough punishment and beating over the years since 1948, Palestinians would ultimately give up, accept the compromised compromises Arafat did in fact accept, and call the whole Palestinian cause off, thereafter excusing Israel for everything it has done. Thus, for example, the "peace process" gave no considered attention to immense Palestinian losses of land and goods, none to the links between past dislocation and present statelessness, while as a nuclear power with a formidable military, Israel nevertheless continued to claim the status of victim and demand restitution for genocidal anti-semitism in Europe. Incongruously, there has still been no official acknowledgement of Israel's (by now amply documented) responsibility for the tragedy of 1948, even as the US went to war in Iraq and Kosovo on behalf of other refugees. But one can't force people to forget, especially when the daily reality was seen by all Arabs as endlessly reproducing the original injustice.

Second, after seven years of steadily worsening economic and social conditions for Palestinians everywhere, Israeli and US policymakers persisted (stupidly, I think) in trumpeting their successes, excluding the UN and other interested parties, bending the disgracefully partisan media to their wills, distorting the actuality into ephemeral victories for "peace". With the entire Arab world up in arms over Israeli helicopter gunships and heavy artillery demolishing Palestinian civilian buildings, with almost 100 fatalities and almost 2,000 wounded (including many children) and with Palestinian Israelis up in arms against their treatment as third-class, non-Jewish citizens, the misaligned and skewed status quo is falling apart. Isolated in the UN and unloved everywhere in the Arab world as Israel's unconditional champion, the US and its lame duck president have little to contribute any more.

Neither does the Arab and Israeli leadership, even though they are likely to cobble together another interim agreement. Most shocking has been the total silence of the Zionist peace camp in the US, Europe and Israel. The slaughter of Palestinian youths goes on and this band of supposed peace-lovers either backs Israeli brutality or expresses disappointment at Palestinian ingratitude. Worst of all is the US media, completely cowed by the fearsome Israeli lobby, with commentators and anchors spinning distorted reports about "crossfire" and "Palestinian violence" that eliminate the fact that Israel is in military occupation and that Palestinians are fighting it, not "laying siege to Israel", as the ghastly Mrs Albright put it. While the US celebrates the Serbian people's victory over Slobodan Milosevic, Clinton and his minions refuse to see the Palestinian insurgency as the same kind of struggle against injustice.

My guess is that some of the new Palestinian intifada is directed at Arafat, who has led his people astray with phony promises, and maintained a battery of corrupt officials holding down commercial monopolies even as they negotiate incompetently and weakly on his behalf. Some 60% of the public budget is disbursed by Arafat to bureaucracy and security, only 2% to the infrastructure. Three years ago his own accountants admitted to an annual $400m in disappeared funds. His international patrons accept this in the name of the "peace process", certainly the most hated phrase in the Palestinian lexicon today.

An alternative peace plan and leadership is slowly emerging among Israeli, West Bank, Gaza and diaspora Palestinians. No return to the Oslo framework; no compromise on the original UN resolutions (242, 338, and 194) "mandating the Madrid conference in 1991; removal of all settlements and military roads; evacuation of all the territories annexed or occupied in 1967; boycott of Israeli goods and services. A new sense may actually be dawning that only a mass movement against Israeli apartheid (similar to the South African variety) will work. Certainly it is sheer idiocy for Barak and Albright to hold Arafat responsible for what he no longer fully controls. Rather than dismissing the new framework being proposed, Israel's supporters would be wise to remember that the question of Palestine concerns an entire people, not an ageing and discredited leader. Besides, peace in Palestine/Israel can only be made between equals once the military occupation has ended. No Palestinian, not even Arafat, can really accept anything less.

Edward Said's book, The End of the Peace Process, will be published by Granta.

fields.headline: New horizons for Time
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The privately-owned Time computer group is rolling out a 150-strong chain of retail outlets specialising in "life technology" products.
fields.body:
The privately-owned Time computer group is rolling out a 150-strong chain of retail outlets specialising in "life technology" products.

The Time Talk stores will be a mixture of stand-alone and concession outlets located in Powerhouse stores and inside some of its own 206-strong Time Computers retail chain outlets. The Time Group is investing £2m in the venture and has already started opening the new outlets. A spokesman said the group was rolling out the new shops at 10 a week.

"Time Talk will be selling state-of-the-art consumer technology such as mobile phones, Palm 5s, personal organisers and laptops and is looking to take a piece of the growing consumer technology market within the coming year," said the company.

The new chain is focusing on a tough marketplace where aggressive discounting is the norm and prices are being cut to the bone. It will take Time into head-to-head competition with groups such as Dixons and Carphone Warehouse together with online retailers such as Jungle.com and letsbuyit.com.

Mike Phillipson, marketing director of the Time Group said: "Time Talk will build upon the Time heritage and we are confident it will complement our successful track record in computer retailing.

"We will be treating our customers as human beings, not sales targets."

The expansion plan is Time's first venture away from its core computer market.

fields.headline: After Donald ...
fields.standfirst:
The untimely death of Scotland's first minister leaves an awkward problem for the prime minister
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Donald Dewar has died too soon, in both the personal and political senses. He also came back to work too quickly after heart surgery - friends who spoke to him then found that he was anxious about his senior colleagues' inability to cope without him.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar has died too soon, in both the personal and political senses. He also came back to work too quickly after heart surgery - friends who spoke to him then found that he was anxious about his senior colleagues' inability to cope without him.

Had it not been for his guile and sagacity, the launch of the Scottish parliament in 1999 would not have been merely limp: it might have been disastrous. Not long before his death he compared the process to "political abseiling". For the Labour party it was a jump into the abyss of coalition government with the Lib Dems and proportional representation, a system that allowed the Scottish Tories back into parliamentary politics.

For Tony Blair, Dewar's greatest value was that he de livered a stable and reasonably obedient parliament amid fears that it would be a much more troublesome beast. Dewar, highly respected at Westminster and influential everywhere in Scotland, was uniquely capable of doing this.

The possible Labour successors to Dewar are either at the ceiling of their competence or politically immature. Henry McLeish, the obvious candidate, does not stir the blood. He is plodding and competent as the minister for enterprise and lifelong learning, but Blair does not rate him highly. Dewar himself conspicuously failed to endorse him as his successor.

Indeed, McLeish chose a career in Edinburgh rather than at Westminster after hints from the prime minister about where his better prospects lay. McLeish's anger over the party's deci sion not to hold an election for the post of deputy leader in the Scottish parliament - which he might have won - has been all too apparent.

Finance minister Jack McConnell may be a candidate. But he, too, has his critics. His career was barely affected by the so-called Lobbygate affair over the issue of preferential access to ministers: he was implicated but eventually exonerated. Observers say he is lazy, shirks his brief and tends to "wing it" in meetings. He often gets away with it because he is quick-witted.

But even his enemies acknowledge that McConnell is "good at schmooze", a quality singularly lacking in Wendy Alexander, Dewar's and almost certainly Blair's own preferred successor. Indeed, a friend who lunched with Dewar shortly before his death noted that he fulmi nated against senior colleagues who shot their mouths off to journalists, but in the case of his beloved protegee, who also was known to call the press, he was much more indulgent. "That's Wendy," he would say.

Alexander, the minister for communities, is respected for her intelligence, her hard work, her integrity and her ideals. But her inter-personal skills and media manner are much less secure. And her standing has slumped since she bungled the reform of section 28. Alexander is criticised for shirking the process of consultation later forced on the executive by Stagecoach millionaire Brian Souter and his allies. Although the section was repealed in Scotland, but not in England thanks to the Lords, the damage lingers on.

Most of the criticism of the parliament's performance so far has been shallow, concerned with what are essentially growing pains. More perceptive critics in all the parties are disturbed by two trends. The first is for the public to confuse the executive with the parliament itself: many would prefer it to be called the "Scottish government". The second is the executive's tendency to impose its decisions, Westminster-style, on what it hopes will be a supine parliament. So far there has been only one sig nificant rebellion, on the bill to abolish debt recovery by means of humiliating warrant sales, and even that may fizzle out.

The Scottish parliament - not the Labour party - will elect the new first minister. It would be nice but foolish to think that enough Labour MSPs might turn away from their own unappetising slate and endorse Jim Wallace, the Lib Dem who has been quietly growing in the job of deputy first minister and will act in that role until Dewar's successor is chosen. Under the parliament's rules the task must be completed within 28 days.

What Blair may want in the short term is someone who can keep the parliament in line. But beyond that he must be looking with great apprehension to the next general election. According to the latest polls, the Nationalists are level with Labour for the first time since 1997. Rebel Labour MP Dennis Canavan has already resigned from the Commons to force a by-election in Falkirk West. Dewar's death means another in Glasgow Anniesland.

It would be surprising if Blair's mind did not turn to John Reid, the former defence secretary now twiddling his thumbs at the Scottish Office - the post is much attenuated: once the Scottish Office was a major spending department. It would be surprising if Blair did not want to give Reid a key role in Labour's fight against the SNP. But Gordon Brown regards Scotland as his own fiefdom and may have ideas of his own. Without Donald Dewar, devolution is much more dangerous.

Arnold Kemp is a columnist for the Observer in Scotland

Dewar, highly respected at Westminster and influential everywhere in Scotland, was uniquely capable of doing this. The possible Labour successors to Dewar are either at the ceiling of their competence or politically immature. Henry McLeish, the obvious candidate, does not stir the blood. He is plodding and competent as the minister for enterprise and lifelong learning, but Blair does not rate him highly. Dewar himself conspicuously failed to endorse him as his successor. Indeed, McLeish chose a career in Edinburgh rather than at Westminster after hints from the prime minister about where his better prospects lay. McLeish's anger over the party's deci sion not to hold an election for the post of deputy leader in the Scottish parliament - which he might have won - has been all too apparent. Finance minister Jack McConnell may be a candidate. But he, too, has his critics. His career was barely affected by the so-called Lobbygate affair over the issue of preferential access to ministers: he was implicated but eventually exonerated. Observers say he is lazy, shirks his brief and tends to "wing it" in meetings. He often gets away with it because he is quick-witted. But even his enemies acknowledge that McConnell is "good at schmooze", a quality singularly lacking in Wendy Alexander, Dewar's and almost certainly Blair's own preferred successor. Indeed, a friend who lunched with Dewar shortly before his death noted that he fulmi nated against senior colleagues who shot their mouths off to journalists, but in the case of his beloved protegee, who also was known to call the press, he was much more indulgent. "That's Wendy," he would say. Alexander, the minister for communities, is respected for her intelligence, her hard work, her integrity and her ideals. But her inter-personal skills and media manner are much less secure. And her standing has slumped since she bungled the reform of section 28. Alexander is criticised for shirking the process of consultation later forced on the executive by Stagecoach millionaire Brian Souter and his allies. Although the section was repealed in Scotland, but not in England thanks to the Lords, the damage lingers on. Most of the criticism of the parliament's performance so far has been shallow, concerned with what are essentially growing pains. More perceptive critics in all the parties are disturbed by two trends. The first is for the public to confuse the executive with the parliament itself: many would prefer it to be called the "Scottish government". The second is the executive's tendency to impose its decisions, Westminster-style, on what it hopes will be a supine parliament. So far there has been only one sig nificant rebellion, on the bill to abolish debt recovery by means of humiliating warrant sales, and even that may fizzle out. The Scottish parliament - not the Labour party - will elect the new first minister. It would be nice but foolish to think that enough Labour MSPs might turn away from their own unappetising slate and endorse Jim Wallace, the Lib Dem who has been quietly growing in the job of deputy first minister and will act in that role until Dewar's successor is chosen. Under the parliament's rules the task must be completed within 28 days. What Blair may want in the short term is someone who can keep the parliament in line. But beyond that he must be looking with great apprehension to the next general election. According to the latest polls, the Nationalists are level with Labour for the first time since 1997. Rebel Labour MP Dennis Canavan has already resigned from the Commons to force a by-election in Falkirk West. Dewar's death means another in Glasgow Anniesland. It would be surprising if Blair's mind did not turn to John Reid, the former defence secretary now twiddling his thumbs at the Scottish Office - the post is much attenuated: once the Scottish Office was a major spending department. It would be surprising if Blair did not want to give Reid a key role in Labour's fight against the SNP. But Gordon Brown regards Scotland as his own fiefdom and may have ideas of his own. Without Donald Dewar, devolution is much more dangerous. Arnold Kemp is a columnist for the Observer in Scotland

 An item headed Northern grit, panel, page 45, Education, October 10, gave a misleading impression of the views of Yorkshire Forward, the Yorkshire and Humber regional development agency. webTitle: Letters: Wrapped up in the flag

fields.headline: Wrapped up in the flag
fields.trailText: It is rich that a government which rode the wave of "cool Britannia" is now seriously considering a report which concludes that the word "British" has racist connotations (British tag is 'coded racism', October 11)
fields.body:
It is rich that a government which rode the wave of "cool Britannia" is now seriously considering a report which concludes that the word "British" has racist connotations (British tag is 'coded racism', October 11). A piece of languagedoes not have connotations. It is how we use it that counts. Change the underlying social practices and structures and the connotations of the word will change. It is naive to think that a government in some Orwellian frenzy can tell us how to speak and somehow this will create a more inclusive society. Language is far more complex then that.

Being truly proud about one's national identity means one is confident enough to include others. To insist that using the word "British" is racist will erode what little confidence a lot of British people have and lack of confidence can lead to pathological hatred and resentment or petty nationalism.

Incidentally, I am Canadian-British - from the country that actually invented multiculturalism. Racism is still an issue there but its government spends its time and money on real policies for social change.
Jennifer Griffin
London

The extraordinary thing about Lord Parekh's Runnymede Trust report is that the commissioners see no difficulty about it being introduced by Jack Straw. You simply cannot have a multi-ethnic Britain if the home secretary and his ministers go on attacking bogus asylum seekers and bogus gypsies in the way they do and so long as they persist with the policy of dispersal and vouchers. Not surprisingly the report has wandered off into a discussion of abstractions in a way which will give widespread offence.
Prof John Rex
Centre for research in ethnic relations, University of Warwick johnrex@clara.net

At the Sydney Olympics black British gold medalist Denise Lewis wrapped herself in a union flag (described as a "racist" flag). In France, people from ethnic minorities with French citizenship are proud to call themselves French. There is racism but there's a recognition that it's a multi-racial society. For a Briton to claim his or her citizenship is "racist" is totally unjustified if not ridiculous. It would be far better to educate children against racial prejudice.
Clare Hartley
London
C.Hartley@macmillan.co.u

The union flag must be adopted by parliament as the national flag of the UK. This has never been done and the flag remains a royal flag, used by ordinary citizens with permission. That permission is unlikely ever to be revoked. If parliament, in cross-party unison, were to adopt it as the national flag it would become the flag of all British citizens, of whatever background or ethnicity.
Michael Faul
The Flag Institute

I very much welcome the thinktank's conclusion that "British" has racial connotations. Over several centuries, many Welsh, Scottish, Irish, Manx and Cornish people have been more than irritated by the arrogant assumption (cue Lord Tebbit) that they should be grateful to be part of greater England, this assumption often being connected with the common usage of "British" as meaning English.

Speed the day when we are allowed to adopt the identities that we feel happy with.
Dr Brian Stowell
Manx Branch, Celtic Congress

So if I describe myself as British it's racist, is it? What should I describe myself as then, a Teletubby?
Barnaby Brocklehurst
London

webTitle: Leader: The quick and the dead

fields.headline: The quick and the dead
fields.standfirst: A message for Geoff Hoon
fields.trailText: How a nation remembers its dead says much about the living. Few Russian cities lack imposing, sometimes histrionic memorials to the Soviet dead of the second world war. The massively impressive stone salute to the Red Army in Treptow, East Berlin, is not easily missed or forgotten, not least by Germans.
fields.body:
How a nation remembers its dead says much about the living. Few Russian cities lack imposing, sometimes histrionic memorials to the Soviet dead of the second world war. The massively impressive stone salute to the Red Army in Treptow, East Berlin, is not easily missed or forgotten, not least by Germans. Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia is America's principal shrine, the place "where valor proudly sleeps". Its website plays Taps to internet visitors and recommends the Hollywood fantasy, Saving Private Ryan, to all those who would recall the Normandy landings. But there is a universal solemnity here, too, in its quoting of Aeschylus. "Even in our sleep, pain which cannot forget falls drop by drop upon the heart until, in our despair, against our will, comes wisdom through the awful grace of God."

After guiltily debating whether it should remember its war dead at all, Germany has in the past decade launched an extraordinary programme to exhume the remains of its soldiers from unmarked or neglected battlefield sites and reinter them in modern, purpose-built graveyards across eastern Europe. The biggest new cemetery, opened last month at Sologubovka, Russia, will eventually contain up to 100,000 individual remains.

Britain, historically, has been particularly active in sending its young people to their deaths in foreign fields. As King George V once said, "the whole circuit of the earth is girdled with the graves of our dead". The 20th-century victims are remembered on village greens, at the Cenotaph, by poppies, and by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission. Its staff tend, with flowers and gardens in 150 countries, the graves and memorials of 1,694,988 allied servicemen and women. They do an essential, sensitive job. To avoid any appearance of uncaring penny-pinching, defence secretary Geoff Hoon, chairman of the commission, would be wise personally and quickly to ensure they get a fair, agreed wage for doing so.

webTitle: Letters: A strike for Billy Elliott

fields.headline: A strike for Billy Elliott
fields.trailText: I found Charlotte Raven's comments on the miners' strike and the film Billy Elliot bizarre (Silly Billy, G2, October 10). I was on strike at Sliverwood pit near Rotherham and I thoroughly enjoyed the film.
fields.body:
I found Charlotte Raven's comments on the miners' strike and the film Billy Elliot bizarre (Silly Billy, G2, October 10). I was on strike at Sliverwood pit near Rotherham and I thoroughly enjoyed the film. She accuses Stephen Daldry of depicting an inaccurate portrayal of the strike. Obviously, she thinks we used the 12 months on strike against pit closures to sort out personal relationships. Maybe there should have been a scene showing miners sitting around a picket-line fire getting in touch with their inner feelings.

The Thatcher government mobilised the full forces of the state in an attempt to break the miners. Daldry's film shows why the police were seen as Maggie Thatcher's boot boys, paid thugs sent in to mining areas to beat the crap out of the strikers. For me, Billy Elliot is a film about standing up for your beliefs and principles. The acting is superb, the story believable. It is sentimental but what the hell - nowt like a good cry.

By the way, Charlotte, Billy's dad does not go back to work (did you actually see the film?). Money was raised to send Billy for his audition in London from amongst the strikers. If Ms Raven makes a "positive version" of the film about the strike maybe we could have the TUC and the Labour party standing by the miners and bringing down Thatcher. Now that would be shocking and inaccurate, but it should have happened.
Ian Mitchell
Glasgow
g.hubbard@ntlworld.com

A chance for miners to "broaden their horizons"? No - you're mixing up the misery and poverty resulting from the strike with your gap year.
Alex Conway
London

webTitle: Letters: Discordant views on music in the classroom

fields.headline: Discordant views on music in the classroom
fields.trailText: The "dullness" of music lessons (Pop input needed to brighten up music lessons, October 10) derives from a simple linguistic confusion. Music lessons are not lessons in music.
fields.body:
The "dullness" of music lessons (Pop input needed to brighten up music lessons, October 10) derives from a simple linguistic confusion. Music lessons are not lessons in music. They are lessons in the extremely specialist form we call classical music. This form is unlike any other in the world, yet it continues to dominate music lessons as if it defined the whole of music.

In classical music, everything is written out in advance. The aspiring player has no more input than a galley slave. Music lessons are devoted to acquiring total mastery of the instrument, because you never know what you might be asked to play, and wrong notes are not allowed.

This concentration on technique is soulless and soul-destroying for many pupils. It is small wonder that so many stop playing as soon as they leave a school ensemble.

The chauvinism implicit in "music is classical music" means that the teaching profession has failed generations of children. Its effect, because of its presumption of rightness, is malign. It even affects geniuses. The great jazz drummer Max Roach, after several years working with Charlie Parker, thought he would go to college "to get a proper musical education". He failed the audition because they said he wasn't holding the drumsticks properly!
Conrad Cork
Leicester

Some of your assumptions on music learning were dismally predictable. Least helpful to music teachers struggling with limited resources was the view that because "there's a disparity between music in schools and the music that young people like" therefore "teachers trained in classical music need to be brought up to date". I thought that education was about more than just finding what children digest most quickly and feeding it to them.

As long as we bow to the myth that the searching demands of musical training are "boring", we will be leaving our young people untouched by the incredible challenges of a discipline that is continually winning new audiences. My students listen to pop music at home and I use rock in their teaching, but they know better than to assume that the music they have not yet encountered can never become "relevant" to their lives.
Piers Hellawell
Belfast

The answer to the malaise in music lessons, particularly in secondary schools, is not to go downmarket to offer popular commercial styles in a spurious attempt at relevance.

Our European commissioned research in UK schools has demonstrated that integrating new and affordable technology into music lessons motivates pupils by giving them direct and tactile access to the raw materials of music to make their own. This is analogous to the exploration of paint and other basic materials used as a starting point in visual art education.

Such an approach reinvigorates music lessons, opening doors to pupils, even from the most deprived backgrounds, to the widest range of musical genres.
Paul Wright
Sonic Arts Network

fields.headline: It's a 'gaur'
fields.trailText: When Bessie the cow gives birth to a gaur next month it will be no more a contribution to saving extinct species than copying paintings is an insurance against the destruction of originals (The cow, her cloned bison calf and a new era in saving endangered species, October 9).
fields.body:
When Bessie the cow gives birth to a gaur next month it will be no more a contribution to saving extinct species than copying paintings is an insurance against the destruction of originals (The cow, her cloned bison calf and a new era in saving endangered species, October 9). The value of a painting lies in the history of its production. The value of species lies in their natural history. Once this is interrupted whatever follows can only be a less valuable copy of the original. The scientists of advanced cell technology are offering us a "gaur", not a gaur. We need more conservation, not more genetic manipulation.
Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University a.n.h.dobson@pol.keele.ac.uk

webTitle: Letters: How to run the National

fields.headline: How to run the National
fields.trailText: I'm sure Sir Trevor Nunn and his company are grateful to Michael Billington (Stage fright, G2, October 10) for his suggestions on how to programme the three auditoria at the National Theatre, as they would be to any Theatre Studies course if it were asked to contribute: I'm pretty certain it would come up with something similar.
fields.body:
I'm sure Sir Trevor Nunn and his company are grateful to Michael Billington (Stage fright, G2, October 10) for his suggestions on how to programme the three auditoria at the National Theatre, as they would be to any Theatre Studies course if it were asked to contribute: I'm pretty certain it would come up with something similar.

The problem with running theatres is that the more you follow your idealistic instincts, the more crises you are likely to encounter and one crisis is almost certain to shunt into and exacerbate another. This must lead to a revision of the planned programme.

"A gang of young directors who can offer both moral support and artistic input", Mr Billington suggests. Quite right, but remember, if they are worth their salt they are likely to be ambitious for their own careers and unlikely to be tied down when a dazzling opportunity occurs elsewhere.

"There is a world elsewhere," Billington says. What about the superb collaboration that resulted in Speer; a riveting revelation to me and, more so, to younger generations, worth 10 visits to the Holocaust museum?

An ensemble company embracing many ethnic groups will inevitably contain some young and inexperienced actors. But they may eventually attract the audience which John Freeman (I accuse, G2, October 4) says is alienated from today's theatre.
Stuart Burge
Lymington, Hampshire

fields.headline: Tough decisions for a land of opportunity
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic's fall could transform Yugoslavia - if the right policies are pursued
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The fall of Slobodan Milosevic is not only a political event of the first order. It transforms the economic prospects of Yugoslavia, its immediate neighbours and the entire south-east European region.
fields.body:
The fall of Slobodan Milosevic is not only a political event of the first order. It transforms the economic prospects of Yugoslavia, its immediate neighbours and the entire south-east European region. The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, consisting of the republics of Serbia and Montenegro, is in dire economic straits. Ten years of war and isolation and the effects of the Nato bombing campaign in 1999 have reduced gross domestic product measured in US dollars by at least a third since 1989. Recorded unemployment is more than 30% of the labour force.

Last year was specially disastrous with an estimated decline in real GDP of 23%. Agriculture, which accounts for nearly a quarter of GDP, has been badly hit by drought. Inflation is running at 50-60% per annum and the government's budget deficit exceeds 5% of GDP. External debt, now $12bn, is rising steadily, with the country in default on almost all its foreign debt.

About 40% of GDP is produced by the private sector but much of it is in the informal economy. There has been negligible progress on structural reforms. Nearly all large industrial enterprises continue to be in state hands, despite the 1997 privatisation law in Serbia. Confidence in the banking sector is low with little intermediation from savers to productive private enterprises. Domestic capital markets are woefully underdeveloped. The country's infrastructure is in very poor condition. The damage from the bombing campaign was of the order of $3bn-4bn (£2bn-2.7bn).

Yugoslavia is a long way from completing the three early steps for transition to an effective market economy: liberalisation of administered prices (still widespread), privatisation and macro-econom ic stabilisation. The hardest part, creating institutions that will support an effective, competitive market economy, has not yet started. The introduction of sensible laws for economic transactions is an important challenge. Effective regulation of the financial sector and of the natural monopolies (electricity transmission and distribution, gas distribution, the railway network) has to be created from scratch. Protection of minority shareholder and creditor rights has to be established.

The challenges are daunting, but the opportunities are exhilarating. Yugoslavia has common borders with seven countries. It straddles the Danube. Its central location means any improvement in its domestic transportation infrastructure will have positive effects for transport throughout the region. Of course, this will require enormous investment, from domestic as well as international sources. Foreign financial support will depend heavily on direct investment with significant support needed from international financial institutions such as the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

The EBRD has been active in all other countries of south-eastern Europe. The expertise gained in other post-war arenas such as Bosnia and Herzegovina can be useful in Yugoslavia. It is a public institution using private sector projects as its principal instrument. It has also played an important role in the funding of public infrastructure. Basic infrastructure will have to be initially funded with sovereign guarantees and blending multilateral and bilateral concessionary finance. However, ultimately some sectors will also have to be financed with private funding and participation.

In addition to becoming a partner in this restructuring and eventual privatisation of the banking system, the EBRD could promote and co-finance the setting up of a micro-enterprise and small-businesses bank, and the creation of an equity fund to provide risk capital. Under its mandate, the EBRD cannot operate with its own resources in non-member countries. Yugoslavia is not yet a member, because it did not satisfy EBRD requirements for multi-party democracy and respect for human rights. However, since 1999 the EBRD has been active in micro-lending with donor funds rather than its own resources in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

Before the Kosovo crisis there was considerable interest among foreign investors in partnerships with Yugoslav investors. The EBRD can be a catalyst for reviving and promoting this interest. Resource allocation in Yugoslavia has been severely distorted by economic isolation (including import-substituting policies), domestic protectionism and, since 1992, an external embargo. The removal of artificial barriers to trade and factor mobility is a necessary condition for a rational reallocation of resources and sustained growth. In the short run,, such restructuring can involve serious hardship for those involved as workers, entrepreneurs or owners, in the formerly sheltered sectors of the economy.

It is essential that scarce budgetary and foreign concessionary resources be used effectively to provide a social safety net to prevent deprivation without slowing the process of moving human and other resources towards long-run viable uses. Apart from humanitarian concerns, the social costs must be addressed effectively because otherwise popular support for wide-ranging and deep structural reforms will vanish and the reform process will stall and fail.

 Willem Buiter is chief economist at the EBRD

webTitle: JJB ahead of the retail pack

fields.headline: JJB ahead of the retail pack
fields.trailText: Sports store chain JJB has shrugged off the problems engulfing many of its rivals and reported better sales, higher profits and continuing expansion plans.
fields.body:
Sports store chain JJB has shrugged off the problems engulfing many of its rivals and reported better sales, higher profits and continuing expansion plans.

The company, which operates 422 stores, yesterday reported half year profits up from £23.2m to £28.6m on sales driven up 13% by aggressive TV advertising.

Even so, the shares lost ground, closing down 32.5p at 485p. Analysts pointed to the gloom that surrounds the retail sector and said the profits had come in slightly below expectations. They are also concerned about the intensity of competition eroding margins - JJB admitted margins have been cut by promotions such as the 20% discounts on footwear it is offering.

JJB has 25% of the sports retailing market and footwear accounts for 32% of JJB's sales. Clothing brings in 44%, sports equipment and accessories generate 10% while golf and cycles account for 6%. Replica soccer kit makes up the remaining 8%, marginally less than a year ago. JJB said England's poor showing in Euro 2000 was reflected in sales of three lions shirts.

Finance director David Greenwood said he was unconcerned about the share price reaction: "Shares go up and down and retailers are not really flavour of the month."

The company's improvement comes as smaller sports retailers are struggling to compete with the prices the bigger operators are offering. There have been several casualties among independent outlets in recent months and Mr Greenwood predicted more.

JJB's expansion strategy involves closing smaller city centre stores and concentrat ing on superstores. It closed 27 high street stores in the last six months and opened 13 superstores. JJB said the cost of the closures knocked £1.5m off profits. The group now has 214 superstores but believes there is room in the market for 500 to 600 such outlets.

JJB is experimenting with leisure clubs with superstores built on top. The first opened with 1,500 members paying £29.50 a month in Oldham this week and two more are planned for St Helens and Halifax next year. "It seems like a good concept", said chief executive Duncan Sharpe. "But we will see how they go before deciding whether to open more."

The company is revamping its website, recently voted one of the worst. Mr Sharpe said he believed the online offering was relatively unimportant. "In three years' time it might produce half the turnover of one superstore".

webTitle: Dressed-down Ted Baker seeks global brand extension

fields.headline: Dressed-down Ted Baker seeks global brand extension
fields.trailText: The demise of the tie is creating a whole new clothing market, according to retailer Ted Baker.
fields.body:
The demise of the tie is creating a whole new clothing market, according to retailer Ted Baker.

The group, whose shares have outperformed the market by 43% in the past 12 months, has just opened a new Ted's The Business store in London's Canary Wharf to cater for City workers who need help with "dressing down".

Ties will be banned in the store, and Ted Baker's chief executive, Ray Kelvin, who founded the group 13 years ago, is threatening to burn any worn on the premises.

"The store's taking plenty of money, so if that continues to do well we will open another one," said Mr Kelvin.

Ted Baker was announcing profits for the first 28 weeks of the year down from £2.9m to £2.1m. The decrease was due to the costs of opening four additional stores and moving into a new head office in north London - known as The Ugly Brown Building. "It is ugly, and it is brown", said Mr Kelvin, "But it is also a great place to work."

Two more stores have opened since the end of the half-year and Ted Baker now operates 15 in the UK and one in New York.

Ultimately, said Mr Kelvin, the group may open another six outlets, but its energies are now being focused on developing Ted Baker as a global brand. The group has licensing agreements with 170 retail customers in the US. "That us where the bulk of our growth will come from".

Turnover was up 23.8% to nearly £20m in the first half and in the last eight weeks, retail sales have climbed 34% with wholesale sales up 76%.

Yesterday the shares closed down 41p at 417p, but relatively few shares changed hands and analysts remain positive about group prospects. Rowan Morgan at Teather & Greenwood said he was a "strong buyer", adding: "This is a brand with the potential to go global."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: A strong contender steps forward to challenge for Stupidest MP 2000. He is Christopher Chope, Tory MP for Christchurch.
fields.body:
 A strong contender steps forward to challenge for Stupidest MP 2000. He is Christopher Chope, Tory MP for Christchurch.

A champion of "caring Conservatism", Mr Chope was featured in the Sunday People arguing at the recent Tory party conference that the disabled should be paid less than the minimum wage on the grounds that they are slower workers.

In the explanatory press release, Mr Chope explains his position more fully: "The minimum hourly wage penalises the slow, inexperienced and disabled by pricing them out of jobs."

Ah, so the minimum wage actually hurts more than just the disabled ... why didn't we see it before? "Those who produce goods and services of equal quality but take longer are losing out," he continues. "That is why the minimum wage and the working time directive should be abolished for all." We ring him to ask if he was quite well when he wrote this.

"What do you mean?" Well, were you fully compos? "What is the purpose of this conversation? There is nothing wrong with the press release. I've shown it to others who think there's nothing remarkable about it at all." Click, brrrr. Who now will dare stereotype the Conservatives as "the stupid party"?

 Meanwhile, that party's candidate for Henley answers a questionnaire in the rightwing Freedom Today magazine.

Whatever the reason - probably the death of his dear friend Reggie Kray - Boris the Jackal Johnson seems on combative form. "You what, son?" replies the Jackal, asked about abuse.

"Want some do you? Eh? Is that what you want? Well, you've come to the right place. I'll f****** give you some ..." Oh dear.

In the weeks ahead, by the way, the Diary will interview eager young people, keen to make their way, whatever that means, who may be willing to spare some time next year and stand for parliament in a certain Thames-side constituency.

Anyone interested themselves, or who knows someone who might be, should apply in the usual manner.

 An invitation arrives to Peter Stringfellow's 60th birthday party on October 17. "Does it get any better than this?" the invite asks. Yes it does ... especially since there is doubt as to whether the old boy will be there?

Stringy is believed to be spending the month in the American midwest, touring embryo clinics in the search for the perfect shade of yellow for his next girlfriend's hair.

Still, Stringy or not, there is every chance that my old friend Terry Major-Ball will be present, and on that basis the invitation is sorely tempting.

 Apparently this has already appeared in his Express column, but given that newspaper's highly restricted readership, we are technically justified according to a recent Press Complaints Commission adjudication in claiming as exclusive the news that Peter Hitchens has nominated himself for a people's peerage.

Declining to discuss his referees, Peter says he fancies his chances "if the government is serious about it being truly representative, going for the widest possible groups ...".

Indeed. I have a nomination form in front of me now, and - despite pleas from Peter Bottomley, Lord Lloyd-Webber and the boulevardier Andrew Neil to have a go myself - I am considering whether to propose my sane and rational friend Paul Johnson instead.

 Things must be particularly exhilarating in New Zealand at the moment, judging by the front page splash in the broadsheet Sunday Times. A

Dunedin woman feared for her life, the paper reveals, after her daughter's pet pig knocked her down and then apparently tried to eat her. Vivienne Christie, who was babysitting her granddaughter, stepped into the pen to refill the water trough when the hog, Quincy, which weighed about 220lb, charged. Mrs Christie, a retired teacher, says that she will never trust a pig again.

fields.headline: Jobs outlook 'best in decades'
fields.trailText: Job prospects in small firms are being jeopardised by red tape, but the overall outlook for employment is one of the brightest for decades, according to two business surveys published today.
fields.body:
Job prospects in small firms are being jeopardised by red tape, but the overall outlook for employment is one of the brightest for decades, according to two business surveys published today.

Employers in all regions plan to hire more staff over the next three months, said Manpower, the employment services agency, with the biggest gains expected in the west, followed by East Anglia and the East Midlands.

While most parts of manufacturing are depressed and likely to continue shedding employees or hire them more slowly, service industries are expected to expand payrolls rapidly.

Retailing has the rosiest outlook, with a balance of 61% of firms saying they will hire rather than fire over the next three months.

But the survey, based on larger employers, is contradicted by a separate poll of smaller firms by the Institute of Chartered Accountants, which shows the growing weight of government regulation is preventing many from expanding.

The cost to the smallest, "micro" businesses of complying with new legislation has more than doubled since last year, rising to an average of £3,600, inhibiting many from hiring new employees.

"For smaller businesses, hiring more staff significantly increases the level of work required to meet PAYE and NI regulations, employment protection and health and safety legislation," said the Institute of Chartered Accountants.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Instant camera's gonna get you | The way of all flesh
fields.body:
Instant camera's gonna get you
On its way to Saturn, on Monday, the spacecraft Cassini took its first colour snaps of the planet Jupiter, from a distance of about 50 million miles. October 9 was an important day for Cassini camera chief Carolyn Porco of the University of Arizona. She is a Beatles fan, and October 9 would have been John Lennon's 60th birthday. "This is our first colour image from Cassini and my gift to John Lennon - one of planet Earth's brightest stars, and a person who gave us all boundless joy, pleasure and inspiration," Porco said. "I am pleased that I can celebrate his birthday in this way."

The way of all flesh
In just 400 years, 135 mammal species disappeared from the Americas. These included mastodons, camels, lions, cheetahs, sabre-tooth tigers, horses, giant sloths as big as buffalos and (in South America) the glyptodont, a kind of armadillo, but 20 times bigger. Ross MacPhee of the American Museum of Natural History thinks it could have been something nasty, perhaps spread by the first humans, that toppled animals that had survived entire ice ages. The search is on, for evidence in mammoth bone marrow. MacPhee is not staking his career on the hyperdisease. "If something better comes along tomorrow, it's dead meat," he said.

Fate settles the score
The October issue of Discover has just devised 20 ways the world could end. Asteroid impact is number one. A gamma ray burst a mere 1,000 light years away could fry the planet. A passing black hole could gobble us up. The magnetic field could go into reverse (it last happened 780,000 years ago). There could be a very nasty epidemic of plague. Something horrible could happen in a particle accelerator, or the ecosystem could completely collapse, or biotechnologists could make a ghastly mistake. The magazine doesn't rule out global war, alien invasion, takeover by robots or divine intervention, either.

Fate settles the score The October issue of Discover has just devised 20 ways the world could end. Asteroid impact is number one. A gamma ray burst a mere 1,000 light years away could fry the planet. A passing black hole could gobble us up. The magnetic field could go into reverse (it last happened 780,000 years ago). There could be a very nasty epidemic of plague. Something horrible could happen in a particle accelerator, or the ecosystem could completely collapse, or biotechnologists could make a ghastly mistake. The magazine doesn't rule out global war, alien invasion, takeover by robots or divine intervention, either.

fields.headline: Wave of destruction
fields.standfirst: Bill McGuire  looks at the horrifying wall of water that could sweep away a coastal city and cause the greatest natural catastrophe in human history
fields.trailText: Bill McGuire looks at the horrifying wall of water that could sweep away a coastal city and cause the greatest natural catastrophe in human history
fields.body:
Tsunamis are silent, stalking horrors that often appear without warning and with no apparent cause to devastate a coastline thousands of kilometres from their source.

Compared with earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, images of tsunamis are rare. Anyone close enough to photograph them is usually rewarded with a watery grave alongside the fragmented remains of the camera.

Most result from large submarine earthquakes that give the sea floor and the water above such a jolt that waves shoot outwards in all directions. In the last century alone, earthquakes around the Pacific rim produced over 400 tsunamis in this way resulting in the loss of over 50,000 lives.

Volcanoes can also produce devastating tsunamis, with the cataclysmic 1883 eruption of Krakatoa (Indonesia) churning up the sea sufficiently to produce lethal waves that killed 36,000 people.

Submarine landslides are also particularly effective: a gigantic collapse off the coast of Norway around 7,000 years ago resulted in north-eastern Scotland being inundated by huge waves.

Even scarier are the mega-tsunamis formed by gigantic landslides at ocean island volcanoes. Before the last Ice Age a chunk of rock ten times the size of the Isle of Wight fell off the flank of the Mauna Loa volcano on the Big Island of Hawaii, forming tsunamis that raged 320m up the sides of neighbouring islands and even pounded the coastline of New South Wales 7,000km away.

Scarier still, when a 1km asteroid plunged into the southeast Pacific just over two million years ago it sent a 70m wave of destruction hurtling across the entire Pacific.

They are very different from the normal, wind-driven waves that break millions of times a day on our shores. One of their strangest properties is the Jekyll and Hyde transformation as they approach the shore. In deep water a tsunami is to all intents and purposes invisible; a wave less than a metre high that is lost among the troughs and peaks of a turbulent sea.

Only when the tsunami enters shallow water does it start to build in height as the front of the wave slows and is caught by more water from behind. In a matter of minutes a half-metre swell can become a wall of water 20m or more high. And if the waves are focused into estuaries and bays, this height can increase even further. This behaviour sheds light on the derivation of the term "tsunami", which in the original Japanese means 'harbour wave'.

The building of a tsunami as it approaches a coastline also results in another of its weird properties. As the wave increases in size it sucks in water that causes the sea to retreat from the shore, sometimes as far as the horizon or beyond - collecting it all together for the big push.

Unless the local population has been educated in the mysteries of the tsunami, this can be lethal as thousands rush curiously on to the exposed sea-bed only to be battered by the sudden appearance of the tsunami itself. And can they move? In deep water, tsunamis can move at speeds in excess of 800km an hour - as fast as a jet aircraft - and even when the wave slows as it enters the shallows there is no possibility of outrunning it.

Another difference between tsunamis and wind-driven storm waves is that the entire column of water from the sea surface to the sea floor, perhaps several kilometres high, is involved in the wave motion.

So, for example, the entire volume of the ocean is involved in the transmission of a tsunami from one side of the Pacific to the other. Trying to cram all this movement into progressively shallowing waters is part of the reason for the terrifying height increase as a tsunami approaches a coastline. The water simply has nowhere else to go but up.

But it is not only the spectacular height and power of tsunamis that makes them so destructive. When they hit the coast they just keep coming - perhaps for 20 to 30 minutes - before taking the same time to drain back into the ocean. This is because a tsunami wavelength is typically hundreds of kilometres long rather than the few tens of metres characteristic of storm waves.

Such long waves reflect the scale of the phenomena that generate tsunamis. If a submarine quake thrusts upwards an area of sea floor the size of England by a metre or two then you can be sure that the ripples formed will be of a comparably spectacular scale.

The destructive power of a tsunami is truly awesome. Ships and coastal installations are smashed to matchwood in seconds and solid metal structures such as parking metres are combed flat. A three-storey building would be lucky to survive an impact from a 10m wave, while a 20m wave would leave a five storey office block much the worse for wear.

A fragile human caught in the open has almost no chance of survival and severe battering by debris results in few bodies being recovered intact. Many, in fact, are carried far out into the ocean never to be seen again.

Things have been relatively quiet on the tsunami front since 1998 when an offshore earthquake and accompanying submarine landslide generated a series of waves that flattened villages and took 3,000 lives on the north coast of New Guinea . Sadly, further big earthquakes are sure to repeat this scenario time and time again in coming years.

Waiting in the wings, however, is the terrifying prospect of the coming Atlantic mega-tsunami. The western flank of the Cumbre Vieja volcano on the Canary Island of La Palma remains unstable and poised to slide into the sea. Recent modelling has shown that when this happens the initial wave will be 600m high. Eight hours later, as the wall of water bears down on the east coast of the United States and the Caribbean Islands, the human race will face the greatest natural catastrophe in its history. You have been warned!

 Bill McGuire is the Benfield Greig professor of geohazards and director of the Benfield Greig Hazard research centre at University College London. The coming Atlantic Mega-tsunami is the focus of tonight's Horizon programme on BBC2 at 9.30pm

fields.headline: Blake's heaven
fields.standfirst: Tim Radford  finds out why the paintings of the author of Jerusalem are coming unstuck
fields.trailText: Tim Radford finds out why the paintings of the author of Jerusalem are coming unstuck
fields.body:
Some of William Blake is completely cracked. That is not a judgment about his poetry. Some of William Blake is very dark. That is not a statement about his vision of Albion. Both are statements about glue.

Blake painted with vision, passion and glue. Strictly speaking, according to Joyce Townsend, conservation scientist at the Tate Britain - the scene of next months' full-scale exhibition of Blake's life and work - he painted with glue tempera. He also used gum, and then he used water-based paints on a glue ground because he didn't care for oils.

What he painted was a message for his age and his contemporaries may be the only ones to have got the message he intended. Time, chemistry and 19th century restorers have smeared over the original luminous vision.

"Large paintings on glue don't survive well anyway and they really need that rigid support, because glue cracks, it is sensitive to moisture," says Dr Townsend. "You keep it anywhere with a change of relative humidity - because you heat the room during the day and you cool it at night - and cracks develop and bits flake off.

"He not only used glue, he used very thick layers. He was the only person doing that, he didn't call it tempera, he called it fresco. He said he was trying to emulate the jewel-like colours that you saw in frescoes and jewel-like colours are not what you think when you see a lot of Blake's temperas now. It can change so much."

She is not restoring Blake. She is looking in exquisite detail at flakes and tiny samples from his paintings to try to disentangle the man from the accidents of his materials.

Blake had intemperate views on painting and painters. "Venetian, all thy Colouring is no more/ Than Boulster'd Plasters on a Crooked Whore." He was talking about Titian.

But then he had intemperate views the way other people have lunch: regularly. "The road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom," he also said. "Prudence is a rich, ugly old maid courted by incapacity."

One day virtual reality might reconstruct the excess and the imprudence of Blake's colours as they might have shone, 200 years ago. But the originals have suffered enough at the hands of a previous generation of carers. Blake described oil as a "cloggy" medium and he was an intemperate critic of the Royal Academy school as exemplified by Sir Joshua Reynolds.

But that kind of forthrightness didn't save him from confusion.

"Some of his temperas in the past have been treated as if they were oils, and conservation treatments have been carried out that were entirely approriate for oil paintings but not appropriate for his materials. It was as if they did not know what they were dealing with, and I don't suppose they did, in the 19th century, after he died," says Dr Townsend.

Good glue dries clear; coarse, cheap glue goes yellow. There is glue on Blake's canvases but it may not have been his. It masks the original jewel-like colours, but, says Dr Townsend, some of them are there all the same.

"When you look at the water colours, you see quite a bright palette, you see blues, red, bluish greens, you don't see very grassy greens ever, and you see yellows.

"You don't see purples, you don't see that much solid black or solid brown, but you see quite bright areas of colour, you see modulated colour, and then you look at some of the temperas and those in better condition, you could still see these same colours.

"In fact, he was using very much the same pigments in tempera and water colour, they could have looked very similar originally."

Stare at the chemistry enough, and you can reconstruct the artist in his studio. "I would think he worked pretty fast," she says. "It's not that easy to work with glue. The easiest way is to keep several pots hot, a pot for each colour. You'd keep them probably the right distance from the open fire, you'd have to look after the fire, keep it going or move the pots back and forward.

"It would be a really tedious process. You might actually work quite quickly while you had the glue at the right temperature."

She sees him stepping out from his home in Lambeth to buy from the professional artists' colourmen already in business around Covent Garden, who formulated pigments out of minerals and vegetable matter and sugars and gums, many of them imported from Benares and the Far East, and who sold whole suits of reds, or blues or yellows to the art market.

"Blake had a very narrow colour range compared with other artists: vermilion and red lead, prussian blue most of the time - ultramarine when you needed it for sky - yellow ochre, brown ochre, madder, probably gamboge. This is a yellow that fades and a yellow that fades under a varnish that goes yellow is very hard to spot."

Blake wouldn't have used a lot of ultramarine: it was made from crushed lapis lazuli, shipped from Afghanistan, and was costly.

"I think maybe I do have a picture of the individual shuffling out to buy materials to do enough for small quantities of works or a handcoloured version of the prints.

"I don't think he had a big organised storeroom at all, I think he just got things as needed, and even maybe there is not much of one colour in one because he was just finishing it and there wasn't any left.

"I have pictures of a just-in-time philosophy of making up just enough materials, working in a small scale just for the thing in hand."

 William Blake: Tate Britain from November 9 to February 11, is supported by Glaxo Wellcome. Admission £8, concessions £5, family ticket £21.

fields.headline: Thanks for the tip
fields.standfirst:
Can e-commerce survive on gratitude? asks John Barker
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Can e-commerce survive on gratitude? asks John Barker
fields.body:
Despite the heady trillion dollar predictions for e-commerce, the reality is that life is hard for dot.com companies. The promise of great riches has produced hordes of wannabee sites, often grossly over-funded but run by inexperienced people.

Even worse, the bricks and mortar outlets are starting to fight back. In this situation you can lie back and die, or attack. One of Europe's leading retailers of digital versatile discs (DVDs) retaliated last week with a strategy that could have major implications.

DVDplus has abandoned the cost-plus model, saying: "Here is the cost; if you like the service then leave us a tip". This concept it calls the"e-tip".

All the DVDs on its website (See www.dvdplus.co.uk) are now listed at cost (the price it pays for the DVD) plus postage and packing, also at cost. Its profits depend on whether the customer leaves a tip.

Bryan Welsh, managing director of DVDplus, said: "For the first time in retailing history we're giving customers the power to decide how much to pay. We believe we offer the best service in the business, so our customers will be happy to buy DVDs at cost, and leave an e-tip in appreciation of that service. If you don't think we're doing the best job in the business then don't leave us an e-tip. We are prepared to live or die by the e-tip."

Is this the last act of a dying business or an innovation that will transform e-commerce? The latter seems more likely because the results so far have been astonishing. Since the launch of last week's initiative, the number of visitors to the site has tripled and the amount of business has doubled. The most important statistic is that half of them left a tip. These are early days but Welsh is pleased.

DVDplus was set up in 1998 by a bunch of top ex-Intel employees who describe themselves as new generation retailers and are exclusively web-based. They see the benefits of their operation as wide selection (every title launched in UK) and convenience (open 24 hours a day).

On the face of it the proposition is compelling and the product is ideal for e-commerce. The DVD has been hailed as the fastest growing consumer electronics product of all time. Growth in Europe is outstripping even that in the US. Vastly increased quality of audio and video are two of the factors propelling this new format, which is challenging the dominance of the videocassette. Sadly for the dot.coms, the success of DVD has not gone unnoticed by the traditional retailers. Even the supermarkets are vying for a slice of the burgeoning market.

No longer is the internet always the cheapest option, given the massive buying power of the supermarkets. Welsh says: "When Asda is offering 'Two DVDs for £20' it is not easy to compete".

Dixons, too, is keen to jump on the bandwagon. Back in the 80s it missed out on becoming a destination site for CDs and is determined to avoid that happening with DVDs.

The DVD market is still in its infancy and it is dominated by the Hollywood blockbuster titles. They are an impulse buy for the Saturday shopper. Thus, internet sales of DVD titles are not booming in the UK and many e-retailers are having a rough time. It would seem that the internet-savvy early adopters are not typical consumers of DVD titles. They are a different breed - often film buffs who prefer to buy a title direct from the US.

Or they can shop around and buy from an offshore site that does not levy VAT. The people who buy DVDs at the moment are the telly addicts. They could be reached via the TV but "it costs close to £1m to get access through OpenTV and we don't have that sort of money," says Welsh.

While DVDplus is still growing, this latest act is a bold move to capture the market. Welsh admits that it is a desperate gamble to gain volume. "We have done the research," he says, "we think it will work. If it doesn't we could be out of business next year".

By moving to a cost-plus approach, DVDplus is hoping to treble its volume and cover its overheads. In the process it could wipe out its competition in the UK. Who'd be a dot.com company?

 John Barker is the editor of Inside Multimedia.

fields.headline: Don't feed them up
fields.standfirst: Natasha McDowell on the possible danger                                                                      in helping a poorly nourished child to catch                                                                      up
fields.trailText: Natasha McDowell on the possible danger in helping a poorly nourished child to catch up
fields.body:
It would seem common sense that a malnourished foetus may have problems in later life. But could that individual be better off if it stays poorly nourished?

This controversial theory may be the key to preventing the type of diabetes that can develop in middle age. Textbooks say that whether or not you develop type II diabetes depends in part on which genes you inherit and in part on environmentalfactors such as obesity.

But Nick Hales, professor of clinical biochemistry at Cambridge University thinks it is "your early development, in addition to obesity, that determines your risk of developing the disease". Twelve years ago he was studying a clear link between obesity and type II diabetes, when he met David Barker, professor of clinical epidemiology at Southampton University.

"David was investigating whether heart and blood pressure problems might be due to poor foetal growth. We discussed mechanisms that might explain this and wondered whether they might also apply to type II diabetes." The hormone insulin lets your body remove glucose, produced as food is digested, from your bloodstream. With type II diabetes you do not produce sufficient insulin, nor can you use it effectively. As glucose builds up in your blood, symptoms range from tiredness and weight loss, to kidney failure, heart attacks and blindness.

Insulin is made by cells in your pancreas which normally grow very quickly during foetal life. The scientists reasoned that if your foetal food supply is poor then you might have fewer of these cells and not be able to produce sufficient insulin so diabetes will result. Their initial approach was crude but informative.

They looked at birth-weight records for 60-80 year olds in Hertfordshire, Preston and Sheffield and found those with a low birthweight were more likely to develop type II diabetes, especially if they had become obese in later life. Hales's team fed pregnant rats either a normal diet or one with half the normal protein. Malnourished mothers gave birth to small malnourished babies and normally-nourished mothers gave birth to normally-nourished babies. Then malnourished babies were suckled by the normally-nourished foster mothers, and vice versa. The malnourished babies suckled by normal foster mothers were, by weaning, the same weight as babies who had never been malnourished. But these foster babies, espe cially the males, died younger, than normal babies who, suckled by malnourished foster mothers, had been poorly nourished during this stage.

"A pregnant mother who is malnourished communicates this to her baby and the foetus adapts to its food shortage by growing in a different way," says Hales.

"Somehow, maybe by a change in the bloodstream, nutrients are diverted to essential organs like the brain and lung, since if you have a smaller kidney, pancreas or liver, it's not that critical in the short-term. The problem is that these adaptations by the food starved organs permanently alter their development and the way they will function in later life." A pancreas optimised for a poor nutritional environment will have no problem if food continues to be sparse after birth. In sub-Saharan Africa birthweight is low, but glucose tolerance is high and diabetes is almost non-existent. Hales believes this is because such infants, if malnourished before birth, are also likely to be poorly nourished after birth and so never catch-up.

Obesity among adult sub-Saharans is also rare. In the west in contrast, although a foetus may be malnourished due to problems during pregnancy, food is usually abundant post-birth and so a pancreas developed to be "thrifty" will be traumatised. "Our big question is if a baby born malnourished then receives many nutrients, will this make it more prone to diabetes in later life, especially if it also becomes obese?" says Hales.

"We don't want to scare mothers who have had small babies and experienced health visitors with the traditional 'stuff-'em till they burst' approach to feeding. Rats do mimic the human situation in some ways. Like male baby rats, human male babies with low birth-weights undergo faster growth than female babies born with a low birth-weight. Male rats also die younger then female rats, just like men generally die younger than women. But until we do more human trials we cannot say for sure whether such catch-up growth is detrimental to long-term health in humans as it is in the rat."

This will be discussed in February as part of aninternational conference which has caught the interest of the World Health Organisation and the World Bank More than 100 million people world wide have type II diabetes and for every one known case it is estimated that there is one unknown. In the UK it affects 2% of people, but accounts for 5% of health service spending.

"Ideally, there needs to be a whole change in emphasis so women and especially pregnant women are at the start of the food chain," says Hales. But it is easier and cheaper, with environmental theories rather than genetic ones, to change a situation and improve health. Which is why WHO and the World Bank are interested.

fields.headline: Kerbango tango
fields.standfirst:
If you are on one of those addicted to listening to the radio on your computer you have to have a wireless, writes Jack Schofield
Net news
fields.trailText: If you are on one of those addicted to listening to the radio on your computer you have to have a wireless, writes Jack Schofield
fields.body:
"It looks and works like a radio, but it's an internet radio, so instead of picking up just 20 stations, it could pick up 20,000," says James Gable, the president of Kerbango. "And it does it without using a personal computer!"

The Kerbango radio is intended to appeal to computer users who are already listening to radio stations via the internet, but it has four advantages. First, it is a dedicated appliance and therefore easier to operate. Second, you can listen to local radio stations all over the world - though listening to your old home town radio is a more attractive feature in the US than it is here.

Third, it handles data, so it can offer two-way services such as letting users vote on songs, or buy albums or concert tickets. And fourth, you can put a Kerbango radio in a kitchen or bedroom where you might not want a conventional PC.

The Kerbango is also at the forefront of the "everything IP" movement. In the long term, almost every kind of data - voice, radio, television, movies - should be available via IP (internet protocol) as well as, or instead of, using traditional delivery systems.

Of course, the Kerbango does not really avoid using a personal computer, and at the moment it won't appeal to the long-promised "appliance" market, but that's the concept. While it looks like a retro-styled radio, inside, the Kerbango is actually based on a personal computer board with an 81MHz Motorola/ IBM PowerPC processor running Montavista's Hard Hat Linux (a version of the GNU/Linux clone of the Unix operating system). But these are shielded from the user, who operates the Kerbango using menus on a quarter-VGA monochrome LCD (liquid crystal display) screen.

There isn't a "tuning knob" for finding thousands of stations, and you don't have to type in internet addresses to get them. When connected to the internet through a phone or Ethernet socket, the radio accesses the free Kerbango Tuning Service ), which provides a thematic menu of options. First, you choose the kind of music you want - Oldies, then 50s pop, for example - then pick a station to try.

The listing also includes many internet-only stations, and things like police scanners. The Kerbango radio can "play" RealAudio streams and streamed MP3 files, which Gable says covers about 80% of the market. It doesn't work with Windows Media Audio "but,"Gable says, "we'd like to support it."

When not plugged in to the internet, the Kerbango works as a traditional standalone AM/FM clock radio, picking up signals via an aerial. Marc Auerbach, Kerbango's director of marketing, says: "We really want to replace your AM/FM radio, not just upgrade it." Internet stations are available only when the Kerbango is connected to the internet, which means it is not really practical for people with dial-up connections. Normally it will be plugged into an Ethernet local area network. These are standard in businesses, but a growing number of home users with "always on" broadband internet connections are also installing Ethernet, especially in the US.

"Internet appliances" are supposed to appeal to late adopters - people who don't want to make the effort to cope with connecting a personal computer - but Gable says: "We realise this is an early-adopter product." He thinks the sort of people with broadband internet connections are the most likely to spend $299 on a portable MP3 music player, or a Palm electronic organiser, or a Kerbango.

From what I heard using a 56k modem connection, the sound quality leaves something to be desired. Part of the problem is that many internet broadcasters are targeting users with slow dial-up modems, and even the music stations may stream mono instead of stereo feeds. The quality should improve as broadband becomes more widely used. Users who want better amplification can connect the Kerbango to a hi-fi system.

Another small drawback is that when you select a station, it doesn't start playing immediately: as with any PC, the signal has to be "buffered" (held in a temporary cache) to compensate for network congestion and the stop/start nature of internet communications.

Still, internet radio is seen as an important development, and Kerbango should get a fair crack at the market. This summer, it was taken over by 3Com, a California-based networking giant, and Thomson, a consumer electronics company, has signed up to market a version under its RCA brand label. This should give Kerbango an advantage over rivals such as AudioRamp.com of Tustin, California.

The Kerbango is expected to go on sale in the US in December. So far there are no plans for a UK launch, but the radio comes with a universal power supply and would work here, too.
